. A combining form from the Gr. idea.

One of several species of large, crested ground pigeons of thegenus Goura, inhabiting New Guinea and adjacent islands. The QueenVictoria pigeon (Goura Victoria) and the crowned pigeon (G. coronata)are among the beat known species.

A black substance formed by combustion, or disengaged from fuelin the process of combustion, which rises in fine particles, andadheres to the sides of the chimney or pipe conveying the smoke;strictly, the fine powder, consisting chiefly of carbon, which colorssmoke, and which is the result of imperfect combustion. See Smoke.

The division of a piece of timber made by sawing; a board orplank; particularly, a board or plank of fir or pine above seveninches in width, and exceeding six feet in length. If narrower thanthis, it is called a batten; if shorter, a deal end.

A beverage composed of wine or distilled liquor, water (ormilk), sugar, and the juice of lemon, with spice or mint; --specifically named from the kind of spirit used; as rum punch, claretpunch, champagne punch, etc. Milk punch, a sort of punch made withspirit, milk, sugar, spice, etc.-- Punch bowl, a large bowl in which punch is made, or from which itis served.-- Roman punch, a punch frozen and served as an ice.
Nonsecretion or defective secretion of urine; ischury.
To kindle. [Obs.] Bp. Sanderson.
Of or pertaining to a city. Shak. City council. See underCouncil.-- City court, The municipal court of a city. [U. S.] -- City ward,a watchman, or the collective watchmen, of a city. [Obs.] Fairfax.
Gray. [R.] Chaucer.
To apply a cautery to; to cauterize.
A viola da gamba.
To kiss. [Obs.] Chaucer

The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper (Piper Cubeba; inmed., Cubeba officinalis), native in Java and Borneo, but nowcultivated in various tropical countries. The dried unripe fruit ismuch used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.
A narrow arm of the sea; an estuary; the opening of a riverinto the sea; as, the Frith of Forth.
To strip off the external covering or envelope of; as, to huskIndian corn.

As far as; to the place or degree that; especially, up to thetime that; till. See Till, conj.In open prospect nothing bounds our eye, Until the earth seems joinedunto the sky. Dryden.But the rest of the dead lives not again until the thousand yearswere finished. Rev. xx. 5.
A ray or glimmer of light; a gleam. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Lorry, or Lorrie.
To stand the consequences of; to answer for; to suffer for.Dearly I abide that boast so vain. Milton.
Any one of several species of small insectivorous West Indianbirds of the genus Todus. They are allied to the kingfishers.
A large pulpit or reading desk, in the early Christianchurches. Gwilt.
A baby; a dunce. [Prov. Eng.]
Possessive form of the pronoun it. See It.
Early; soon. [Prov. Eng.]Then why does Cuddy leave his cot so rear! Gay.

To form or become covered with cream; to become thick likecream; to assume the appearance of cream; hence, to grow stiff orformal; to mantle.There are a sort of men whose visages Do cream and mantle like astanding pool. Shak.
The comic actress in an opera.-- a.
Repeated potations; social or exessive indulgence inintoxicating drinks; revelry.Thence from cups to civil broils. Milton.
To choose or elect in concert with another. [R.]Each of the hundred was to coöpt three others. Jowett (Thysyd. ).
The European throstle or song thrush (Turdus musicus).
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as themandibular rami are united.

A long piece of timber, nearly cylindrical, tapering toward theends, and designed to support and extend a square sail. A yard isusually hung by the center to the mast. See Illust. of Ship. GoldenYard, or Yard and Ell (Astron.), a popular name the three stars inthe belt of Orion.-- Under yard [i. e., under the rod], under contract. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A salt of uric acid; as, sodium urate; ammonium urate.
On the top of; upon; on. See On to, under On, prep.
See Leden. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To bear; to endure; to undergo. [Obs. or Scot.] Gower.So much woe as I have with you tholed. Chaucer.To thole the winter's steely dribble. Burns.
To alienate; to estrange; to transfer, as property orownership. [R.] "It the son alien lands." Sir M. Hale.The prince was totally aliened from all thoughts of . . . themarriage. Clarendon.
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.
To rend apart. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A genus of plants found in China and Japan; the tea plant.
Accent, or inflection or modulation of the voice, as adapted toexpress emotion or passion.Eager his tone, and ardent were his eyes. Dryden.
See Lam.
The great river of Egypt. Nile bird. (Zoöl.) (a) The wryneck.[Prov. Eng.] (b) The crocodile bird.-- Nile goose (Zoöl.), the Egyptian goose. See Note under Goose, 2.

To put to death with a weapon, or by violence; hence, to kill;to put an end to; to destroy.With this sword then will I slay you both. Chaucer.I will slay the last of them with the sword. Amos ix. 1.I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk. Shak.
The god Pluto. Shak.
Release; remission; ease; relief. [Obs.] "Of penance had alisse." Chaucer.
See Price, and 1st Prize. [Obs.]
To burst. [Obs.]And both his yën braste out of his face. Chaucer.Dreadfull furies which their chains have brast. Spenser.
Full; complete; plenary. [Obs.]
To stuff; to lard; to farce. [R.]Wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit. Shak.
Perhaps; possibly; peradventure.Maybe the amorous count solicits her. Shak.In a liberal and, maybe, somewhat reckless way. Tylor.
See Panim. [Obs.]
Making irps. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A place of shelter; protection; refuge. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.][Also written bield and beeld.]The random beild o' clod or stane. Burns.
Species; kind. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To burn up. [Obs.] Bacon.
Secret; secretive; faithful to a secret. [Obs.]To be holden stable and secre. Chaucer.

To explain; to resolve; to unfold; to clear up out to a resultor conclusion; as, to solve a doubt; to solve difficulties; to solvea problem.True piety would effectually solve such scruples. South.God shall solve the dark decrees of fate. Tickell.
To cover.-- n.
The cry of a wild goose.-- Honk"ing, n.

Of or pertaining to urine; obtained from urine; as, uric acid.Uric acid, a crystalline body, present in small quantity in the urineof man and most mammals. Combined in the form of urate of ammonia, itis the chief constituent of the urine of birds and reptiles, formingthe white part. Traces of it are also found in the various organs ofthe body. It is likewise a common constituent, either as the freeacid or as a urate, of urinary or renal calculi and of the so-calledgouty concretions. From acid urines, uric acid is frequentlydeposited, on standing in a cool place, in the form of a reddishyellow sediment, nearly always crystalline. Chemically, it iscomposed of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen, C5H4N4O3, and bydecomposition yields urea, among other products. It can be madesynthetically by heating together urea and glycocoll. It was formerlycalled also lithic acid, in allusion to its occurrence in stone, orcalculus.

An extensive tribe of North American Indians of the Shoshonestock, inhabiting Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, Arizona, and adjacentregions. They are subdivided into several subordinate tribes, some ofwhich are among the most degraded of North American Indians.

A dignitary under the Anglo-Saxons and Danes in England. Ofthese there were two orders, the king's thanes, who attended thekings in their courts and held lands immediately of them, and theordinary thanes, who were lords of manors and who had particularjurisdiction within their limits. After the Conquest, this title wasdisused, and baron took its place.
See Birt.
A piece of money, usually silver money. [Obs.] "Realms andislands were as plates dropp'd from his pocket." Shak.

The second letter of the Greek alphabet, B, b. See B, and cf.etymology of Alphabet. Beta (B, b) is used variously for classifying,as:(a) (Astron.) To designate some bright star, usually the secondbrightest, of a constellation, as, b Aurigæ.(b) (Chem.) To distinguish one of two or more isomers; also, toindicate the position of substituting atoms or groups in certaincompounds; as, b-naphthol. With acids, it commonly indicates that thesubstituent is in union with the carbon atom next to that to whichthe carboxyl group is attached.
A small, flat, sweetened cake of various kinds.
To glisten; to gleam. [Obs.] Prior.
Same as Sufi.

To become, in some respects, different; to vary; to change; as,the weather alters almost daily; rocks or minerals alter by exposure."The law of the Medes and Persians, which altereth not." Dan. vi. 8.
An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, andfastened with brooches.
To make rotten. [Obs.]Well bet is rotten apple out of hoard, Than that it roty all theremenant. Chaucer.
A narrow piece of timber which holds together large pieces; aslat; as, the sloats of a cart.

A part or decoration of the breastplate of the high priestamong the ancient Jews, by which Jehovah revealed his will on certainoccasions. Its nature has been the subject of conflictingconjectures.Thou shall put in the breastplate of judgment the Urim and theThummim. Ex. xxviii. 30.And when Saul inquired of the Lord, the Lord answered him not,neither by dreams, nor by Urim, nor by prophets. 1 Sam. xxviii. 6.
A beak, as of a bird, or sometimes of a turtle or other animal.Milton.

A total prohibition of intercourse with, use of, or approachto, a given person or thing under pain of death, -- an interdict ofreligious origin and authority, formerly common in the islands ofPolynesia; interdiction. [Written also tabu.]
of Do.
A strengthening cross timber.
pret. of Chese. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A goblin; a specter; a frightful phantom; a bogy; a bugbear.[Written also boggle.]
See Royne. [Obs.]
See Reign. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Silver. Luna cornea (Old Chem.), horn silver, or fused silverchloride, a tough, brown, translucent mass; -- so called from itsresemblance to horn. Luna moth (Zoöl.), a very large and beautifulAmerican moth (Actias luna). Its wings are delicate light green, witha stripe of purple along the front edge of the anterior wings, theother margins being edged with pale yellow. Each wing has a lunatespot surrounded by rings of light yellow, blue, and black. Thecaterpillar commonly feeds on the hickory, sassafras, and maple.
Having the heaves.
To come into view; to appear. [Scot.]It kythes bright . . . because all is dark around it. Sir W. Scott.
An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generallyasserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.
imp. & p. p. of Press.
See Almonry. [Obs.]
To clean with a mop or swab; to wipe when very wet, as afterwashing; as, to swab the desk of a ship. [Spelt also swob.]
To sing; esp. to sing joyfully; to warble.And carol of love's high praise. Spenser.The gray linnets carol from the hill. Beattie.

Bad, ill, evil, or corrupt, in a greater degree; more bad orevil; less good; specifically, in poorer health; more sick; -- usedboth in a physical and moral sense.Or worse, if men worse can devise. Chaucer.[She] was nothing bettered, but rather grew worse. Mark v. 26.Evil men and seducers shall wax worse and worse. 2 Tim. iii. 13.There are men who seem to believe they are not bad while another canbe found worse. Rambler."But I love him." "Love him Worse and worse." Gay.
To face, as an embankment, with masonry, wood, or othermaterial.
Vinnewed. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Made.  Chaucer.
Broadly elliptical. Oval chuck (Mech.), a lathe chuck soconstructed that work attached to it, and cut by the turning tool inthe usual manner, becomes of an oval form.

Eight and one more; one less than ten; as, nine miles. Ninemen's morris. See Morris.-- Nine points circle (Geom.), a circle so related to any giventriangle as to pass through the three points in which theperpendiculars from the angles of the triangle upon the oppositesides (or the sides produced) meet the sides. It also passes throughthe three middle points of the sides of the triangle and through thethree middle points of those parts of the perpendiculars that arebetween their common point of meeting and the angles of the triangle.The circle is hence called the nine points or six points circle.
A contrivance, turning on a vertical axis by a handle or winch,and giving a circular motion to the ore to be washed; a stirrer.
A figure made up of a large number of straight lines or curves,which are connected at certain points and related to each other bysome specified law.
A carved ornament on the stern of a vessel, containing a windowor the representation of one.

A tube, filled with combustible matter, for exploding a shell,etc. See Fuse, n. Chemical fuze, a fuze in which substances separateduntil required for action are then brought into contact, and unitingchemically, produce explosion.-- Concussion fuze, a fuze ignited by the striking of theprojectile.-- Electric fuze, a fuze which is ignited by heat or a sparkproduced by an electric current.-- Friction fuze, a fuze which is ignited by the heat evolved byfriction.-- Percussion fuze, a fuze in which the ignition is produced by ablow on some fulminating compound.-- Time fuze, a fuze adapted, either by its length or by thecharacter of its composition, to burn a certain time before producingan explosion.
That which goes out, or is paid out; outlay; expenditure; --the opposite of Ant: income. Lowell.
Gray. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Shining; sheen. [Obs.] Spenser.
A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in.

A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither andFarther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.India ink, a nearly black pigment brought chiefly from China, usedfor water colors. It is in rolls, or in square, and consists oflampblack or ivory black and animal glue. Called also China ink. Thetrue India ink is sepia. See Sepia.-- India matting, floor matting made in China, India, etc., fromgrass and reeds; -- also called Canton, or China, matting.-- India paper, a variety of Chinese paper, of smooth but not glossysurface, used for printing from engravings, woodcuts, etc.-- India proof (Engraving), a proof impression from an engravedplate, taken on India paper.-- India rubber. See Caoutchouc.-- India-rubber tree (Bot.), any tree yielding caoutchouc, butespecially the East Indian Ficus elastica, often cultivated for itslarge, shining, elliptical leaves.
A genus of Amphibia including various species of toads.
A cover; a shelter; a protection. [Archaic] Carew. C. Kingsley.
To hiss. [Obs.] Shak.

Any one of numerous species of Old World venomous makesbelonging to Vipera, Clotho, Daboia, and other genera of the familyViperidæ.There came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand. Actsxxviii. 3.
Composed of, or like, tow.
A branch. [Obs.] Chaucer.

One of the stages in the life history of certain rusts(Uredinales), regarded at one time as a distinct genus. It is asummer stage preceding the teleutospore, or winter stage. SeeUredinales, in the Supplement.

Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammablesubstances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors ofelectricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether,alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin(see Rosin).
A wrinkle; a fold; as, the rugæ of the stomach.
A spirit, or immaterial being, holding a middle place betweenmen and deities in pagan mythology.The demon kind is of an inSydenham.
One. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Loo.
Murder. [Obs.] Shak.
A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Rock. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One of the upper side pieces of the frame of a wagon body or asleigh.
To grieve; to feel sad. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The head. [Obs.] Shak.
Same as Izedi. Taylor.
An unfledged bird; hence, something immature or unfinished.Ford.
The daughter of Tantalus, and wife of Amphion, king of Thebes.Her pride in her children provoked Apollo and Diana, who slew themall. Niobe herself was changed by the gods into stone.
A plant from which layers are propagated by bending itsbranches into the soil. P. Henderson.
The keel and keelson of a ship.

A prefix denoting: (a) Likeness, similarity, or connection, orthat the substance resembles, but is distinct from, that to the nameof which it is prefixed; as paraldehyde, paraconine, etc.; also, anisomeric modification. (b) Specifically: (Organ. Chem.) That twogroups or radicals substituted in the benzene nucleus are opposite,or in the respective positions 1 and 4; 2 and 5; or 3 and 6, asparaxylene; paroxybenzoic acid. Cf. Ortho-, and Meta-. Also usedadjectively.
A Russian drink distilled from rye.
See Powp. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A farrow. [Obs.] Perry.
A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer andsofter than the nap of velvet. Cowper.
A servant; a farm laborer; a peasant; a hind. [Obs.]Bailiff, herd, nor other hine. Chaucer.
Mist; fog. See Roke. [Obs.]
A popular term for a bright-hued variety of some minerals; as,the rose-red cobalt bloom.
Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
Timid; fearful. [R.] Thackeray.
See Silly. [Obs.] Spenser.
To take in with the ears; to hear. [Sportive] "I eared herlanguage." Two Noble Kinsmen.
Like a snipe.
A fillet; a headband; a snood. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Vast. [Obs.] Dryden.
Fixed; solidified. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Sward. [R.] Milton.
pl. of Palus.
A variant of -hood.
see Roun. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
See Leme. [Obs.] Holland.
A quoit. [Obs.] Carew.
Full of sage; seasoned with sage.

A kind of intoxicating liquor distilled from cane juice, orfrom the scumming of the boiled juice, or from treacle or molasses,or from the lees of former distillations. Also, sometimes usedcolloquially as a generic or a collective name for intoxicatingliquor. Rum bud, a grog blossom. [Colloq.] -- Rum shrub, a drinkcomposed of rum, water, sugar, and lime juice or lemon juice, withsome flavoring extract.
See Bowl, a ball, a game.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know. [Obs.] Spenser.
A run made upon a missed ball; as, to steal a bye. T. Hughes.By the bye, in passing; by way of digression; apropos to the matterin hand. [Written also by the by.]
imp. of Wear.

A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found inthe northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs,spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those treeswhich have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to merescales, and the secondary ones (pine needles) acicular, and usuallyin fascicles of two to seven. See Pine.
A sheep in its second year; also, a doe in its second year.[Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.

A form of fungus which grows as indvidual rounded cells, ratherthan in a mycelium, and reproduces by budding; esp. members of theorders Endomycetales and Moniliales. Some fungi may grow both as ayeast or as a mycelium, depending on the conditions of growth. Yeastcake, a mealy cake impregnated with the live germs of the yeastplant, and used as a conveniently transportable substitute for yeast.-- Yeast plant (Bot.), the vegetable organism, or fungus, of whichbeer yeast consists. The yeast plant is composed of simple cells, orgranules, about one three-thousandth of an inch in diameter, oftenunited into filaments which reproduce by budding, and under certaincircumstances by the formation of spores. The name is extended toother ferments of the same genus. See Saccharomyces.-- Yeast powder, a baling powder, -- used instead of yeast inleavening bread.
No; not any; as, nul disseizin; nul tort.
A morsel left at a meal; a fragment; refuse; -- commonly usedin the plural. Milton.Let him have time a beggar's orts to crave. Shak.
Abounding with elms.The simple spire and elmy grange. T. Warton.
See Hip, the fruit of the dog-rose.
To prey; to plunder. [Obs.] Holinshed.
of Begin.
A swift sailing boat. [Obs.]So we took a scout, very much pleased with the manner andconversation of the passengers. Pepys.
imp. of Quake. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Cozy. Dickens.
To wet with dew or as with dew; to bedew; to moisten; as withdew.The grasses grew A little ranker since they dewed them so. A. B.Saxton.
To frisk or frolic like a colt; to act licentiously orwantonly. [Obs.]They shook off their bridles and began to colt. Spenser.
A small tube, usually curved, applied to a trumpet, horn, etc.,to change its pitch or key.
An ouch; a jewel. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A two-horse chariot.
One who, or that which, eats.
A prefix. See Pre-.
p. p. of Weave. Woven paper, or Wove paper, writing paperhaving an even, uniform surface, without watermarks.
Exodus; withdrawal. [Obs.]The time of the Jewish exody. Sir M. Hale.
The bulau.
The channel or spout through which molten metal runs into amold in casting. [Written also git, gate.]

Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria, esp. Somateriamollissima, which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America,and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which isan article of commerce; -- called also eider duck. The American eider(S. Dresseri), the king eider (S. spectabilis), and the spectacledeider (Arctonetta Fischeri) are related species. Eider down. Etym:[Cf. Icel. æ\'ebardun, Sw. eiderdun, Dan. ederduun.] Down of theeider duck, much sought after as an article of luxury.
A small haven. See Hithe. [Obs.]
pl. of Tree. " The shady treen." Fairfax.
of Hote. [Obs.] Spenser.
Master; lord; teacher; -- a Jewish title of respect or honorfor a teacher or doctor of the law. "The gravest rabbies."  Milton.
A woman. See Feme, n. Femme de chambre. Etym: [F.] A lady'smaid; a chambermaid.
The substance which, added to the material of a cell wall,makes it waterproof, as in cork.
A kind of oats. Farm. Encyc.
The malicious burning of a dwelling house or outhouse ofanother man, which by the common law is felony; the malicious andvoluntary firing of a building or ship. Wharton.

A straight line in space with which a definite linear magnitudetermed the pitch is associated (cf. 5th Pitch, 10 (b)). It is used toexpress the displacement of a rigid body, which may always be made toconsist of a rotation about an axis combined with a translationparallel to that axis.
The unit of value and account in Japan. Since Japan's adoptionof the gold standard, in 1897, the value of the yen has been about 50cents. The yen is equal to 100 sen.

To support, either by furnishing strength or means incoöperation to effect a purpose, or to prevent or to remove evil; tohelp; to assist.You speedy helpers . . . Appear and aid me in this enterprise. Shak.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as ofbirch. [Scot.]
One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts onshoes; as, a shoer of horses.
Bookish.

A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten,as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis; the common isRhodymenia. [Written also dillisk.]The crimson leaf of the dulse is seen To blush like a banner bathedin slaughter. Percival.
To bend; to box; to stoop. [Archaic] Chaucer. Longfellow.He fair the knight saluted, louting low. Spenser.
To remove a cap or cover from.
A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals. Thefamous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is A. Persicus; that ofCentral America, called talaje by the natives, is A. Talaje.
See Benne.
A tendon or tendonous tissue. See Tendon.

To a great degree or extent; greatly; abundantly; far; nearly."Much suffering heroes." Pope.Thou art much mightier than we. Gen. xxvi. 16.Excellent speech becometh not a fool, much less do lying lips aprince. Prov. xvii. 7.Henceforth I fly not death, nor would prolong Life much. Milton.All left the world much as they found it. Sir W. Temple.
Same. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An eruption of small, isolated, acuminated vesicles, producedby the entrance of a parasitic mite (the Sarcoptes scabei), andattended with itching. It is transmissible by contact.
Hove. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Characterized by breadth. See Breadth.
A cold north wind which prevails on the northern coasts of theMediterranean and in Switzerland, etc.; -- nearly the same as themistral.
of Delve. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any species of limicoline birds belonging to Himantopus andallied genera, in which the legs are remarkably long and slender.Called also longshanks, stiltbird, stilt plover, and lawyer.
See Fauces.
To embrace. [Obs.] "They coll and kiss him." Latimer.

To avoid slyly, by artifice, stratagem, or dexterity; to escapefrom in a covert manner; to mock by an unexpected escape; to baffle;as, to elude an officer; to elude detection, inquiry, search,comprehension; to elude the force of an argument or a blow.Me gentle Delia beckons from the plain, Then, hid in shades, eludeshe eager swain. Pope.The transition from fetichism to polytheism seems a gradual processof which the stages elude close definition. Tylor.

Pertaining to Holland, or to its inhabitants. Dutch auction.See under Auction.-- Dutch cheese, a small, pound, hard cheese, made from skim milk.-- Dutch clinker, a kind of brick made in Holland. It is yellowish,very hard, and long and narrow in shape.-- Dutch clover (Bot.), common white clover (Trifolium repens), theseed of which was largely imported into England from Holland.-- Dutch concert, a so-called concert in which all the singers singat the same time different songs. [Slang] -- Dutch courage, thecourage of partial intoxication. [Slang] Marryat.-- Dutch door, a door divided into two parts, horizontally, soarranged that the lower part can be shut and fastened, while theupper part remains open.-- Dutch foil, Dutch leaf, or Dutch gold, a kind of brass rich incopper, rolled or beaten into thin sheets, used in Holland toornament toys and paper; -- called also Dutch mineral, Dutch metal,brass foil, and bronze leaf.-- Dutch liquid (Chem.), a thin, colorless, volatile liquid,C2H4Cl2, of a sweetish taste and a pleasant ethereal odor, producedby the union of chlorine and ethylene or olefiant gas; -- called alsoDutch oil. It is so called because discovered (in 1795) by anassociation of four Hollandish chemists. See Ethylene, and Olefiant.-- Dutch oven, a tin screen for baking before an open fire orkitchen range; also, in the United States, a shallow iron kettle forbaking, with a cover to hold burning coals.-- Dutch pink, chalk, or whiting dyed yellow, and used in distemper,and for paper staining. etc. Weale.-- Dutch rush (Bot.), a species of horsetail rush or Equisetum (E.hyemale) having a rough, siliceous surface, and used for scouring andpolishing; -- called also scouring rush, and shave grass. SeeEquisetum.-- Dutch tile, a glazed and painted ornamental tile, formerly muchexported, and used in the jambs of chimneys and the like.
of Let, to allow. Chaucer.

An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coastwho had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of theSpaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. Theyconstructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned theirbuildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmithsand silversmiths. -- Yun"can (#), a.

Through; by means of; through the agency of; by; for; for each;as, per annum; per capita, by heads, or according to individuals; percuriam, by the court; per se, by itself, of itself. Per is alsosometimes used with English words. Per annum, by the year; in eachsuccessive year; annually.-- Per cent, Per centum, by the hundred; in the hundred; -- usedesp. of proportions of ingredients, rate or amount of interest, andthe like; commonly used in the shortened form per cent.-- Per diem, by the day. [For other phrases from the Latin, seeQuotations, Phrases, etc., from Foreign Languages, in theSupplement.]
Fuddled. [Obs.] Shak.
Easy or easily. [Obs.] "Eath to move with plaints." Fairfax.
The plant privet. [Obs.] Tusser.
A sort of blue or black clay lying near a vein of coal.
To fall off from the wind; to edge away to leeward; -- saidonly of inferior craft.
To be ashamed; to feel shame. [R.]I do shame To think of what a noble strain you are. Shak.
A form of the prefix com-, signifying with, together, inconjunction, joint. It is used before vowels and some consonants. SeeCom-.
Slippery; smooth; crafty; hypocritical. [Prov. Eng.] Slape ale,plain ale, as opposed to medicated or mixed ale. [Prov. Eng.]
A prefix from a Greek preposition. It usually signifies from,away from, off, or asunder, separate; as, in apocope (a cutting off),apostate, apostle (one sent away), apocarpous.
To dismantle; as, to strip a ship of rigging, spars, etc.
To defeat or evade; to invalidate. Thus, in a replication, theplaintiff may deny the defendant's plea, or confess it, and avoid itby stating new matter. Blackstone.
To perform the duties of a sewer. See 3d Sewer. [Obs.]
Penned or shut up; confined; -- often with up.Here in the body pent. J. Montgomery.No pent-up Utica contracts your powers. J. M. Sewall.

To subject, as cloth or yarn, to the fulling process; to full.[Obs. or Scot.] To walk the plank, to walk off the plank into thewater and be drowned; -- an expression derived from the practice ofpirates who extended a plank from the side of a ship, and compelledthose whom they would drown to walk off into the water; figuratively,to vacate an office by compulsion. Bartlett.
imp. & p. p. of Hear.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the gnat and mosquito.
Light blue; grayish blue; -- a term applied to different shadesat different periods.-- n.

The plural of he, she, or it. They is never used adjectively,but always as a pronoun proper, and sometimes refers to personswithout an antecedent expressed.Jolif and glad they went unto here [their] rest And casten hem [them]full early for to sail. Chaucer.They of Italy salute you. Heb. xiii. 24.Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness.Matt. v. 6.
The service or sacrifice of the Mass.

A prefix signifying to, toward, before, against, reversely,etc.; also, as a simple intensive; as in oblige, to bind to;obstacle, something standing before; object, lit., to throw against;obovate, reversely, ovate. Ob- is commonly assimilated before c, f,g, and p, to oc-, of-, og-, and op-.
A writ of right.
Barren land having only a thin coat of grass. [Prov. Eng.]
Noise; confusion; uproar.That, with the hurly, death itself awakes. Shak.
Surrounded by sky. [Poetic & R.] "The skyed mountain." Thomson.
Gold; -- so called from its brilliancy, color, and value.Chaucer.
A variant of Eddish. [Obs.] Mortimer.
The sky; the atmosphere; the firmament. [Obs. or Scot.]
Dung. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Ray. Scarn bee (Zoöl.), a dungbeetle.
A short or waste piece or knot of wool separated from thelonger staple by combing; also, a similar piece or shred of wastesilk.
See Æolic.
Air. [Obs.] Chaucer.

The amount by which a slide valve at its half stroke overlaps aport in the seat, being equal to the distance the valve must movefrom its mid stroke position in order to begin to open the port. Usedalone, lap refers to outside lap. See Outside lap (below).

A ruminant of the genus Cervus, of many species, and of relatedgenera of the family Cervidæ. The males, and in some species thefemales, have solid antlers, often much branched, which are shedannually. Their flesh, for which they are hunted, is called venison.
The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being theexternal or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares, the openings ofthe nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.
To pry; to peep slyly. Shak. Peak arch (Arch.), a pointed orGothic arch.
A solid bulb-shaped root, as of the crocus. See Bulb.
To collect, and reduce to order, as troops dispersed or throwninto confusion; to gather again; to reunite.
To strut; to swagger; to look big, pert, or menacing. Addison.
A troublesome grass, growing as a weed in grain fields; --called also chess. See Chess.
The act of snorting; the sound produced in snorting.
Paint used on the face. [Obs.] "Painted with French fard." J.Whitaker.
The snow goose. [Canadian, & Local U. S.]
An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate, a derivative ofnitrobenzene, chlorated napthalene, and wood meal.
To dry, or make dry. Bacon.
A circle of two or more leaves, flowers, or other organs, aboutthe same part or joint of a stem.
Hatred; fury; envy. [Obs.]
Credit; trust; as, to buy on, or upon, tick.
Designating, or pertaining to, the chief linguistic stock ofIndo-China, including the peoples of Siamese and Shan speech.
Strong; sinewy. "His nervy knees." Keats.
The flesh of a calf when killed and used for food.
See Mohr.
The rough, scaly matter on the surface of the bark of trees.[Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S.]

To stupefy with excess of light; with a blow, with cold, orwith fear; to confuse; to benumb.While flashing beams do daze his feeble eyen. Spenser.Such souls, Whose sudden visitations daze the world. Sir H. Taylor.He comes out of the room in a dazed state, that is an odd though asufficient substitute for interest. Dickens.

A member of the solar system which usually moves in anelongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion,and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. Acomet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, orcoma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequentlywanting. See Illustration in Appendix.
imp. & p. p. of Tell.
An old French copper coin, equivalent in value to, and nowdisplaced by, the five-centime piece (sou.
The aurochs.
A small tub or lading vessel. [Prov. Eng.] Johnson.

To have a dream of; to see, or have a vision of, in sleep, orin idle fancy; -- often followed by an objective clause.Your old men shall dream dreams. Acts ii. 17.At length in sleep their bodies they compose, And dreamt the futurefight. Dryden.And still they dream that they shall still succeed. Cowper.To dream away, out, through, etc., to pass in revery or inaction; tospend in idle vagaries; as, to dream away an hour; to dream throughlife. " Why does Antony dream out his hours" Dryden.

Said of crystalline rocks which contain a relatively lowpercentage of silica, as basalt. Basic salt (Chem.), a salt formedfrom a base or hydroxide by the partial replacement of its hydrogenby a negative or acid element or radical.
A vital part; one of the vitals. [R.]

That which fastens or holds; especially, (Naut.) a mooringrope, hawser, or chain; -- called, according to its position, a bow,head, quarter, breast, or stern fast; also, a post on a pier aroundwhich hawsers are passed in mooring.
Any detergent plant, or the part of it used as a detergent, asthe roots of Agave Americana, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, etc. [Sp.Amer. & Mex.]
To cry, as a cat; to waul. [Obs.] Spenser.
To stuff; to crowd; to fill full; hence, to make hot and close;to render stifling. Sandys.His chamber was commonly stived with friends or suitors of one kindor other. Sir H. Wotton.
One who fines or purifies.
A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section ofwhom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to theearth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.
A contraction for Violoncello.
A narrow street. [Prov. Eng.]
A kind of carp (Cyprinus gibelio); -- called also Prussiancarp.
To wane. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the Tamils, or to their language. [Writtenalso Tamul.]
An old Italian silver coin, worth about ten cents.
A concave molding; a cavetto. Gwilt.
A neatling of a pigeon or other similar bird, esp. when veryfat and not fully fledged.
A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired itssilvery color.
The people governed by the Incas, now represented by theQuichua tribe. Inca dove (Zoöl.), a small dove (Scardafella inca),native of Arizona, Lower California, and Mexico.
See Sola.

Contraction of Skimming and Skimmed. Skim coat, the final orfinishing coat of plaster.-- Skim colter, a colter for paring off the surface of land.-- Skim milk, skimmed milk; milk from which the cream has beentaken.
To exalt to the dignity of a god; to deify. [Obs.] "Begoddedsaints." South.
A hand basket. [Obs.] Herrick.
An herb; a plant.
Equal; impartial. [Obs.] Shak.
A European fish; the lyrie.
Circuit or compass.His great parts did not live within a small ambit. Milward.
A girdle. [Obs.] "Girt with a seint of silk." Chaucer.
A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille. [Obs.]Hudibras.

The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abodeof the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world;the grave.And death and Hades gave up the dead which were in them. Rev. xx. 13(Rev. Ver. ).Neither was he left in Hades, nor did his flesh see corruption. Actsii. 31 (Rev. Ver.).And in Hades he lifted up his eyes, being in torments. Luke xvi.23(Rev. Ver.).
See Phoebe.
A inn. [Turkey] See Khan.
The interval of a fifth.
A truffle. [Obs.]

Such portion of any quantity, as when taken a certain number oftimes, will exactly make that quantity; as, 3 is a part of 12; -- theopposite of multiple. Also, a line or other element of a geometricalfigure.
In Shetland and Orkney, a freehold; property held by udal, orallodial, right.
To ingraft, as a tree or plant, by the insertion of a bud oreye; to inoculate.The arts of grafting and ineying. J. Philips.
A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside fromthe main one. " Take no byways." Herbert.
A kind of wig. [Obs.] Lamb.
See Oxide.
That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.
Indian millet and its varieties. See Sorghum.
A saddle girth made of leather, canvas, woven horsehair, orwoven grass. [Western U.S.]
Among. [Obs.] "Ymel them all." Chaucer.
A waif. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Esteem. [Obs.] Spenser.
Curtain or covering; -- applied to various membranouspartitions, especially to the soft palate. See under Palate.
Learned. [Obs.] " Lewed man or lered." Chaucer.
The whole number of cards played in one round, and consistingof as many cards as there are players.On one nice trick depends the general fate. Pope.
Be silent; be still; hush; silence.
The packet of vellum leaves in which the gold is first beateninto thin sheets.
To cut to a bevel angle; to slope the edge or surface of.
Rounded stones containing tin ore, lying at the surface of theground, and indicating a vein. Raymond.
To kindle; to inflame; to excite.And flamed with zeal of vengeance inwardly. Spenser.
To beat or strike with a rod or whip; to whip; to lash; tochastise with repeated blows.
The female of the ruff.
Unless. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Cream; -- a term used esp. in cookery, names of liqueurs, etc.
In a coy manner; with reserve.
Redness; complexion. [Obs.] "His rode was red." Chaucer.
At a distance, but within view; yonder. [Poetic]Read thy lot in yon celestial sign. Milton.Though fast yon shower be fleeting. Keble.
A small evergreen tree or shrub (Arbutus Menziesii), ofCalifornia, having a smooth bark, thick shining leaves, and ediblered berries, which are often called madroña apples. [Written alsomadroño.]
An Arabian shrub Catha edulis) the leaves of which are used astea by the Arabs.
A blow or thump. Halliwell.-- a.
A servant. See Hine. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To cause to dance, or move nimbly or merrily about, or up anddown; to dandle.To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind. Shak.Thy grandsire loved thee well; Many a time he danced thee on hisknee. Shak.To dance attendance, to come and go obsequiously; to be or remain inwaiting, at the beck and call of another, with a view to please orgain favor.A man of his place, and so near our favor, To dance attendance ontheir lordships' pleasure. Shak.
A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people ofSwitzerland.
The namaycush.
The black grime or soot of coal. [Obs.] Burton.
See Saker.
Defensive armor for the thighs. [ Written also cuisse, andquish.]
An ornament [Obs.] L'Estrange.
Ornamented with bosses; studded.
A plank fixed beneath an object, as beneath the rudder of avessel, to protect it from injury; a plank on the ground under theend of a shore or the like.
Cleft to the middle or slightly beyond the middle; opening witha cleft; divided by a linear sinus, with straight margins.
See Pygmy. Pigmy falcon. (Zoöl.) Same as Falconet, 2 (a).
A boast. See Crack, n. [Obs.] Spenser.
One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serousmembranes.
A sort of flat custard or pie. [Obs.] Tusser.
. In faith; indeed; truly. Shak.
In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; withimperfect sight.
The gazelle.
The unbrunched antler of a young deer.

Earth and water mixed so as to be soft and adhesive. Mud bass(Zoöl.), a fresh-water fish (Acantharchum pomotis) of the EasternUnited States. It produces a deep grunting note.-- Mud bath, an immersion of the body, or some part of it, in mudcharged with medicinal agents, as a remedy for disease.-- Mud boat, a large flatboat used in deredging.-- Mud cat. See Catfish.-- Mud crab (Zoöl.), any one of several American marine crabs of thegenus Panopeus.-- Mud dab (Zoöl.), the winter flounder. See Flounder, and Dab.-- Mud dauber (Zoöl.), a mud wasp.-- Mud devil (Zoöl.), the fellbender.-- Mud drum (Steam Boilers), a drum beneath a boiler, into whichsediment and mud in the water can settle for removal.-- Mud eel (Zoöl.), a long, slender, aquatic amphibian (Sirenlacertina), found in the Southern United States. It has persistentexternal gills and only the anterior pair of legs. See Siren.-- Mud frog (Zoöl.), a European frog (Pelobates fuscus).-- Mud hen. (Zoöl.) (a) The American coot (Fulica Americana). (b)The clapper rail.-- Mud lark, a person who cleans sewers, or delves in mud. [Slang] -- Mud minnow (Zoöl.), any small American fresh-water fish of thegenus Umbra, as U. limi. The genus is allied to the pickerels.-- Mud plug, a plug for stopping the mudhole of a boiler.-- Mud puppy (Zoöl.), the menobranchus.-- Mud scow, a heavy scow, used in dredging; a mud boat. [U.S.] --Mud turtle, Mud tortoise (Zoöl.), any one of numerous species offresh-water tortoises of the United States.-- Mud wasp (Zoöl.), any one of numerous species of hymenopterousinsects belonging to Pepæus, and allied genera, which constructgroups of mud cells, attached, side by side, to stones or to thewoodwork of buildings, etc. The female places an egg in each cell,together with spiders or other insects, paralyzed by a sting, toserve as food for the larva. Called also mud dauber.
The legs; as, to stir one's stumps. [Slang]
An honorary title given to officers of high rank in Turkey, asto governers of provinces, military commanders, etc. The earlier formwas bashaw. [Written also pacha.]
Yet. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To rip; to cut open. Bacon.
The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness andindependence of function, in distinction from the morphologicalindividual or morphon.
One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of aflower. See Corolla, and Illust. of Flower.
To skulk; to cower. See Mich.
A rod or stick used by masons in mixing hair with mortar.
See Nouch. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To decorate with fringe or embroidery. "Nature's cradle moreenchased and purled." B. Jonson.
imp. of Sweat. Thomson.
Suitable to be taken as a model or pattern; as, a model house;a model husband.
Customary; ordinary; -- applied to the usual English spelling,in distinction from strictly phonetic methods. H Sweet.-- n.

A self-evident and necessary truth, or a proposition whosetruth is so evident as first sight that no reasoning or demonstrationcan make it plainer; a proposition which it is necessary to take forgranted; as, "The whole is greater than a part;" "A thing can not, atthe same time, be and not be."
An exclamation, expressive of surprise, pity, complaint,entreaty, contempt, threatening, delight, triumph, etc., according tothe manner of utterance.
An exclamation of contempt.

Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphexand allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to thethorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp, under Sand.Sphex fly (Zoöl.), any one of numerous species of small dipterousflies of the genus Conops and allied genera. The form of the body issimilar to that of a sphex.
To keep within limits; to restain; to cause to stop, or cease;to stint.Then would he weep, he might not be stent. Chaucer.Yet n'ould she stent Her bitter railing and foul revilement. Spenser.

In a full manner or degree; completely; entirely; without lackor defect; adequately; satisfactorily; as, to be fully persuaded ofthe truth of a proposition. Fully committed (Law), committed toprison for trial, in distinction from being detained for examination.
p. p. of Fare, v. i. Chaucer.
Like a pipe; hollow-stemmed. Keats.
Neat cattle. [Prov. Eng.]
To free from the restraint of anything that surrounds orincloses; to let loose; to open. [Obs.]I ought . . . to unbay the current of my passion. Norris.
A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.] Grose.
Clothes; furniture; appurtenances; luggage; as, to pack orstore one's things. [Colloq.]
East. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A high, steep rock; a precipice. Cliff swallow (Zoöl.), a NorthAmerican swallow (Petrochelidon lunifrons), which builds its nestagainst cliffs; the eaves swallow.
A suffix composed of -able and the adverbial suffix -ly; as,favorably.

A planet supposed to influence one's destiny; (usually pl.) aconfiguration of the planets, supposed to influence fortune.O malignant and ill-brooding stars. Shak.Blesses his stars, and thinks it luxury. Addison.
Defensive armor formerly worn by a man at arms.

A sailing canoe of the Ladrone Islands and Malay Archipelago,having its lee side flat and its weather side like that of anordinary boat. The ends are alike. The canoe is long and narrow, andis kept from overturning by a cigar-shaped log attached to a frameextending several feet to windward. It has been called the flyingproa, and is the swiftest sailing craft known.

Not straitened as to money matters; as, the market is easy; --opposed to tight. Honors are easy (Card Playing), said when each sidehas an equal number of honors, in which case they are not counted aspoints.
The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of thosewho acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.
The upper part of a glacier, above the limit or perpetual snow.See Galcier.
The first vertebra of the neck, articulating immediately withthe skull, thus sustaining the globe of the head, whence the name.
See Painim. [Obs.] Milton.
A leopard; a panther.And more pinch-spotted make them Than pard or cat o'mountain. Shak.
An herbaceous cruciferous plant (Isatis tinctoria). It wasformerly cultivated for the blue coloring matter derived from itsleaves.

A projection beneath the breech end of a gun barrel. In thelump, In a lump, the whole together; in gross.They may buy them in the lump. Addison.-- Lump coal, coal in large lumps; -- the largest size brought fromthe mine.-- Lump sum, a gross sum without a specification of items; as, toaward a lump sum in satisfaction of all claims and damages.
An adjectival suffix, meaning made of; as in golden, leaden,wooden.
The bitter vetch (Ervum Ervilia).

A variety of the domestic dog, usually having large, droopingears, esp. one which hunts game by scent, as the foxhound,bloodhound, deerhound, but also used for various breeds of fleethunting dogs, as the greyhound, boarhound, etc.Hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs. Shak.
Indicating, or pertaining to, some mode of conceivingexistence, or of expressing thought.
Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente.
The whole axial portion of an animal, including the head, neck,trunk, and tail. B. G. Wilder.
The symbol under which Sakti, or the personification of thefemale power in nature, is worshiped. Cf. Lingam.
Characterized by exessive brevity; short; rudely concise; as,curt limits; a curt answer.The curt, yet comprehensive reply. W. Irving.
To break; to violate. [Obs.] Shak.
p. p. of Kythe.
To lead off in delivering (the ball).
A suffix with the same meaning as -ide. See -ide. [Obs.]
To banish or expel from one's own country or home; to driveaway. "Exiled from eternal God." Tennyson.Calling home our exiled friends abroad. Shak.
A little; a bit, as of space, time, or distance. [Obs. orScot.]
Straw. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Union knitting; texture. Shak.
imp. of Get. [Obs.]
To untwist; to unravel, as the end of a rope. Johnson.
A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to ahawk's legs.

The crowned gibbon (Hylobates pileatus), native of Siam,Southern China, and the Island of Hainan. It is entirely arboreal inits habits, and has very long arms. the males are dark brown orblackish, with a caplike mass of long dark hair, and usually with awhite band around the face. The females are yellowish white, with adark spot on the breast and another on the crown. Called also wooyen,and wooyen ape.

Limitation; abridgment. Burrill. Estate in tail, a limited,abridged, or reduced fee; an estate limited to certain heirs, andfrom which the other heirs are precluded; -- called also estate tail.Blackstone.
Weight. [Obs.]
A shallow porus cup, used in refining precious metals, commonlymade of bone ashes (phosphate of lime). [Written also coppel.] Cupeldust, powder used in purifying metals.
A bone of the human body which was supposed by certainRabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter ofdispute. Brande & C.
pertaining to, or obtained from, rue (Ruta); as, rutic acid,now commonly called capric acid.
imp. of Slay.
To mingle; to mix. [Obs.]
A kind of ornamental firework. Farrow.
The black howler of Central America (Mycetes villosus).
A stripe of color.
Bereft. Chaucer.
The lapwing. [Prov. Eng.]
A genus of sea birds including the booby and the common gannet.
A yeoman. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A bank; a dike. [Obs.] Sir W. Temple.
A slow unwieldy trading vessel. [Obs.] [Written also crayer,cray, and craie.] Shak.

Any animal of the hog kind, especially one of the domesticalspecies. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat, which,when extracted, is known as lard. The male is specifically calledboar, the female, sow, and the young, pig. See Hog. "A great herd ofswine." Mark v. 11. Swine grass (Bot.), knotgrass (Polygonumaviculare); -- so called because eaten by swine.-- Swine oat (Bot.), a kind of oat sometimes grown for swine.-- Swine's cress (Bot.), a species of cress of the genus Senebiera(S. Coronopus).-- Swine's head, a dolt; a blockhead. [Obs.] Chaucer.-- Swine thistle (Bot.), the sow thistle.
See Leveful. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A fine-grained sedimentary rock of a thin, laminated, and oftenfriable, structure. Bituminous shale. See under Bituminous.
A South American rodent (Myopotamus coypus), allied to thebeaver. It produces a valuable fur called nutria. [Written alsocoypou.]
All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to performtogether. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
A cage for hawks; a mew. See 4th Mew, 1. Milman.
One of the peculiar stinging, cells found in Coelenterata; anematocyst; a lasso cell.
Home. [Scot. & O. Eng.]
A changeling or elf child, -- that is, one left by fairies; adeformed or foolish child; a simpleton; an oaf. [Obs.] Drayton.
To thrust some pointed instrument into; to prick with somethingsharp; as, to prod a soldier with a bayonet; to prod oxen; hence, togoad, to incite, to worry; as, to prod a student. H. Taylor.
A kind of millet. See Durra.

A block of wood let into a wall, to afford a hold for nails.Fire plug, a street hydrant to which hose may be attached. [U. S.] --Hawse plug (Naut.), a plug to stop a hawse hole.-- Plug and feather. (Stone Working) See Feather, n., 7.-- Plug centerbit, a centerbit ending in a small cylinder instead ofa point, so as to follow and enlarge a hole previously made, or toform a counterbore around it.-- Plug rod (Steam Eng.) , a rod attached to the beam for workingthe valves, as in the Cornish engine.-- Plug valve (Mech.), a tapering valve, which turns in a case likethe plug of a faucet.
Tricky; deceptive; contemptible; as, a snide lawyer; snidegoods. [Slang]
To settle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one uponthe form a piece of armor.
Hastily. [Prov. Eng.]
imp. & p. p. Shoot.

Caries of the vertebræ, frequently resulting in curvature ofthe spine and paralysis of the lower extremities; -- so named fromPercival Pott, an English surgeon. Pott's fracture, a fracture of thelower end of the fibula, with displacement of the tibia. Dunglison.
Directly; exactly; as, a due east course.
A decree of the Sultan.
The lapwing; the wipe; -- so called from its cry.
A vessel for holding ale or wine; a jug. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A place where ships may ride at anchor at some distance fromthe shore; a roadstead; -- often in the plural; as, Hampton Roads.Shak.
A petty falling out; a tiff; a quarrel; offense. Fielding.
Resembling lead. Sir T. Elyot.

Pious; reverencing God, and his character and laws; obedient tothe commands of God from love for, and reverence of, his character;conformed to God's law; devout; righteous; as, a godly life.For godly sorrow worketh repentance. 2 Cor. vii. 10.
The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to allparts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterialsystem.
A thicket; a small wood. "Through bosk and dell." Sir W. Scott.
To twinkle. [Obs.]
A region; country. [Obs.] "The plages of the north." Chaucer.
Any one of numerous species of small, fresh-water, chætopodannelids of the tribe Naidina. They belong to the Oligochæta.
Curved arms of timber or iron, projecting over a ship's side ofstern, having tackle to raise or lower a boat, swing it in on deck,rig it out for lowering, etc.; -- called also boat davits. Totten.
A var. spelling of Coin, Quoin, a corner, wedge; -- chieflyused in the phrase coign of vantage, a position advantageous foraction or observation.
A vessel carried on a pole between two persons, for conveyanceof water. Johnson.
Wake.
To vault; to leap. [Obs.] Spenser.

To invert a type of the same thickness, as temporary substitutefor any sort which is exhausted. To turn about, to face to anotherquarter; to turn around.-- To turn again, to come back after going; to return. Shak.-- To turn against, to become unfriendly or hostile to.-- To turn aside or away. (a) To turn from the direct course; towithdraw from a company; to deviate. (b) To depart; to remove. (c) Toavert one's face.-- To turn back, to turn so as to go in an opposite direction; toretrace one's steps.-- To turn in. (a) To bend inward. (b) To enter for lodgings orentertainment. (c) To go to bed. [Colloq.] -- To turn into, to enterby making a turn; as, to turn into a side street.-- To turn off, to be diverted; to deviate from a course; as, theroad turns off to the left.-- To turn on or upon. (a) To turn against; to confront in hostilityor anger. (b) To reply to or retort. (c) To depend on; as, the resultturns on one condition.-- To turn out. (a) To move from its place, as a bone. (b) To bendor point outward; as, his toes turn out. (c) To rise from bed.[Colloq.] (d) To come abroad; to appear; as, not many turned out tothe fire. (e) To prove in the result; to issue; to result; as, thecropsturned out poorly.-- To turn over, to turn from side to side; to roll; to tumble.-- To turn round. (a) To change position so as to face in anotherdirection. (b) To change one's opinion; to change from one view orparty to another.-- To turn to, to apply one's self to; have recourse to; to referto. "Helvicus's tables may be turned to on all occasions." Locke.-- To turn to account, profit, advantage, or the like, to be madeprofitable or advantageous; to become worth the while.-- To turn under, to bend, or be folded, downward or under.-- To turn up. (a) To bend, or be doubled, upward. (b) To appear; tocome to light; to transpire; to occur; to happen.
The coarse, strong fiber of the East Indian Corchorusolitorius, and C. capsularis; also, the plant itself. The fiber ismuch used for making mats, gunny cloth, cordage, hangings, paper,etc.
See Lepidosiren.
To guess. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A person whose intellectual development proceeds normally up toabout the eighth year of age and is then arrested so that there islittle or no further development.
To better; to mend. See Beete. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Brun, a brook. [Scot.]
Enormous. [Obs.] Spenser.
A root. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A member of the most prominent tribe of the Moro tribes,occupying the Sulu Archipelago; also, their language.
Robbery. [Obs. or Scot.]
To wet or moisten. Gay.
Relating to a type or types; belonging to types; serving as atype; typical. Owen.
The condition of being sulky; a sulky mood or humor; as, to bein the sulks.

A liquid food of many kinds, usually made by boiling meat andvegetables, or either of them, in water, -- commonly seasoned orflavored; strong broth. Soup kitchen, an establishment for preparingand supplying soup to the poor.-- Soup ticket, a ticket conferring the privilege of receiving soupat a soup kitchen.
See Cozen.
A kind of worm or larva. Walton.
An ordinary with its ends cut off, borne sinister as a mark ofbastardy, and containing one fourth in breadth of the bend sinister;-- called also bastard bar. See Bend sinister.
A cereal grass (Triticum vulgare) and its grain, whichfurnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grainmost largely used by the human race.
See Gypsy.
See Sace.
Urine. [Prov. Eng.]
The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory throughwhich the fused glass is taken out. Craig.
Calculated to arrest attention; ostentatiously fashionable;showy. [Colloq.]
A fabric made of silk or wool, or of silk and wool, and havinga transversely corded or ribbed surface.
A goddess. [Obs.] Croft.
To give. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Woe. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder,Frigg, and the others. Their home was called Asgard.
To raise. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal orrightful title, whether he is the possessor or not. Shak.
See -or.
A solution in water of a gaseous or readily volatile substance;as, ammonia water. U. S. Pharm.
To ask; to inquire or inquire of.
See Myope.

A prefix used to signify around, by, near, over, beyond, or togive an intensive sense; as, perimeter, the measure around; perigee,point near the earth; periergy, work beyond what is needed;perispherical, quite spherical.
Of great bulk or dimensions; of great size; large; thick;massive; as, bulky volumes.A bulky digest of the revenue laws. Hawthorne.
Any jager gull; especially, the Megalestris skua; -- calledalso boatswain.
The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parableof the "Rich Man and Lazarus" (Luke xvi. 19-31). Hence, a name for arich worldling.
Originally, the highest note in the scale of Guido; hence,proverbially, any extravagant saying. "Why, this is above E-la!"Beau. & Fl.
A reduction in size near the end of an object, formed by agroove around it; as, a neck forming the journal of a shaft.
Of a dull yellowish brown color, like things tanned, or personswho are sunburnt; as, tawny Moor or Spaniard; the tawny lion. "Aleopard's tawny and spotted hide." Longfellow.
Complete measure; utmost extent; the highest state or degree.The swan's-down feather, That stands upon the swell at full of tide.Shak.Full of the moon, the time of full moon.
Gear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Without contents; empty; void of sense or intelligence;purposeless; pointless; characterless; useless. "Vague and inaneinstincts." I. Taylor.-- In*ane"ly, adv.
To give obedience.Will he obey when one commands Tennyson.
A composing stick. See under Composing. It is usually a frameof metal, but for posters, handbills, etc., one made of wood is used.
Same as Shiite.
Of or relating to the front or forward part; having a positionin front; foremost; as, a front view.
A legislative or administrative assembly in Germany, Poland,and some other countries of Europe; a deliberative convention; acouncil; as, the Diet of Worms, held in 1521.
Apparel. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The rump of beef; esp., the lower and back part of the rump.Natch bone, the edgebone, or aitchbone, in beef.
An iron bucket for hoisting coal or ore. Raymond.
To answer a defendant's plea.
A great collection of ore without any vein coming into it orgoing out from it.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow orcourtesy.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and OldPrussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
To cough faintly and frequently, or in a short, broken manner;as, a hacking cough.
One of the divisions of a pinnate part or organ.
To know; to understand. [Obs.]To skill the arts of expressing our mind. Barrow.
To stum. [R.]
To look narrowly or curiously or intently; to peep; as, thepeering day. Milton.Peering in maps for ports, and piers, and roads. Shak.As if through a dungeon grate he peered. Coleridge.
To extol in psalms; to sing; as, psalming his praises.Sylvester.

To strike, thrust, or hit violently with the foot; as, a horsekicks a groom; a man kicks a dog.He [Frederick the Great] kicked the shins of his judges. Macaulay.To kick the beam, to fit up and strike the beam; -- said of thelighter arm of a loaded balance; hence, to be found wanting inweight. Milton.-- To kick the bucket, to lose one's life; to die. [Colloq. & Low]
See Mosque.
A narrow inlet of the sea, penetrating between high banks orrocks, as on the coasts of Norway and Alaska. [Written also fjord.]
That which is laid; a stratum; a bed; one thickness, course, orfold laid over another; as, a layer of clay or of sand in the earth;a layer of bricks, or of plaster; the layers of an onion.
A word used as a shout of joy, exultation, approbation, orencouragement.
A shard or fragment. [Obs.]
The snuff, or burnt wick, of a candle. [Obs.] Bacon.

That by which anything is made known or represented; that whichfurnishes evidence; a mark; a token; an indication; a proof.Specifically:(a) A remarkable event, considered by the ancients as indicating thewill of some deity; a prodigy; an omen.(b) An event considered by the Jews as indicating the divine will, oras manifesting an interposition of the divine power for some specialend; a miracle; a wonder.Through mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God.Rom. xv. 19.It shall come to pass, if they will not believe thee, neither hearkento the voice of the first sign, that they will believe the voice ofthe latter sign. Ex. iv. 8.
To deduce logically, as conclusions. [Obs.] Hewyt.
A blotch or spot of ink on a printed page, caused by the inknot being properly distributed. It is distinguished from a friar, orwhite spot caused by a deficiency of ink.
Resembling a dew-covered surface; appearing as if covered withdew.
To furnish with a rim; to border.
Thrush. [Local, U.S.]
A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated withsalts, whence the name.
Having the form or the use of an oar; as, the swan's oary feet.Milton. Addison.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Have.
An East Indian insectivore (Tupaia ferruginea). It is arborealin its habits, and has a bushy tail. The fur is soft, and varies fromrusty red to maroon and to brownish black.
To inherit; to succeed to. [R.]One only daughter heired the royal state. Dryden.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhoodoccupied by anchorites who were under the same superior. C. Kingsley.
In the most general sense, indicating that in consideration of,in view of, or with reference to, which anything is done or takesplace.
A pike when full grown. Halliwell.
The privet.
The grand adversary of man; The Devil, or Prince of darkness;the chief of the fallen angels; the archfiend.I beheld Satan as lightning fall from heaven. Luke x. 18.
See Warye. [Obs.]
Having a rind [Obs.] Milton.
An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet. [Obs.] Holland.
A small European lamprey (Petromyzon branchialis); -- calledalso prid, and sandpiper.
To rise in blisters, breaking in white froth, as cane juice inthe clarifiers in sugar works.
Invocation of evil spirits; witchcraft. [Obs.] Hallywell.
A style of painting, sculpture, or other imitative art, whichillustrates everyday life and manners.
A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially toringworm. See Ringworm, and Sycosis.
Disposed to rest; indisposed toexercton; sluggish; also,restive. [Obs.] Burton.Where the master is too resty or too rich to say his own prayers.Milton.
, 2d pers. sing. pres. of. Fave, contr. of havest. [Archaic]
A diminutive of Ann or Anne, the proper name. Nanny goat, afemale goat. [Colloq.]
Silent; not speaking. Thackeray.The citizens are mum, and speak not a word. Shak.
Coupled; paired. Bars gemel (Her.), two barrulets placed nearand parallel to each other.
Since; seeing. [Scot.]
Jade.
A projecting ornament in carved stone. Specifically, a finial.[Obs.]
A colloquial abbreviation of midshipman.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.]

A more or less musical sound made by many of the lower animals.See Stridulation. Magic music, a game in which a person is guided infinding a hidden article, or in doing a specific art required, bymusic which is made more loud or rapid as he approaches success, andslower as he recedes. Tennyson.-- Music box. See Musical box, under Musical.-- Music hall, a place for public musical entertainments.-- Music loft, a gallery for musicians, as in a dancing room or achurch.-- Music of the spheres, the harmony supposed to be produced by theaccordant movement of the celestial spheres.-- Music paper, paper ruled with the musical staff, for the use ofcomposers and copyists.-- Music pen, a pen for ruling at one time the five lines of themusical staff.-- Music shell (Zoöl.), a handsomely colored marine gastropod shell(Voluta musica) found in the East Indies; -- so called because thecolor markings often resemble printed music. Sometimes applied toother shells similarly marked.-- To face the music, to meet any disagreeable necessity withoutflinching. [Colloq. or Slang]
An exclamation of abhorrence or contempt; poh; fle. Shak.
Not to will; to refuse; to reject. [Obs.]Certes, said he, I nill thine offered grace. Spenser.
Of no legal force or effect, incapable of confirmation orratification; null. Cf. Voidable, 2. Void space (Physics), a vacuum.
Nap or down; flue; soft, downy feathers.
Pomp, show, or festivity. Macaulay. Gala day, a day of mirthand festivity; a holiday.
To hoard. [Obs.] Donne.
pl. of Toe. Chaucer.
To wit; that is; namely.
A slice of beef, broiled, or cut for broiling; -- also extendedto the meat of other large animals; as, venison steak; bear steak;pork steak; turtle steak.
An assart, or clearing. [Obs.] Bailey.
Neighborhood; vicinity; venue. See Venue.
The wild ass of Persia.
To yawn; to gape. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The East Indian name for the large spiral shell of severalspecies of sea conch much used in making bangles, esp. Turbinellapyrum. Called also chank chell.

A quadrumanous mammal, esp. of the family Simiadæ, having teethof the same number and form as in man, having teeth of the samenumber and form as in man, and possessing neither a tail nor cheekpouches. The name is applied esp. to species of the genus Hylobates,and is sometimes used as a general term for all Quadrumana. Thehigher forms, the gorilla, chimpanzee, and ourang, are often calledanthropoid apes or man apes.
A flattish or convex flower cluster, of the centrifugal ordeterminate type, differing from a corymb chiefly in the order of theopening of the blossoms.
The blindworm.
In a sly manner; shrewdly; craftily.Honestly and slyly he it spent. Chaucer.

A native of the Caribbee islands or the coaste of the Caribbeansea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of SouthAmerica, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West Indiaislands.
The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the nativesas sacred.
See Here, pron. Chaucer.
The Poland marmot (Arctomys bobac).
Roast. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To cause to pass away pleasantly or without irksomeness ordisgust; to spend or pass; -- usually followed by away.The lovely lady whiled the hours away. Longfellow.
See Endow.
Craft; deceitful cunning; artifice; duplicity; wile; deceit;treachery.Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile. John i. 47.To wage by force or guile eternal war. Milton.

An eel-like marine marsipobranch (Myxine glutinosa), allied tothe lamprey. It has a suctorial mouth, with labial appendages, and asingle pair of gill openings. It is the type of the orderHyperotpeta. Called also hagfish, borer, slime eel, sucker, andsleepmarken.
Major; in the major mode; as, C dur, that is, C major.
Fated; doomed. [Old Eng. & Scot.]
A sheave. [R.]

To wither; to fade; also, to decay; to decline; to wane. [Obs.]When ruddy Phwelk in west. Spenser.The church, that before by insensible degrees welked and impaired,now with large steps went down hill decaying. Milton.
A claw. See Chela. [Obs.]
Sullenly; threateningly; maliciously; so as to produceblackness.
A splinter or fragment, as of wood or stone. See Spall.
Ware; aware. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH; -- called also cetylic alcohol.See Cetylic alcohol, under Cetylic.

Happening, or belonging to, each successive day; diurnal; as,daily labor; a daily bulletin.Give us this day our daily bread. Matt. vi. 11.Bunyan has told us . . . that in New England his dream was the dailysubject of the conversation of thousands. Macaulay.
Same as Ixtle.
A kind of minuet, in triple time, of French origin, popular inthe reign of Queen Elizabeth and for some time after; -- called alsopassing measure, and passymeasure. Percy Smith.
To make lame.If you happen to let child fall and lame it. Swift.
Relating to the jaws. Gayton.
To break or fly off in small pieces.
On or at the top. Milton.
The person who makes a promissory note.
To recant or recall, as what has been said; to refract; to takeback again; to make as if not said.You can say and unsay things at pleasure. Goldsmith.
A two-footed animal, as man.
A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plungedhis forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called bythemselves . [Written also Cymri, Cwmry, Kymry, etc.]
A genus of malvaceous plants common in the tropics. All thespecies are mucilaginous, and some have tough ligneous fibers whichare used as a substitute for hemp and flax. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
A great quantity or number. [Prov. Eng.]There was a mort of merrymaking. Dickens.

A carnivorous animal of the genus Vulpes, family Canidæ, ofmany species. The European fox (V. vulgaris or V. vulpes), theAmerican red fox (V. fulvus), the American gray fox (V. Virginianus),and the arctic, white, or blue, fox (V. lagopus) are well-knownspecies.
See Muse, and Muset.
A game of guessing the number of fingers extended in a quickmovement of the hand, -- much played by Italians of the lowerclasses.
A sip or small draught; esp., a draught of intoxicating liquor;a dram.

A rope or long thong of leather with, a running noose, used forcatching horses, cattle, etc. Lasso cell (Zoöl.), one of a peculiarkind of defensive and offensive stinging cells, found in greatnumbers in all coelenterates, and in a few animals of other groups.They are most highly developed in the tentacles of jellyfishes,hydroids, and Actiniæ. Each of these cells is filled with, fluid, andcontains a long, slender, often barbed, hollow thread coiled upwithin it. When the cell contracts the thread is quickly ejected,being at the same time turned inside out. The thread is able topenetrate the flesh of various small, soft-bodied animals, andcarries a subtle poison by which they are speedily paralyzed andkilled. The threads, at the same time, hold the prey in position,attached to the tentacles. Some of the jellyfishes, as the Portugueseman-of-war, and Cyanea, are able to penetrate the human skin, andinflict painful stings in the same way. Called also nettling cell,cnida, cnidocell.
Red. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The upper part or top of a mansard roof or curb roof when madenearly flat.
To crowd; to press together.
The mouth. [Obs.]One a penny, two a penny, hot cross buns, Butter them and sugar themand put them in your muns. Old Rhyme. Halliwell.
All; wholly; completely; as, almighty,almost. (b) Etym: [L.ad.]
To inclose, as in a mew or cage. [R.] "Inmew the town below."Beau. & Fl.
To lop; to trim; to prune; to adorn. [Obs.] Chaucer.The sprigs that did about it grow He proined from the leafy arms.Chapman.

The three goddesses, Clotho, Lachesis, and Atropos, sometimescalled the Destinies, or Parcæwho were supposed to determine thecourse of human life. They are represented, one as holding thedistaff, a second as spinning, and the third as cutting off thethread.
imp. of Slee, to slay. Slew. Chaucer.

Anciently, one to whom lands were given; in later use, one towhom lands and tenements are given in tail; in modern use, one onwhom a power is conferred for execution; -- sometimes called theappointor.
To grow better; to advance to a better state; to becomeimproved. Shak.
A vagrant; an idle, sturdy beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
Jumping, or inducing to jump; characterized by jumps; hence,extremely nervous.
A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indianzinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.
A subordinate; a subaltern. [Colloq.]
To enter into the conjugal or connubial state; to take ahusband or a wife.I will, therefore, that the younger women marry. 1 Tim. v. 14.Marrrying man, a man disposed to marry. [Colloq.]
A medusa, or jellyfish. [R.]The jellied quarl that flings At once a thousand streaming stings. J.R. Drake.
2d pers. sing. of Will.
A heap. See Tas. [Obs.]  Chaucer.
One of certain small prominences on the hind part of the faceof an elephant's tooth.

To grant; to acknowledge; to admit to be true; to confess; torecognize in a particular character; as, we own that we haveforfeited your love.The wakeful bloodhound rose, and shook his hide owns. Keats.
Ill luck; misfortune. [Obs.] "The cause of her unhap." Sir P.Sidney.
That portion of the real estate of a man which his widow enjoysduring her life, or to which a woman is entitled after the death ofher husband. Blackstone.
A contagious disease of horses, associated with painfululcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of thesame nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin, andfarcimen.
The handle of a joiner's plane. Knight.
A thong of soft leather to bind up a hawk's wing.
Of or pertaining to Cuba or its inhabitants.-- n.
A privy or jakes. [Obs.] Chaucer. Gong farmer, Gong man, acleaner of privies. [Obs.]
In a shy or timid manner; not familiarly; with reserve.[Written also shily.]
The Dragon, a northern constellation within which is the northpole of the ecliptic.

An elementary substance found as an oxide in the mineralcassiterite, and reduced as a soft white crystalline metal, malleableat ordinary temperatures, but brittle when heated. It is not easilyoxidized in the air, and is used chiefly to coat iron to protect itfrom rusting, in the form of tin foil with mercury to form thereflective surface of mirrors, and in solder, bronze, speculum metal,and other alloys. Its compounds are designated as stannous, orstannic. Symbol Sn (Stannum). Atomic weight 117.4.
Having a nose, or such a nose; -- chieflay used in composition;as, pug-nosed.
Toward the outside or surface; -- opposed to entad. B. G.Wilder.
Strong; powerful; fierce. [Obs.] -- Derf"ly, adv. [Obs.]
A woman's breast. [Low]
A thick, ill-shapen piece; a clumsy leaden counter used by boysin playing chuck farthing. [Eng.] Smart.
To be astounded. [Archaic] B. Taylor.

A cloth used for wiping, especially one used for dryinganything wet, as the person after a bath. Towel gourd (Bot.), thefruit of the cucurbitaceous plant Luffa Ægyptiaca; also, the plantitself. The fruit is very fibrous, and, when separated from its rindand seeds, is used as a sponge or towel. Called also Egyptian bathsponge, and dishcloth.
A Peruvian name for certain species of Oxalis (O. crenata, andO. tuberosa) which bear edible tubers.
Disorder; merriment. [Obs.]
Same as Lawe, v. t. [Obs.]

True; real; actual; veritable.Whether thou be my very son Esau or not. Gen. xxvii. 21.He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeatetha matter separateth very friends. Prov. xvii. 9.The very essence of truth is plainness and brightness. Milton.I looked on the consideration of public service or public ornament tobe real and very justice. Burke.
The Egyptian sycamore (Ficus Sycamorus). See Sycamore.
Same as Strew.Thick as autumnal leaves that strow the brooks In Vallombrosa.Milton.A manner turbid . . . and strown with blemished. M. Arnold.
A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.

To hide, or get out of the way, in a sneaking manner; to lieclose, or to move in a furtive way; to lurk. "Want skulks in holesand crevices." W. C. Bryant.Discovered and defeated of your prey, You skulked behind the fence,and sneaked away. Dryden.
A leash. [Obs.]
A state of profound insensibility from which it is difficult orimpossible to rouse a person. See Carus.
The general appearance and manner of life of a living organism.
To place or fix firmly or permanently. [Obs.] Shak.
The air bladder of a fish; as, cod sounds are an esteemedarticle of food.
To render useless or void; to annul; to reject; to send away.[Obs.] Sir W. Raleing.
A genus of fresh-water fishes, including pike and pickerel.
variant of Dere, v. t. & n. [Obs.]

A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by theNord American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or aclan.And they painted on the grave posts Of the graves, yet unforgotten,Each his own ancestral totem Each the symbol of his household;Figures of the bear and reindeer, Of the turtle, crane, and beaver.Longfellow.The totem,the clan deity, the beast or bird who in some supernaturalway attends tothe clan and watches over it. Bagehot.
The 3d pers. sing. pres. of Do.
obs. imp. of Read, or Rede. Chaucer.
The interval embracing six diatonic degrees of the scale.
One who, or that which, plies; specifically: (a) pl.

The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on theback. They are generally white. Among the best known species are theAmerican egret (Ardea, or Herodias, egretta); the great egret (A.alba); the little egret (A. garzetta), of Europe; and the Americansnowy egret (A. candidissima).A bunch of egrets killed for their plumage. G. W. Cable.
Nimble; quick; swift. [Obs.] See Fleet.
A lay; a German song. It differs from the French chanson, andthe Italian canzone, all three being national.The German Lied is perhaps the most faithful reflection of thenational sentiment. Grove.
Good form; style. [Slang]
Easy. [Obs.] Spenser.
A small bag; a wallet; a satchel. [Archaic] Chaucer.And in requital ope his leathern scrip. Milton.

The male of bovine quadrupeds, especially the domestic animalwhen castrated and grown to its full size, or nearly so. The word isalso applied, as a general name, to any species of bovine animals,male and female.All sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field. Ps. viii. 7.
A deception for mockery or mischief; a deceptive trick orstory; a practical joke. Macaulay.
To swell; to puff out, as with weeping. [Obs.]

A small shrill pipe, resembling the piccolo flute, used chieflyto accompany the drum in military music. Fife major (Mil.), anoncommissioned officer who superintends the fifers of a regiment.-- Fife rail. (Naut.) (a) A rail about the mast, at the deck, tohold belaying pins, etc. (b) A railing around the break of a poopdeck.

A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle;-- called also rhumb line, and loxodromic curve. See Loxodromic. Tosail on a rhumb, to sail continuously on one course, following arhumb line.
A light, liquid food, made by boiling meal of maize, oatmeal,or fiour in water or milk; thin porridge.
A cupola formed on a large scale.
An awl. [Obs.] usser.
A swing. [Local, U.S.]
