An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value.The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas.
A mound of earth in which potatoes and other vegetables arestored for protection against frost; -- called also burrow and pie.[Prov. Eng.]
To discharge through pores or incisions, as moisture or otherliquid matter; to give out.Our forests exude turpentine in . . . abundance. Dr. T. Dwight.
To move (a vessel) by carrying out a kedge in a boat, droppingit overboard, and hauling the vessel up to it.
Same as Tyro.
See Stee.

A bent portion of an axle, or shaft, or an arm keyed at rightangles to the end of a shaft, by which motion is imparted to orreceived from it; also used to change circular into reciprocatingmotion, or reciprocating into circular motion. See Bell crank.
An exclamation expressing delight.
To struggle in extreme pain; to be in agony; to agonize.
A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle formedicines; a vial.
See Byssus, n., 1.
A command to a horse, probably meaning "stand still." [Obs.]Chaucer.

A suffix added to the names of certain numerals or to thenumerals themselves, to indicate the number of leaves made by foldinga sheet of paper; as, sixteenmo or 16mo; eighteenmo or 18mo. It istaken from the Latin forms similarly used; as, duodecimo,sextodecimo, etc. A small circle, placed after the number and nearits top, is often used for -mo; as, 16°, 18°, etc.
See Kie, Ky, and Kine. [Prov. Eng.] Gay.
See Umber.
Long live, that is, success to; as, vive le roi, long live theking; vive la bagatelle, success to trifles or sport.
See Dakotas.
A stone. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
An oilskin hat or southwester; -- a fisherman's name. [U. S.]
The dried tubers of various species of Orchis, and Eulophia. Itis used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powderedpreparation with hot water. U. S. Disp.
A small scarlet arachnid.
A man. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
Bereft.Reft of thy sons, amid thy foes forlorn. Heber.

A large American carnivore (Felis concolor), found from Canadato Patagonia, especially among the mountains. Its color is tawny, orbrownish yellow, without spots or stripes. Called also catamount,cougar, American lion, mountain lion, and panther or painter.
A celebrated fairy, "the merry wanderer of the night;" --called also Robin Goodfellow, Friar Rush, Pug, etc. Shak.He meeteth Puck, whom most men call Hobgoblin, and on him doth fall.Drayton.

Bright; glittering; radiant; fair; showy; sheeny. [R., exceptin poetry.]This holy maiden, that is so bright and sheen. Chaucer.Up rose each warrier bold and brave, Glistening in filed steel andarmor sheen. Fairfax.
Resembling a bag; loose or puffed out, or pendent, like a bag;flabby; as, baggy trousers; baggy cheeks.
Same as Scissel, 2.
The higher part of the scale. See Alto. To be in alt, to be inan exalted state of mind.
Like a runt; diminutive; mean.
Filled with white flakes; mothery; -- said vinegar whencontaining mother. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Consisting of fur. [Obs.]
The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter edh, capital form th in asimilar word: oedher, other, dôedh, doth." March.
Deftly. [Obs.] Spenser.
A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th centuryand later.
Work varnished and figured in the Japanese manner; also, thevarnish or lacquer used in japanning.

To swallow eagerly, or in large draughts; to swallow up; totake down at one swallow.He does not swallow, but he gulps it down. Cowper.The old man . . . glibly gulped down the whole narrative. Fielding.To gulp up, to throw up from the stomach; to disgorge.

A light canoe, made of skins stretched over a frame, andusually capable of carrying but one person, who sits amidships anduses a double-bladed paddle. It is peculiar to the Eskimos and otherArctic tribes.
Same as Knop,2. Milman.

A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2, which isobtained from certain lichens (Roccella, Lecanora, etc.), also fromextract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives oftoluene. It changes readily into orcein.
See Troll.
Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as thehead of the Shinto religion.
Abounding in sap; resembling, or consisting lagerly of,sapwood.
The condition of being stunned.
One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws,or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of mostvertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and masticationof food.
The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probablythe wild goat of the Bible.
To cause to be unbegotten or unborn, or as if unbegotten orunborn. [R.]I 'll disown you, I 'll disinherit you, I 'll unget you. Sheridan.

The whole machinery and apparatus employed in carrying on atrade or mechanical business; also, sometimes including real estate,and whatever represents investment of capital in the means ofcarrying on a business, but not including material worked upon orfinished products; as, the plant of a foundry, a mill, or a railroad.
The territory governed by a ban.
The ring which turns inward and condenses the flame of a lamp.Knight.
A live coal. See Gleed. [Archaic]
A Russian village community. D. M. Wallace.

A kind of prison; a building for the confinement of personsheld in lawful custody, especially for minor offenses or withreference to some future judicial proceeding. [Written also gaol.]This jail I count the house of liberty. Milton.Jail bird, a prisoner; one who has been confined in prison. [Slang] -- Jail delivery, the release of prisoners from jail, either legallyor by violence.-- Jail delivery commission. See under Gaol.-- Jail fever (Med.), typhus fever, or a disease resembling it,generated in jails and other places crowded with people; -- calledalso hospital fever, and ship fever.-- Jail liberties, or Jail limits, a space or district around a jailwithin which an imprisoned debtor was, on certain conditions, allowedto go at large. Abbott.-- Jail lock, a peculiar form of padlock; -- called alsoScandinavian lock.
Soft; sticky, and dirty. [Prov. Eng.] See Mucky.
Grossly; greasily.
To grope with the hands, as in the dark. [Scot.] To glaum at,to grasp or snatch at; to aspire to.Wha glaum'd at kingdoms three. Burns.
A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur.It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.
A small brass Venetian coin. [Obs.]
See Rind. [Obs.] Spenser.
A vessel with a very narrow stern; -- called also pinky. Sir W.Scott. Pink stern (Naut.), a narrow stern.
See Spunk.
To stoop by bending the knees; to crouch; to squat; hence, toquail; to sink through fear.Our dame sits cowering o'er a kitchen fire. Dryden.Like falcons, cowering on the nest. Goldsmith.
The neutral compound formed by the union of an acid base; thus,sulphuric acid and iron form the salt sulphate of iron or greenvitriol.
The leaves and tops of vegetables, as of potatoes, turnips,etc. [Scot.] Jamieson.
imp. & p. p. of Sky, v. t.
Like a plate; consisting of plates.
A Celt or the Celts of the Scotch Highlands or of Ireland; nowesp., a Scotch Highlander of Celtic origin.
Flowing.Their founts aflow with tears. R. Browning.

To change direction; to turn; to shift; as, wind veers to thewest or north. "His veering gait." Wordsworth.And as he leads, the following navy veers. Dryden.an ordinary community which is hostile or friendly as passion or asinterest may veer about. Burke.To veer and haul (Naut.), to vary the course or direction; -- said ofthe wind, which veers aft and hauls forward. The wind is also said toveer when it shifts with the sun.

The dense tissues which invest the teeth, and cover theadjacent parts of the jaws. Gum rash (Med.), strophulus in a teethingchild; red gum.-- Gum stick, a smooth hard substance for children to bite uponwhile teething.
Waste silk formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.
To suit; to be adjusted or conformable. [R.] Shak.
Same as Lory.
A kind of slow match or safety fuse.

A bridge; -- applied to several parts which connect others, butespecially to the pons Varolii, a prominent band of nervous tissuesituated on the ventral side of the medulla oblongata and connectedat each side with the hemispheres of the cerebellum; themesocephalon. See Brain. Pons asinorum. Etym: [L., literally, bridgeof asses.] See Asses' bridge, under Ass.

To be full to the brim. "The brimming stream." Milton. To brimover (literally or figuratively), to be so full that some of thecontents flows over the brim; as, cup brimming over with wine; a manbrimming over with fun.

Not held by honorable service; as, a base estate, one held byservices not honorable; held by villenage. Such a tenure is calledbase, or low, and the tenant, a base tenant. Base fee, formerly, anestate held at the will of the lord; now, a qualified fee. See noteunder Fee, n., 4.-- Base metal. See under Metal.
Worn out; common; used until so common as to have lost noveltyand interest; hackneyed; stale; as, a trite remark; a trite subject.-- Trite"ly, adv.-- Trite"ness, n.
The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within thegleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
A prefix meaning eight. See Octo-.
A servant at a hotel or elsewhere, who cleans and blacks theboots and shoes.
Skimmed. [Obs.]
the old imp. of chide. See Chide.
To cry aloud; to proclaim loudly.This last action will roar thy infamy. Ford.
See Weld.
Having a brown color tonged with red, as of flame seen throughsmoke.
A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet.
The poke (Phytolacca decandra); -- called also pocan bush.

A genus of perennial, herbaceous, endogenous plants of greatsize, including the banana (Musa sapientum), the plantain (M.paradisiaca of Linnæus, but probably not a distinct species), theAbyssinian (M. Ensete), the Philippine Island (M. textilis, whichyields Manila hemp), and about eighteen other species. See Illust. ofBanana and Plantain.
To occupy a room or rooms; to lodge; as, they arranged to roomtogether.
imp. of Throw.
To form; to fashion. [Obs.]To the more mature, A glass that feated them. Shak.
The coarse and broken part of flax or hemp, separated from thefiner part by the hatchel or swingle.
A double sulphate formed of aluminium and some other element(esp. an alkali metal) or of aluminium. It has twenty-four moleculesof water of crystallization.

The land with which a prebend or other ecclesiastical office isendowed. [Obs.]The prebendaries over and above their reserved rents have a corps.Bacon.Army corps, or (French) Corps d'armée (k, a body containing two ormore divisions of a large army, organized as a complete army initself.-- Corps de logis (ke l Etym: [F., body of the house], the principalmass of a building, considered apart from its wings.-- Corps diplomatique (k Etym: [F., diplomatic body], the body ofministers or envoys accredited to a government.
The combining form of the Greek word meaning air.
Sward. [Obs.] Holinshed.
The emperor of Russia. See Czar.
Made of boxwood; pertaining to, or resembling, the box (Buxus).[R.]The faded hue of sapless boxen leaves. Dryden.
A money of account in Goa, India, equivalent to about 2s. 6d.sterling. or 60 cts.
See Leach.
A dark shade or dark passage in a painting, engraving, or thelike; as, the light and darks are well contrasted.The lights may serve for a repose to the darks, and the darks to thelights. Dryden.
To cover (the head) with a wig. Hawthorne.
Variegated; spotted; speckled; piebald. [Prov. Eng.]

A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in thePeloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, whencut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the woundwas cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.Gorgons, and Hydras, and Chimeras dire. Milton.
The unit for estimating the weight of a
To braid. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To run about; to frisk; to whisk. [Obs.]He fisks abroad, and stirreth up erroneous opinions. Latimer.
The rotating part of a generator or motor.

A headdress of linen or woolen, that hangs down over theshoulders, worn by old women of the lower classes; -- called also toymutch. [Scot.] "Having, moreover, put on her clean toy, rokelay, andscarlet plaid." Sir W. Scott.
Jutlanders; one of the Low German tribes, a portion of whichsettled in Kent, England, in the 5th century.

A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans,etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a maincord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of variouscolors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn,soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in thesmaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used forarithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.[Written also quipo.] Tylor.The mysterious science of the quipus . . . supplied the Peruvianswith the means of communicating their ideas to one another, and oftransmitting them to future generations. Prescott.
Rank in growth. [Prov.Eng.]
A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usuallyof a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidalfracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire withsteel.
See Chine, n., 3.
A pigment formed by combining some coloring matter, usually byprecipitation, with a metallic oxide or earth, esp. with aluminiumhydrate; as, madder lake; Florentine lake; yellow lake, etc.

Before any other person or thing in time, space, rank, etc.; --much used in composition with adjectives and participles.Adam was first formed, then Eve. 1 Tim. ii. 13.At first, At the first, at the beginning or origin.-- First or last, at one time or another; at the beginning or end.And all are fools and lovers first or last. Dryden.
Industrious; active. [R.] Cowper.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.Shak.
To deter (an opponent) from taking the risk of betting on hishand of cards, as the bluffer does by betting heavily on his own handalthough it may be of less value. [U. S.]
See Sheik.
A plant of the genus Cannabis (C. sativa), the fibrous skin orbark of which is used for making cloth and cordage. The name is alsoapplied to various other plants yielding fiber.
imp. of Seethe. Chaucer.
See Copra.
A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic; a carousal.[Colloq.]
See Miter.
See Luny.
Sky-blue; resembling the clear blue color of the unclouded sky;cerulean; also, cloudless. Azure stone (Min.), the lapis lazuli;also, the lazulite.
Indian wheat, granulated but not pulverized; a kind ofsemolina. [Written also soojee.]
A gutter or channel for water, hewn out of the bottom of aworking drift. Page.
To pass by; to leave. See 1st Forego.For sith [since] I shall forgoon my liberty At your request. Chaucer.And four [days] since Florimell the court forwent. Spenser.

The original sense seems to have been a lane cut through trees.See Grave, v., and cf. Groove.] A smaller group of trees than aforest, and without underwood, planted, or growing naturally as ifarranged by art; a wood of small extent.
See Petard. [Obs.] "Hoist with his own petar." Shak.
A falsehood; a lie; -- used euphemistically.They are very serious; they don't tell fibs. H. James.
To abash; to disconcert or be disconcerted or put out ofcountenance. [Obs.]His countenance was bold and bashed not. Spenser.
To jolt; to jounce. [Obs.] Bale.

An old solfeggio name for B flat; the seventh harmonic, asheard in the or æolian string; -- so called by Tartini. It was longconsidered a false, but is the true note of the chord of the flatseventh. H. W. Poole.
See 2d Poppy.
A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palmsand the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes avaluable kind of sago.
The California white oak (Quercus lobata).
A French cloth measure, of different parts of the country (atParis, 0.95 of an English ell); -- now superseded by the meter.
To protest against; to reject solemnly. [Obs.]I utterly abhor, yea, from my soul Refuse you for my judge. Shak.
The portion of a line formerly occupied by the letter m, then asquare type, used as a unit by which to measure the amount of printedmatter on a page; the square of the body of a type.
Once. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Abounding with pines. [Written also piney.] "The piny wood."Longfellow.
To carry or transport over a river, strait, or other narrowwater, in a boat.

A loose under-garment for the upper part of the body, made ofcotton, linen, or other material; -- formerly used of the under-garment of either sex, now commonly restricted to that worn by menand boys.Several persons in December had nothing over their shoulders buttheir shirts. Addison.She had her shirts and girdles of hair. Bp. Fisher.
A white crystalline substance consisting of phenol salicylate.
The sheatfish; -- called also waller.

Of or pertaining to Attica, in Greece, or to Athens, itsprincipal city; marked by such qualities as were characteristic ofthe Athenians; classical; refined. Attic base (Arch.), a peculiarform of molded base for a column or pilaster, described by Vitruvius,applied under the Roman Empire to the Ionic and Corinthian and "RomanDoric" orders, and imitated by the architects of the Renaissance.-- Attic faith, inviolable faith.-- Attic purity, special purity of language.-- Attic salt, Attic wit, a poignant, delicate wit, peculiar to theAthenians.-- Attic story. See Attic, n.-- Attic style, a style pure and elegant.
A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in theglands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends insuppuration.
Like curd; full of curd; coagulated. "A curdy mass." Arbuthnot.
The Dipper, or Charles's Wain.
Upper; covering; higher; superior; also, excessive; too much ortoo great; -- chiefly used in composition; as, overshoes, overcoat,over-garment, overlord, overwork, overhaste.
Any one of several species of very brilliant South Americanhumming birds, having a very long and deeply-forked tail; as, theblue-tailed sylph (Cynanthus cyanurus).
Pulverized sugar candy. Crabb.
A person not a Mohammedan, who pays the capitation tax.[Turkey.]
A tune, air, strain, or a whole piece, played by a singleperson on an instrument, or sung by a single voice.
The places which command the entrances or access; hence, placeof vantage; power; might.The gates of hell shall not prevail against it. Matt. xvi. 18.
To ask. See Spere. Sir W. Scott.
A nestful; a brood; as, a nide of pheasants. [Obs.]
See Flicker, n., 2.
Same as 2d Grise. [Obs.]

A low hill of drifting sand usually formed on the coats, butoften carried far inland by the prevailing winds. [Written also dun.]Three great rivers, the Rhine, the Meuse, and the Scheldt, haddeposited their slime for ages among the dunes or sand banks heavedup by the ocean around their mouths. Motley.
Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
Flourishing; thriving; fresh; in good case; vigorous. [Obs.]"Frim pastures." Drayton.

The white substance, consisting of an aggregation of bubbles,which is formed on the surface of liquids,or in the mouth of ananimal, by violent agitation or fermentation; froth; spume; scum; as,the foam of the sea. Foam cock, in steam boilers, a cock at the waterlevel, to blow off impurities.
The girdle of a Jewish priest or officer.
Pertaining to rebels or rebellion; acting in revolt;rebellious; as, rebel troops.Whoso be rebel to my judgment. Chaucer.Convict by flight, and rebel to all law. Milton.
Purified; refined. [Obs.] "Bread of pured wheat." "Pured gold."Chaucer.
A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); thered monkey.
See Rest bower, under 2d Bower.
The rhinocerous bird (a).
A wave. [Obs.] Spenser.
Straw. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In India, a mounted soldier.
See 2d Will. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To proclaim with a loud voice, or by outcry, as a hawker ortown-crier does. Swift.
,. v. i. To ply the whip; to strike; to uttercensure orsarcastic language.To laugh at follies, or to lash at vice. Dryden.To lash out, to strike out wildly or furiously.

A rope, chain, or rod attached to anything to steady it; as: arope to steady or guide an object which is being hoisted or lowered;a rope which holds in place the end of a boom, spar, or yard in aship; a chain or wire rope connecting a suspension bridge with theland on either side to prevent lateral swaying; a rod or ropeattached to the top of a structure, as of a derrick, and extendingobliquely to the ground, where it is fastened.
imp. of Cleave. [Obs.]
See Louver. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A black flag with white skull and crossbones, formerly used bypirates; -- called also Jolly Roger.
To form, or surround with, a halo; to encircle with, or aswith, a halo.The fire That haloed round his saintly brow. Sothey.
The country of Arabia. [Archaic & Poetic]
ASlothful. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
The order of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sawfishes,skates, and rays; -- called also Rajæ, and Rajii.

A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung;a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noblesentiment and appropriate dignity of style.Hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles. Shak.O! run; prevent them with thy humble ode, And lay it lowly at hisblessed feet. Milton.Ode factor, one who makes, or who traffics in, odes; -- usedcontemptuously.

Furze. See Furze.The common, overgrown with fern, and rough With prickly gorse.Cowper.Gorse bird (Zoöl.), the European linnet; -- called also gorsehatcher. [Prov. Eng.] -- Gorse chat (Zoöl.), the winchat.-- Gorse duck, the corncrake; -- called also grass drake, landdrake, and corn drake.
A claw. [Holland.
A kind of wild red cherry.
The Paraguay tea, being the dried leaf of the Brazilian holly(Ilex Paraguensis). The infusion has a pleasant odor, with anagreeable bitter taste, and is much used for tea in South America.
The black vulture (Catharista atrata). It ranges from theSouthern United States to South America. See Vulture.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth;wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door.
One of the whitish and elastic bundles of fibers, with theaccompanying tissues, which transmit nervous impulses between nervecenters and various parts of the animal body.
Whereas.And flight and die is death destroying death; Where fearing dyingpays death servile breath. Shak.
The carrion crow. [Written also dob.] [Prov. Eng.]
A rush (the plant). [Obs.] Chaucer.
To play on an instrument of music, or as on an instrument, inan unskillful or noisy way; to thrum; as, to strum a piano.
See 3d Leech.
A Hebrew dry measure, containing a little over two (2.37)pints. W. H. Ward. 2 Kings vi. 25.

A hard brittle brownish gelatin, obtained by boiling to a jellythe skins, hoofs, etc., of animals. When gently heated with water, itbecomes viscid and tenaceous, and is used as a cement for unitingsubstances. The name is also given to other adhesive or viscoussubstances. Bee glue. See under Bee.-- Fish glue, a strong kind of glue obtained from fish skins andbladders; isinglass.-- Glue plant (Bot.), a fucoid seaweed (Gloiopeltis tenax).-- Liquid glue, a fluid preparation of glue and acetic acidoralcohol.-- Marine glue, a solution of caoutchouc in naphtha, with shellac,used in shipbuilding.
To remove. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of the value of three oboli; hence, mean; worthless. [Obs.]It may pass current . . . for a triobolar ballad. Cheyne.
A kind of moccasin, having the edges of the sole turned up andsewed to the upper. Knight.
A large African antelope (Alcejaphus tora). It has widelydivergent, strongly ringed horns.
Situated in the axis of anything; as an embryo which lies inthe axis of a seed. Gray.
The page number. The even folios are on the left-hand pages andthe odd folios on the right-hand.

A hoofed quadruped of the genus Equus; especially, the domestichorse (E. caballus), which was domesticated in Egypt and Asia at avery early period. It has six broad molars, on each side of each jaw,with six incisors, and two canine teeth, both above and below. Themares usually have the canine teeth rudimentary or wanting. The horsediffers from the true asses, in having a long, flowing mane, and thetail bushy to the base. Unlike the asses it has callosities, orchestnuts, on all its legs. The horse excels in strength, speed,docility, courage, and nobleness of character, and is used fordrawing, carrying, bearing a rider, and like purposes.
A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of abouttwenty-eight cents. See Crown, n., 9.
To obtrude one's self on another for bed and board. [Scot.] SirW. Scott.
A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to thecranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breastedtrumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surfacemarked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.
An exclamation expressing various emotions, according to thetone and manner, especially surprise, pain, sorrow, anxiety, or awish. See the Note under O.
From; away; back or backward; -- now used only in oppositiontothe word to, in the phrase to and fro, that is, to and from. See Toand fro under To. Millon.
A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of manykinds.
The box, case, vase, or tabernacle, in which the host isreserved.
Jasper. [Obs.] Spenser.
The consecrated wafer, believed to be the body of Christ, whichin the Mass is offered as a sacrifice; also, the bread beforeconsecration.
Bad, soft coal, containing much earthy matter, found in theimmediate locality of faults.
Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as,the oak eggar (L. roboris) of Europe.

The Savior; the name of the Son of God as announced by theangel to his parents; the personal name of Our Lord, in distinctionfrom Christ, his official appellation. Luke i. 31.Thou shalt call his name Jesus; for he shall save his people fromtheir sins. Matt. i. 21.
Lees; dregs; grounds. [Eng.] "Grouts of tea." Dickens.
. A form of the prefix in- not, and in- in. See In-. Im- alsooccurs in composition with some words not of Latin origin; as,imbank, imbitter.
To associate with strumpets; to wench. Beau. & Fl.

A well-known cereal grass (Oryza sativa) and its seed. Thisplant is extensively cultivated in warm climates, and the grain formsa large portion of the food of the inhabitants. In America it growschiefly on low, moist land, which can be overflowed. Ant rice. (Bot.)See under Ant.-- French rice. (Bot.) See Amelcorn.-- Indian rice., a tall reedlike water grass (Zizania aquatica),bearing panicles of a long, slender grain, much used for food byNorth American Indians. It is common in shallow water in the NorthernStates. Called also water oat, Canadian wild rice, etc.-- Mountain rice, any species of an American genus (Oryzopsis) ofgrasses, somewhat resembling rice.-- Rice bunting. (Zoöl.) Same as Ricebird.-- Rice hen (Zoöl.), the Florida gallinule.-- Rice mouse (Zoöl.), a large dark-colored field mouse (Calomyspalistris) of the Southern United States.-- Rice paper, a kind of thin, delicate paper, brought from China, -- used for painting upon, and for the manufacture of fancy articles.It is made by cutting the pith of a large herb (Fatsia papyrifera,related to the ginseng) into one roll or sheet, which is flattenedout under pressure. Called also pith paper.-- Rice troupial (Zoöl.), the bobolink.-- Rice water, a drink for invalids made by boiling a small quantityof rice in water.-- Rice-water discharge (Med.), a liquid, resembling rice water inappearance, which is vomited, and discharged from the bowels, incholera.-- Rice weevil (Zoöl.), a small beetle (Calandra, or Sitophilus,oryzæ) which destroys rice, wheat, and Indian corn by eating out theinterior; -- called also black weevil.
Internal; interior; secret.Didst thou but know the inly touch of love. Shak.
See Scion.The cion overruleth the stock; and the stock is but passive, andgiveth aliment, but no motion, to the graft. Bacon.
The mark of a stripe. See Wale.
The stormy petrel. [Prov. Eng.]
An order regulating the practice of the courts, or an ordermade between parties to an action or a suit. Wharton.
Slumber. [Prov. Eng.]
A square-rigged vessel, differing from a brig only in that shehas a trysail mast close abaft the mainmast, on which a large trysailis hoisted.

To stop, as the orifice in the bilge of a cask, with a bung; toclose; -- with up. To bung up, to use up, as by bruising or overexertion; to exhaust or incapacitate for action. [Low]He had bunged up his mouth that he should not have spoken these threeyears. Shelton (Trans. Don Quixote).

A tract of low ground, or of land between hills; a valley. "Make me a cottage in the vale." Tennyson.Beyond this vale of tears there is a life above. Montgomery.In those fair vales, by nature formed to please. Harte.
Like a wedge; wedge-shaped.
To deny. [Obs.]That with great rage he stoutly doth denay. Spenser.
To remove a peg or pegs from; to unfasten; to open. Shak.
A child's name for mamma, mother.
Made of linen; as, linen cloth; a linen stocking.

The name given by ancient geographers to the northernmost partof the habitable world. According to some, this land was Norway,according to others, Iceland, or more probably Mainland, the largestof the Shetland islands; hence, the Latin phrase ultima Thule,farthest Thule.
In a quick manner; quickly; promptly; rapidly; with haste;speedily; without delay; as, run quick; get back quick.If we consider how very quick the actions of the mind are performed.Locke.
Royal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Realm. [Obs.]
Nearer. [Obs.] Spenser.
Any one of numerous species of stinging hymenopterous insects,esp. any of the numerous species of the genus Vespa, which includesthe true, or social, wasps, some of which are called yellow jackets.
Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food;delicacies; dainties. Shak.Cates for which Apicius could not pay. Shurchill.Choicest cates and the fiagon's best spilth. R. Browning.
A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsomelady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.

A dwarf umbelliferous plant, somewhat resembling fennel(Cuminum Cyminum), cultivated for its seeds, which have a bitterish,warm taste, with an aromatic flavor, and are used like those of aniseand caraway. [Written also cummin.]Rank-smelling rue, and cumin good for eyes. Spenser.Black cumin (Bot.), a plant (Nigella sativa) with pungent seeds, usedby the Afghans, etc.
That same; this; that. [Obs.] "I love thilk lass." Spenser.Thou spake right now of thilke traitor death. Chaucer.
See Fisher, 2.
Coagulated. [Obs.]His cruel wounds with crudy blood congealed. Spenser.
A ledge; a right-angled projection.

To imbue or impregnate with something different or foreign; as,to tinge a decoction with a bitter taste; to affect in some degreewith the qualities of another substance, either by mixture, or byapplication to the surface; especially, to color slightly; to stain;as, to tinge a blue color with red; an infusion tinged with a yellowcolor by saffron.His [Sir Roger's] virtues, as well as imperfections, are tinged by acertain extravagance. Addison.
To arrange in exact continuity of line, as soldiers; commonlyto adjust to a straight line and at proper distance; to align; as, todress the ranks.
A prefix signifying ten. See Deca-.
A large and bright constellation on the equator, between thestars Aldebaran and Sirius. It contains a remarkable nebula visibleto the naked eye.The flaming glories of Orion's belt. E. Everett.
A fool; a simpleton. Shak.
To gaze; to stare. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea.
Solely; simply; exclusively.

Troy weight. Troy weight, the weight which gold and silver,jewels, and the like, are weighed. It was so named from Troyes, inFrance, where it was first adopted in Europe. The troy ounce issupposed to have been brought from Cairo during the crusades. In thisweight the pound is divided into 12 ounces, the ounce into 20pennyweights, and the pennyweight into 24 grains; hence, the troyounce contains 480 grains, and the troy pound contains 5760 grains.The avoirdupois pound contains 7000 troy grains; so that 175 poundstroy equal 144 pounds avoirdupois, or 1 pound troy = 0.82286 of apound avoirdupois, and 1 ounce troy = 1apothecaries' weight, used inweighing medicines, etc. In the standard weights of the UnitedStates, the troy ounce is divided decimally down to the
To drivel, or drop saliva; as, the child drools.His mouth drooling with texts. T. Parker.
A fairy; a goblin; an elf. [Obs.] "Like urchins, ouphes, andfairies." Shak.
An unburnt brick dried in the sun; also used as an adjective,as, an adobe house, in Texas or New Mexico.
Pertaining to ulmin; designating an acid obtained from ulmin.
Any one of numerous species of small parrots having a graduatedtail, which is frequently very long; -- called also paroquet andparaquet.
A term of reproach used by the Jews of our Savior's time,meaning "worthless."
pl. of Tarsus.
A spy; a scout. [Obs.] Bacon.

Greater by a semitone, either in interval or in difference ofpitch from another tone. Major axis (Geom.), the greater axis. SeeFocus, n., 2.-- Major key (Mus.), a key in which one and two, two and three, fourand five, five and six and seven, make major seconds, and three andfour, and seven and eight, make minor seconds.-- Major offense (Law), an offense of a greater degree whichcontains a lesser offense, as murder and robbery include assault.-- Major premise (Logic), that premise of a syllogism which containsthe major term.-- Major scale (Mus.), the natural diatonic scale, which hassemitones between the third and fourth, and seventh and fourth, andseventh and eighth degrees; the scale of the major mode, of which thethird is major. See Scale, and Diatonic.-- Major second (Mus.), a second between whose tones is a differencein pitch of a step.-- Major sixth (Mus.), a sixth of four steps and a half step. Inmajor keys the third and sixth from the key tone are major. Majorkeys and intervals, as distinguished from minors, are more cheerful.-- Major term (Logic), that term of a syllogism which forms thepredicate of the conclusion.-- Major third (Mus.), a third of two steps.
imp. of Wax. Gower.
See Haulm, straw.
A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright,giving the characters when taken together a round look.
To perform the action of biting and grinding with the teeth; toruminate; to meditate.old politicians chew wisdom past. Pope.
To chew loudly and greedily; to champ. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Halliwell.
See 1st and 2d Teen. [Obs.]
League; confederacy; esp. the confederation of German states.
See Feeze.
Silica, SiO2 as found in nature, constituting quarz, and mostsands and sandstones. See Silica, and Silicic.
Being out of the common course or limits; extravagant; bizarre.
A nesting or unfledged Lird; in falconry, a young hawk from thenest, not able to pr Shak J. H. Walsh
The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma,Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
A dull, silent person; a blockhead. [Obs.] Spenser.

To express or signify the mind, will, or preference, eitherviva voce, or by ballot, or by other authorized means, as in electingpersons to office, in passing laws, regulations, etc., or in decidingon any proposition in which one has an interest with others.The vote for a duelist is to assist in the prostration of justice,and, indirectly, to encourage the crime. L. Beecher.To vote on large principles, to vote honestly, requires a greatamount of information. F. W. Robertson.
To toss up the head frequently, as a horse to avoid therestraint of the bridle.
The edge of a cask, etc; a chine. See Chine, n., 3. [Writtenalso hime.]
To live in, or as in, a cabin; to lodge.I'll make you . . . cabin in a cave. Shak.
Same as Chive.
Wolfram, an ore of tungsten. Simmonds.
To throw out with force from a narrow orifice; to eject; tospurt out. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Fretful; peevish; petulant; easily irritated.Must I observe you must I stand and crouch Under your testy humorShak.I was displeased with myself; I was testy. Latimer.
An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.My lungs began to crow like chanticleer. Shak.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.
p. p. from Do, and formerly the infinitive.
If. [Obs.]
To adjust or form to a line; to range or form in line; to bringinto line; to aline.
See 1st Pea.
imp. & p. p. of Bid.
Covered with, or containing, bark. "The barky fingers of theelm." Shak.
A fish. See Bleak, n.
The crab plover (Dromas ardeola), a peculiar North Africanbird, allied to the oyster catcher.
A bale of raw silk.
A blank on the edge or corner of a page, owing to a portion ofthe frisket, or something else, intervening between the type andpaper.
In a fit manner; suitably; properly; conveniently; as, a maximfitly applied.
To stamp with the foot. [Colloq.] "In gallant procession, thepriests mean to stomp." R. Browning.
See Corf.
Same as Britzska.
A sneer; a flout. [Obs.]

A tree, usually growing in moist land, and belonging to thegenus Alnus. The wood is used by turners, etc.; the bark by dyers andtanners. In the U. S. the species of alder are usually shrubs orsmall trees. Black alder. (a) A European shrub (Rhamnus frangula);Alder buckthorn. (b) An American species of holly (Ilexverticillata), bearing red berries.
A mope; a drone. [Obs.] Swift.
See Y-.
See Misy.
Place; room; stead; -- used only in the phrase in lieu of, thatis, instead of.The plan of extortion had been adopted in lieu of the scheme ofconfiscation. Burke.
imp. of Undo.
. See -ize.
A wall. [Obs.] Shak.
To begin [Obs.] See Gin.

Way of being or acting; manner; mode; fashion. "All armed incomplete wise." Spenser.To love her in my beste wyse. Chaucer.This song she sings in most commanding wise. Sir P. Sidney.Let not these blessings then, sent from above, Abused be, or spilt inprofane wise. Fairfax.
To follow; to pursue; to follow and overtake. [Obs.] "Seekpeace, and ensue it." 1 Pet. iii. 11.To ensue his example in doing the like mischief. Golding.
The name of several evergreen trees. The wood is remarkable forits durability and fragrant odor.
The siskin. [Prov.]
Green gram, a kind of pulse (Phaseolus Mungo), grown for foodin British India. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
The aurochs.
The slender styles of the pistillate flowers of maize; alsocalled silk.
The cargo of a vessel when stowed.
One who has been deceived or who is easily deceived; a gull;as, the dupe of a schemer.
Evil; ill. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any article or separable part of one's assets.
A combining form used to signify thousand in forming the namesof units of measurement; as, kilogram, kilometer, kilowatt, etc.
A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.[Written also cimar, cymar, samare, simare.]
To break in pieces violently; to dash together with noise andviolence. [R.]He shakt his head, and crasht his teeth for ire. Fairfax.
Forth from; out of. [Archaic]Some forth their cabins peep. Donne.
A race of people of uncertain origin, who inhabited Scotland inearly times.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of thecrown. [Scot.]
The marriage knot. [Obs.] Crashaw.
A thorp. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Clad in a cope.

To close the eyes of (a hawk or other bird) by drawing throughthe lids threads which were fastened over the head. Bacon.Fools climbs to fall: fond hopes, like seeled doves for want ofbetter light, mount till they end their flight with falling. J.Reading.
A suffix used to form the superlative of adjectives andadverbs; as, smoothest; earl(y)iest.
To thrive; to prosper. [Obs.] "He shall never thee." Chaucer.Well mote thee, as well can wish your thought. Spenser.
To cause to make a sharp twanging sound; to twang, or twangle.Addison.
The smallest particle of matter that can enter intocombination; one of the elementary constituents of a molecule.

To cheat; to defrand; to beguile; to deceive, usually by smallarts, or in a pitiful way.He had cozened the world by fine phrases. Macualay.Children may be cozened into a knowledge of the letters. Locke.Goring loved no man so well but that he would cozen him, and exposehim to public mirth for having been cozened. Clarendon.
Crooked; awry. [Obs.] "This is clean kam." Shak.
The track or trail of any wild animal; as, the spoor of anelephant; -- used originally by travelers in South Africa.
Same as Lug, n., 3.

One of the end bars by which the lay of a hand loom issuspended. Sword arm, the right arm.-- Sword bayonet, a bayonet shaped somewhat like a sword, and whichcan be used as a sword.-- Sword bearer, one who carries his master's sword; an officer inLondon who carries a sword before the lord mayor when he goes abroad.-- Sword belt, a belt by which a sword is suspended, and borne atthe side.-- Sword blade, the blade, or cutting part, of a sword.-- Sword cane, a cane which conceals the blade of a sword or dagger,as in a sheath.-- Sword dance. (a) A dance in which swords are brandished andclashed together by the male dancers. Sir W. Scott. (b) A danceperformed over swords laid on the ground, but without touching them.-- Sword fight, fencing; a combat or trial of skill with swords;swordplay.-- Sword grass. (Bot.) See Gladen.-- Sword knot, a ribbon tied to the hilt of a sword.-- Sword law, government by the sword, or by force; violence.Milton.-- Sword lily. (Bot.) See Gladiolus.-- Sword mat (Naut.), a mat closely woven of yarns; -- so calledfrom a wooden implement used in its manufacture.-- Sword shrimp (Zoöl.), a European shrimp (Pasiphæa sivado) havinga very thin, compressed body.-- Sword stick, a sword cane.-- To measure swords with one. See under Measure, v. t.-- To put to the sword. See under Put.
Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hecticfever, with no well-marked local symptoms.
Same as Socle.
A prefix, meaning equally; as, equidistant; equiangular.
To take; to steal; to filch. [Obs.]This canon it in his hand nam. Chaucer.
Tore.
See Ocher.

A suffix denoting that the element indicated by the namebearing it, has a valence lower than that denoted by the termination-ic; as, nitrous, sulphurous, etc., as contrasted with nitric,sulphuric, etc.
Like a net, or network; netted. [R.]
One of the Cetacea, or collectively, the Cetacea.
Affected by "dope"; esp., sluggish or dull as though under theinfluence of a narcotic. [Slang]
To as, to hash meat. Hudibras.
Bright; glittering; fiery. [Obs.]His eyen steep, and rolling in his head. Chaucer.
To carve or cut up, as a chub.
Certain prayers to be repeated at stated times of the day, asmatins and vespers.
. See Iso-.
To take fish, or other marine animals, with a trawl.

A mercantile establishment or factory for foreign trade inChina, as formerly at Canton; a succession of offices connected by acommon passage and used for business or storage. Hong merchant, oneof the few Chinese merchants who, previous to the treaty of 1842,formed a guild which had the exclusive privilege of trading withforeigners.
To manufacture counterfeit money.They cannot touch me for coining. Shak.
A loft or upper chamber; a garret room. [Obs.] [Written alsosoler, solere, sollar.] Oxf. Gloss.
A gatepost or doorpost. [Local Eng.] C. Kingsley.

To retard; to hinder; to impede; to oppose. [Archaic]He was so strong that no man might him let. Chaucer.He who now letteth will let, until he be taken out of the way. 2.Thess. ii. 7.Mine ancient wound is hardly whole, And lets me from the saddle.Tennyson.

A kind of food. See citation, below.Caring or carl are gray steeped in water and fried the next day inbutter or fat. They are eaten on the second Sunday before Easter,formerly called Carl Sunday. Robinson's Whitby Glossary (1875).
The electric catfish. [Written also raasch.]
The engagement of the teeth of wheels, or of a wheel and rack.Mesh stick, a stick on which the mesh is formed in netting.
See Sicker. [Obs.]
One who cements with glue.
See Sib. [Obs. or Scot.]
The sacrifice in the sacrament of the Eucharist, or theconsecration and oblation of the host.
To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The pewit.
The brambling finch.

In an equal part or degree; in some paas, half-colored, halfdone, half-hearted, half persuaded, half conscious. "Half loth andhalf consenting." Dryden.Their children spoke halfin the speech of Ashdod. Neh. xiii. 24
Having (such) a face, or (so many) faces; as, smooth-faced,two-faced.
See Sadh.
See Oast.

One who guards, protects, watches over, or has the care of,some person or thing. Specifically: --(a) A treasurer; a keeper. "Tutour of your treasure." Piers Plowman.(b) (Civ. Law) One who has the charge of a child or pupil and hisestate; a guardian.(c) A private or public teacher.(d) (Eng. Universities) An officer or member of some hall, whoinstructs students, and is responsible for their discipline.(e) (Am. Colleges) An instructor of a lower rank than a professor.
Tenth. [Obs.]Every tithe soul, 'mongst many thousand. Shak.
In a cocked or turned up fashion.
Certainly. [Obs.] "God so wisly have mercy on me." Chaucer.
Quick; rapid. Pui tosto ( Etym: [It.] (Mus.), faster; morerapid.
Dry. Secco painting, or Painting in secco, painting on dryplaster, as distinguished from fresco painting, which is on wet orfresh plaster.
To plow. [Obs.] See Ear, v. t. Chaucer.
A period of seven days, usually that reckoned from one Sabbathor Sunday to the next.I fast twice in the week. Luke xviii. 12.
Miry; slushy.
Like. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.

Correspondence of sound in the terminating words or syllablesof two or more verses, one succeeding another immediately or at nogreat distance. The words or syllables so used must not begin withthe same consonant, or if one begins with a vowel the other mustbegin with a consonant. The vowel sounds and accents must be thesame, as also the sounds of the final consonants if there be any.For rhyme with reason may dispense, And sound has right to governsense. Prior.
To deprive of wit. [Obs.] Shak.
An aerie.
To deny; to disown. [Obs.]
A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fattyingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine.
The sliding weight on a steelyard. [Written also pee.]
See Voe. [Scot.]
See Jorum.
Self. [Obs. or Scot.] B. Jonson.
Milk sickness.
Vaulted. "The haughty vauty welkin." [Obs.] Taylor (1611).
A narrow passage between two buildings, as between the transeptand chapter house of a monastery. [Eng.]
To weave, as cloth, so as to produce the appearance of diagonallines or ribs on the surface.
To listen or listen to; to hearken to. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
Same as Vugg.
A genus of woodpeckers, including some of the common Americanand European species.
One more than three; twice two.
Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland.
The vascular body which forms the apex of the penis, and theextremity of the clitoris.
To refuse to support, as a nomination made by a party to whichone has belonged or by a caucus in which one has taken part.
Rennet. See 3d Reed. [Prov. Eng.]
A syllable applied to the third tone of the scale of C, i. e.,to E, in European solmization, but to the third tone of any scale inthe American system.
A diminutive suffix; as, manikin; lambkin.
The gadwall. [Prov.Eng.]
To woo. [Obs.] Chaucer.
No; not. See No, a. Chaucer.

A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wanderingfrom place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk,like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed forthe shelter of cattle or their keepers. [Obs.] [Written also boley,bolye, bouillie.] Spenser.
Old Norse poetry expressed in runes.Runes were upon his tongue, As on the warrior's sword. Longfellow.Rune stone, a stone bearing a runic inscription.
Filled with roe.

To be contiguous, close, or in contact; to come together; tounite; to mingle; to form a union; as, the hones of the skull join;two rivers join.Whose house joined hard to the synagogue. Acts xviii. 7.Should we again break thy commandments, and join in affinity with thepeople of these abominations Ezra ix. 14.Nature and fortune joined to make thee great. Shak.

To refit; to repair, or make reparation for; hence, to repay orrequite. [Obs.]It shall be good that you redub that negligence. Wyatt.God shall give power to redub it with some like requital to theFrench. Grafton.
A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what onedislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy.Worse than Tantalus' is her annoy. Shak.

imp. & p. p. of Breed. Bred out, degenerated. "The strain ofman's bred out into baboon and monkey." Shak.-- Bred to arms. See under Arms.-- Well bred. (a) Of a good family; having a good pedigree. "Agentleman well bred and of good name." Shak. [Obs., except as appliedto domestic animals.] (b) Well brought up, as shown in having goodmanners; cultivated; refined; polite.

Formerly the part sung by the highest male, or counter-tenor,voices; now the part sung by the lowest female, or contralto, voices,between in tenor and soprano. In instrumental music it now signifiesthe tenor.
Yellow; fal [Obs.] Wright.
imp. of Sit. [Written also sate.]
To place in the sky or in heaven. [R.] "A thing enskied andsainted." Shak.
Extra pay; esp. an extra allowance to an English officerserving in India. Whitworth.
See Quinic.
Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovialsacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposedbetween tendons and bony prominences.
A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; theumbilicus. See Umbilicus.belly button in humans
In a idle manner; ineffectually; vainly; lazily; carelessly;(Obs.) foolishly.

A molding, shaft of a column, or any other member of convex,rounded section, made to resemble the spiral twist of a rope; --called also cable molding. Bower cable, the cable belonging to thebower anchor.-- Cable road, a railway on which the cars are moved by acontinuously running endless rope operated by a stationary motor.-- Cable's length, the length of a ship's cable. Cables in themerchant service vary in length from 100 to 140 fathoms or more; butas a maritime measure, a cable's length is either 120 fathoms (720feet), or about 100 fathoms (600 feet, an approximation to one tenthof a nautical mile).-- Cable tier. (a) That part of a vessel where the cables arestowed. (b) A coil of a cable.-- Sheet cable, the cable belonging to the sheet anchor.-- Stream cable, a hawser or rope, smaller than the bower cables, tomoor a ship in a place sheltered from wind and heavy seas.-- Submarine cable. See Telegraph.-- To pay out the cable, To veer out the cable, to slacken it, thatit may run out of the ship; to let more cable run out of the hawsehole.-- To serve the cable, to bind it round with ropes, canvas, etc., toprevent its being, worn or galled in the hawse, et.-- To slip the cable, to let go the end on board and let it all runout and go overboard, as when there is not time to weigh anchor.Hence, in sailor's use, to die.
Confined in, or as in, a cage; like a cage or prison. "Thecaged cloister." Shak.
A jester; a buffoon. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The denuded stems or stalks of such crops as buckwheat and thecereal grains, beans, etc.; straw.
A genus of plants (Rumex), some species of which are well-knownweeds which have a long taproot and are difficult of extermination.
A delicate fiber, produced in the Philippine Islands from anunidentified plant, of which dresses, etc., are made.
To beat; to whap. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Sir T. Malory.
To adorn. [Obs.] Bp. Watson.
One of the New England States. Maine law, any law prohibitingthe manufacture and sale of intoxicating beverages, esp. oneresembling that enacted in the State of Maine.
See Eccentric, and V-hook.
A firework which, while burning, is caused to revolve on anaxis by the reaction of the escaping gases.(f) (Poetry) The burden or refrain of a song.
Of or pertaining to sepia; done in sepia; as, a sepic drawing.
The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.
To throw, as a lance; to let fly; to launch.See Whose arm can lanch the surer bolt. Dryden & Lee.
To cauterize. To fire up, to light up the fires of, as of anengine.
Same as Banxring.
A suffix signifying action; also, quality or state; as,assistance, resistance, appearance, elegance. See -ancy.
imp. of Give.

To strike with fear and reverence; to inspire with awe; tocontrol by inspiring dread.That same eye whose bend doth awe the world. Shak.His solemn and pathetic exhortation awed and melted the bystanders.Macaulay.
To notify of a proceeding in court. Abbot
An irregular, narrow, projecting part of a field. [Prov. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to the pine; obtained from the pine; formerly,designating an acid which is the chief constituent of common resin, -- now called abietic, or sylvic, acid.
To stutter. [Obs.] Skelton.
Same as Achene.
A young person of either sex. [Obs.] See Girl. Chaucer.

The unit of monetary value in Russia. It is divided into 100copecks, and in the gold coin of the realm (as in the five and tenruble pieces) is worth about 77 cents. The silver ruble is a coinworth about 60 cents. [Written also rouble.]
The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.
See Supawn. [Local, U.S.]
An appeal (in verification of a statement made) to a superiorsanction, in such a form as exposes the party making the appeal to anindictment for perjury if the statement be false.
Furious; mad; angry; fierce. [Obs.] "Then wexeth wood andyond." Spenser.
Possessing acres or landed property; -- used in composition;as, large-acred men.
imp. & p. p. of Slink.
The striped quagga, or Burchell's zebra, of South Africa(Asinus Burchellii); -- called also peechi, or peetsi.
A chap or crack in the flesh occasioned by cold; an ulceratedchilblain. "He galls his kibe." Shak.

Being on the outside; external; farthest or farther from theinterior, from a given station, or from any space or positionregarded as a center or starting place; -- opposed to inner; as, theouter wall; the outer court or gate; the outer stump in cricket; theouter world. Outer bar, in England, the body of junior (or utter)barristers; -- so called because in court they occupy a place beyondthe space reserved for Queen's counsel.

A species of hickory (Carya olivæformis), growing in NorthAmerica, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it isone of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblongnut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat. [Written also pacane.]
A variety of plum; as, the greengage; also, the blue gage,frost gage, golden gage, etc., having more or less likeness to thegreengage. See Greengage.
A kind of sauce much used in India, containing garlic, pepper,ginger, and other strong spices.
A twig of a tree cut off. [Obs.]
A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given bycourtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
To pass from one note to another with no perceptible cassationof sound.

A long seat, usually with a cushioned bottom, back, and ends; -- much used as a comfortable piece of furniture.Let fall the curtains, wheel the sofa round. Cowper.Sofa bed, a sofa so contrived that it may be extended to form a bed;-- called also sofa bedstead.

Save or except (that); -- an adversative used elliptically withor without that, and properly introducing a single fact orconsideration.He might have seemed some secretary or clerk . . . only that his low,flat, unadorned cap . . . indicated that he belonged to the city. SirW. Scott.
See Camis. [Obs.]
A Spanish title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also,a lady.
The trade winds.
A prefix signifying Indian (i. e., East Indian); of orpertaining of India.
Unsteady; fickle. [Obs.]O, stormy people, unsad and ever untrue. Chaucer.
A cipher; nothing; naught.
Any one of numerous species of regularly scaled harmlesslizards of the family Scincidæ, common in the warmer parts of all thecontinents.
Dejected; sorrowful; downcast. [Obs.] "So piteous and so maat."Chaucer.
A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter. [Written alsocomb.]
To fall at once into a chair or seat; to sit lazily. [Obs.]Swift.
To repress or repel by expressing displeasure or disapproval;to rebuke with a look; as, frown the impudent fellow into silence.

A plant of the genus Linum, esp. the L. usitatissimum, whichhas a single, slender stalk, about a foot and a half high, with blueflowers. The fiber of the bark is used for making thread and cloth,called linen, cambric, lawn, lace, etc. Linseed oil is expressed fromthe seed.
A small gudgeon.
Hypochondria. [Colloq.]
Same as Crape.
A short, thick, heavy piece of wood. Morton. Chump end, thethick end; as, the chump end of a joint of meat. Dickens.
About. [Obs.] Layamon.
To open; as, to dup the door. [Obs.] Shak.
A French lyceum, or secondary school supported by the Frenchgovernment, for preparing students for the university.
See Ghoul.
To conduct a quiz. See Quiz, n., 4. [U.S.]
A kiln. [Obs.]

Refuse; lees; dregs; the wash given to swine or cows; hogwash;waste matter.Prodigals lately come from swine keeping, from eating draff andhusks. Shak.The draff and offal of a bygone age. Buckle.Mere chaff and draff, much better burnt. Tennyson.
A combining form from Gr. "omo`s, one and the same, common,joint.
See Ayle. [Obs.]
In the greatest or highest degree.Those nearest to this king, and most his favorites, were courtiersand prelates. Milton.
The hard, calcified tissue of the skeleton of vertebrateanimals, consisting very largely of calcic carbonate, calcicphosphate, and gelatine; as, blood and bone.
To fleet; to skim. [Obs.] Tusser.
An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas orcopiapite.
One of the furs, the ground being sable, and the spots or tuftsor.
p. p. of Flay. Chaucer.
See Big, n. & v.
To act with force in opposition to force impressed; to exerciserepulsion.
Anywhere. [Obs.] "If he found owher a good fellow." Chaucer.
An eager desire or longing; greediness; as, a greed of gain.
Affected with kibes. Skelton.
One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so forsport; a copyist; a buffoon. Burke.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, great fear, or funking.[Colloq. Eng.]
To waste away; to pine; to languish. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Gower.

Of or pertaining to the Salian Franks, or to the Salic law socalled. [Also salique.] Salic law. (a) A code of laws formed by theSalian Franks in the fifth century. By one provision of this codewomen were excluded from the inheritance of landed property. (b)Specifically, in modern times, a law supposed to be a specialapplication of the above-mentioned provision, in accordance withwhich males alone can inherit the throne. This law has obtained inFrance, and at times in other countries of Europe, as Spain.
Same as Arrack.

Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix, v. t. & i.Mixed action (Law), a suit combining the properties of a real and apersonal action.-- Mixed angle, a mixtilineal angle.-- Mixed fabric, a textile fabric composed of two or more kinds offiber, as a poplin.-- Mixed marriage, a marriage between persons of different races orreligions; specifically, one between a Roman Catholic and aProtestant.-- Mixed number, a whole number and a fraction taken together.-- Mixed train, a railway train containing both passenger andfreight cars.-- Mixed voices (Mus.), voices of both males and females united inthe same performance.
capable of being drawn into a thread, as a glutinous substance;stringy; viscous; tenacious; glutinous; as ropy sirup; ropy lees.
See Only. [Obs.] Spenser.
A parrot; -- familiarly so called.
See Llama.

A resinous substance flowing spontaneously from trees ofZanzibar, Madagascar, and South America (Trachylobium Hornemannianum,T. verrocosum, and Hymenæa Courbaril), and dug from earth whereforests have stood in Africa; -- used chiefly in making varnishes. Ur
A public storehouse.
The front of an army. [Obs.] See Van.
A native or inhabitant of Media in Asia.
To singe. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Gee.
A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication fromone siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
To take off the hat of; to remove one's hat, especially as amark of respect. H. Spenser.
Sedge; seaweed. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Dirty; soiled. [Obs.] Fuller.
Misty; foggy; cloudy. [Prov. Eng.] Ray.
Good. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Wilt not. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or resembling, an animal.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar. [Prov. Eng.]
Same as Gang, n., 2. [Obs.]There is a knot, a ging, a pack, a conspiracy against me. Shak.
To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.
A hump-backed person; -- so called sportively. [Eng.]Richardson (Dict.).

Reddish brown; of the color of a chestnut; -- applied to thecolor of horses. Bay cat (Zoöl.), a wild cat of Africa and the EastIndies (Felis aurata).-- Bay lynx (Zoöl.), the common American lynx (Felis, or Lynx,rufa).
Wide and general destruction; devastation; waste.As for Saul, he made havoc of the church. Acts viii. 3.Ye gods, what havoc does ambition make Among your works! Addison.
See Morrow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burdenbearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
A name used in calling a hen or chicken. Shak.

A liliaceous plant of the genus Allium (A.cepa), having astrong-flavored bulb and long hollow leaves; also, its bulbous root,much used as an article of food. The name is often extended to otherspecies of the genus. Onion fish (Zoöl.), the grenadier.-- Onion fly (Zoöl.) a dipterous insect whose larva feeds upon theonion; especially, Anthomyia ceparum and Ortalis flexa.-- Welsh onion. (Bot.) See Cibol.-- Wild onion (Bot.), a name given to several species of the genusAllium.
To moisten. [Obs.] Shak.
To anoint. [Obs.] Dryden.
Employing, or done by means of, water or some other liquid; as,the wet extraction of copper, in distinction from dry extraction inwhich dry heat or fusion is employed.
(Agric.) To pasture cattle on the fog, or aftergrass, of; toeat off the fog from.
A genus of water fowls, of the order Anseres, including certainspecies of fresh-water ducks.

A prefix denoting priority (of time, place, or rank); as,precede, to go before; precursor, a forerunner; prefix, to fix orplace before; preëminent eminent before or above others. Pre- issometimes used intensively, as in prepotent, very potent. [Writtenalso præ-.]
To untwist; as, to unlay a rope.
To wriggle. [Obs.] Skelton.

(a) To bring entirely down or put an end to; to do away with;as, to abate a nuisance, to abate a writ. (b) (Eng. Law) To diminish;to reduce. Legacies are liable to be abated entirely or inproportion, upon a deficiency of assets. To abate a tax, to remit iteither wholly or in part.
A curved handle. Sir W. Scott.
The itch in animals; also, a scab. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]

To utter a sudden and loud outcry, as in joy, triumph, orexultation, or to attract attention, to animate soldiers, etc.Shouting of the men and women eke. Chaucer.They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for Shak.To shout at, to utter shouts at; to deride or revile with shouts.
A horizontal dislocation in a metallic lode, taking place at anintersection with another lode.
See Jet. [Obs.]
To plead orally; to argue a matter in court; to recite a count.Burrill.
Stanza. [Obs.] Sackville.
Adieu; farewell; good-by; -- chiefly used among Spanish-speaking people.
Foul matter; dirt, rubbed in; sullying blackness, deeplyingrained.
see Ils Jack.
. See under Hydro-.
See Querl.
the preterit of Eat.
Firm; determined; fixed. "A most posed . . . and gravebehavior." [Obs.] Urquhart.
Tranquil; peaceful; calm. [Poet.] "A still and calmy day"Spenser.
The fist. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A cavity or hollow.[Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
An old term for a river boat.
To make a vow, or solemn promise.Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldestvow and not pay. Eccl. v. 5.
An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis). [Written alsobulti.]
See Aught.

The small intestines; as, the ropes of birds. Rope ladder, aladder made of ropes.-- Rope mat., a mat made of cordage, or strands of old rope.-- Rope of sand, something of no cohession or fiber; a feeble unionor tie; something not to be relied upon.-- Rope pump, a pump in which a rapidly running endless rope raiseswater by the momentum communicated to the water by its adhesion tothe rope.-- Rope transmission (Mach.), a method of transmitting power, asbetween distant places, by means of endless ropes running overgrooved pulleys.-- Rope's end, a piece of rope; especially, one used as a lash ininflicting punishment.-- To give one rope, to give one liberty or license; to let one goat will uncheked.

A military cap having a close-fitting band, a round flat topsloping toward the front, and a visor. As originally worn by theFrench in Algeria about 1830 it was tall and stiff with a straightvisor. It is now lower, has a curved visor, and is frequently soft.
See Dermis.
One entire round in a circle or a spire; as, a cycle or set ofleaves. Gray.

The blubber of whales or other marine mammals; also, the fat ofthe hippopotamus. Speck falls (Naut.), falls or ropes rove throughblocks for hoisting the blubber and bone of whales on board a whalingvessel.
Prolonged, or relatively more prolonged, in utterance; -- saidof vowels and syllables. See Short, a., 13, and Guide toPronunciation, §§ 22, 30.
A hill in Jerusalem, which, after the capture of that city bythe Israelites, became the royal residence of David and hissuccessors.
Same as Alder, of all. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Certainly; really; indeed. [Obs.] "As wis God helpe me."Chaucer.
Lore; learning. [Obs.]

The track left by a vessel in the water; by extension, anytrack; as, the wake of an army.This effect followed immediately in the wake of his earliestexertions. De Quincey.Several humbler persons . . . formed quite a procession in the dustywake of his chariot wheels. Thackeray.

A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish andpellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownishshades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicateof alumina, and is used as a gem.
To carve. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A more or less solid article of confectionery made by boilingsugar or molasses to the desired consistency, and than crystallizing,molding, or working in the required shape. It is often flavored orcolored, and sometimes contains fruit, nuts, etc.
One of the vessels of an animal body by which the products ofglandular secretion are conveyed to their destination.
Same as Nones, 2.
To grow tired; to become exhausted or impatient; as, to wearyof an undertaking.
Of or pertaining to case; as, a casal ending.

Having external ears; having tufts of feathers resembling ears.Eared owl (Zoöl.), an owl having earlike tufts of feathers, as thelong-eared owl, and short-eared owl.-- Eared seal (Zoöl.), any seal of the family Otariidæ, includingthe fur seals and hair seals. See Seal.
Woe. [Obs.]
To look steadfastly; to gaze. [Obs.] [Written also kike, keke.]This Nicholas sat ever gaping upright, As he had kyked on the newemoon. Chaucer.
Angry. [Obs.] Havelok, the Dane.

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonancein the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving toeach several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound ofspeech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whethermade with or without vocality, derives its character in every casefrom some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, aletter or character which represents such a sound. See Guide toPronunciation, §§ 5, 146-149.
Frequently; many times; not seldom.
See Salep.

A cryptogamous plant of a cellular structure, with distinctstem and simple leaves. The fruit is a small capsule usually openingby an apical lid, and so discharging the spores. There are manyspecies, collectively termed Musci, growing on the earth, on rocks,and trunks of trees, etc., and a few in running water.
See Crus.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Grind, Etym: contr. from grindeth.[Obs.] Chaucer.
A variety of carnelian, of a rich reddish yellow or brownishred color. See the Note under Chalcedony.
A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevineFidia, F. longipes) is very injurious to vines in America.
The comic actor in an opera.
A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeralrites; a funeral hymn.The raven croaked, and hollow shrieks of owls Sung dirges at herfuneral. Ford.
The female of the horse and other equine quadrupeds.
The center of an escutcheon.
Destitute of a beard or awn; as, bald wheat.
To operate on as, or by means of, a cathartic medicine, or in asimilar manner.
Azure-colored; of a bright blue color. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
An abyss; a gulf. "The abysm of hell." Shak.
A bigamist. [Obs.]
The state of being bound; imprisonment; captivity, restraint."This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds." Acts xxvi.
See Geat.

A spheroidal body growing from a plant either above or belowthe ground (usually below), which is strictly a bud, consisting of acluster of partially developed leaves, and producing, as it grows, astem above, and roots below, as in the onion, tulip, etc. It differsfrom a corm in not being solid.
An exclamation denoting surprise, or contempt, doubt, etc.
An affirmative vote; one who votes in the affirmative; as, "Tocall for the ayes and noes;" "The ayes have it."

The scales or bracts on the receptacle, which subtend eachflower in the heads of many Compositæ, as the sunflower. Gray. Chaffcutter, a machine for cutting, up straw, etc., into "chaff" for theuse of cattle.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fustic (see Morin); as, moricacid.
The European redwing. [Prov. Eng.] Pop corn. (a) Corn, ormaize, of peculiar excellence for popping; especially, a kind thegrains of which are small and compact. (b) Popped corn; which hasbeen popped.
The bearded seal.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison. [R.] "Venomedvengeance." Shak.
Dewy; bedewed. [R.] T. Granger.
Said. Shak.
The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty. [R.] A. Drummond.Le beau monde Etym: [F.], fashionable society. See Beau monde.-- Demi monde. See Demimonde.
See Koulan.
To go or row in a boat.I boated over, ran my craft aground. Tennyson.
To throw out, as smoke, dust, etc., in puffs. [Scot.]
A sort of table used by printers.
A botch; a patch. [Dial.] Whitlock.
A prefecture or district of the second rank in China, or thechief city of such a district; -- often part of the name of a city,as in Foochow.
See Krems.
A clump of trees in a prairie. [Local, U.S.]
The Canada porcupine. See Porcupine.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandri orpetus) of Florida and the West Indies.
A scurf or scabby disease, especially of the scalp.It is a dry scall, even a leprosy upon the head. Lev. xiii. 30.

Of the nature of, or relating to, a node; as, a nodal point.Nodal line, Nodal point, in a vibrating plate or cord, that line orpoint which remains at rest while the other parts of the body are ina state of vibration.
A minnow.
One of the threads of which the strands of a rope are composed.
To furnish with a helve, as an ax.
To starve; to famish. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
imperative sing. of L. videre, to see; -- used to directattention to something; as, vide supra, see above.
See Jiffy.
Axillary; in the fork or axil. Gray.
A bugbear; false terror. [Obs.] Jonhson.
A gull.
A leaf or division of the calyx.
See Ramie.
To itch. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
A layman. Bp. Morton.

A trick or stratagem practiced for insnaring or deception; asly, insidious; artifice; a beguilement; an allurement.Put on the whole armor of God, that ye may be able to stand againstthe wiles of the devil. Eph. vi. 11.Not more almighty to resist our might, Than wise to frustrate all ourplots and wiles. Milton.
A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islandsto friendly natives.
Look; see; behold; observe. " Lo, here is Christ." Matt. xxiv.23. " Lo, we turn to the Gentiles." Acts xiii. 46.
A beam or rod for holding two parts together; in railways, oneof the transverse timbers which support the track and keep it inplace.
A combining form from L. ter signifying three times, thrice.See Tri-, 2.
To ail. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Equal. [Obs.] Burrill.
a. & n. from Vie.-- Vy"ing*ly, adv.
To follow with violence and trampling. [R.] The Puritan (1607).
Same as Sewen.
Angry; incensed; enraged. [Recent]The irate colonel . . . stood speechless. Thackeray.Mr. Jaggers suddenly became most irate. Dickens.
A cavity in a rock, having its interior surface studded withcrystals and sometimes filled with water; a geode.
pl. of Tooth.
To smear with the white of an egg.
To mind; to regard with care; to take notice of; to attend to;to observe.With pleasure Argus the musician heeds. Dryden.
A corner. [Obs.]Lurking in hernes and in lanes blind. Chaucer.
Infected with the itch, or with an itching sensation. Cowper.
Series. [Obs.]
An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater;-- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
A rent or long aperture; a chink; a fissure; a crack. Sir T.Browne.

To look or gaze steadily in reading or studying; to fix theattention; to be absorbed; -- often with on or upon, and now usuallywith over."Painfully to pore upon a book." Shak.The eye grows weary with poring perpetually on the same thing.Dryden.
See Iguana.
To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the formsof law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. SeeLynch law.

Any one of the numerous species of birds belonging to Garrulus,Cyanocitta, and allied genera. They are allied to the crows, but aresmaller, more graceful in form, often handsomely colored, and usuallyhave a crest.
To steal or pocket game, or to carry it away privately, as in abag; to kill or destroy game contrary to law, especially by night; tohunt or fish unlawfully; as, to poach for rabbits or for salmon.
Therefore; consequently; -- often used in a jocular way. Shak.
A verb suffix signifying to make, to do, to practice; asapologize, baptize, theorize, tyrannize.

The work done by a steam engine or other prime mover whenworking. Load line, or Load water line (Naut.), the line on theoutside of a vessel indicating the depth to which it sinks in thewater when loaded.
The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposedto correspond nearly with our month of June.
To listen. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.

To climb a tree, pole, or the like, by embracing it with thearms and legs alternately. See Shin. [Colloq.]At the top was placed a piece of money, as a prize for those whocould swarm up and seize it. W. Coxe.
Of or pertaining to a former time or state; neither present norfuture; gone by; elapsed; ended; spent; as, past troubles; pastoffences. "Past ages." Milton. Past master. See under Master.

A genus of evergreen trees, thickly branched, remarkable forthe distichous arrangement of their branches, and having scalelike,closely imbricated, or compressed leaves. [Written also thuya.] SeeThyine wood.
One who cries out or gives an alarm; specifically, a balker; aconder. See Balker.
A kind of wine of a deep red color, chiefly from Galicia orMalaga in Spain; -- called also tent wine, and tinta.
Having, or abounding in, fins, as fishes; pertaining to fishes.
A small fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus idus or Idusidus) of Europe. A domesticated variety, colored like the goldfish,is called orfe in Germany.
See Litchi.
One who raves.

An alarm from a real or threatened attack; a sudden attack;also, a bugle sound to give warning. "We have had an alert." Farrow.On the alert, on the lookout or watch against attack or danger; readyto act.
Pertaining to, or resembling, gauze; thin and slight as gauze.
A calculous concretion, especially one in the kidneys orbladder; the disease arising from a calculus.

A thorny tree or shrub of the genus Lawsonia (L. alba). Thefragrant white blossoms are used by the Buddhists in religiousceremonies. The powdered leaves furnish a red coloring matter used inthe East to stain the hails and fingers, the manes of horses, etc.
Same as Nowel.
A species of cherry tree common in Europe (Prunus avium); also,the fruit, which is usually small and dark in color.
An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more musclesor muscular fibers.
Full; having all the instruments.
A plug, or conical block of wood, with longitudital grooves onits surface, in which the strands of the rope slide in the process oftwisting.

An expression used at the end of prayers, and meaning, So beit. At the end of a creed, it is a solemn asseveration of belief.When it introduces a declaration, it is equivalent to truly, verily.It is used as a noun, to demote: (a) concurrence in belief, or in astatement; assent; (b) the final word or act; (c) Christ as being onewho is true and faithful.And let all the people say, Amen. Ps. cvi. 48.Amen, amen, I say to thee, except a man be born again, he can not seethe kingdom of God. John ii. 3. Rhemish Trans.To say amen to, to approve warmly; to concur in heartily oremphatically; to ratify; as, I say Amen to all.
Prussian leather. [Obs.] Dryden.
A silver coin of Ecuador, worth 68 cents.
Having a kell or covering; webbed. [Obs.] Drayton.
Belonging to bees.
To nurse; to lead or teach; to foster; to nuzzle. [Obs.]If any man use the Scripture . . . to nosel thee in anything save inChrist, he is a false prophet. Tyndale.
To dismay; to dishearten; to daunt. [Obs. or Archaic]The Silures, to amate the new general, rumored the overthrow greaterthan was true. Milton.
A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form asalient angle toward the enemy.

To think worthy; to vouchsafe; to condescend; -- followed by aninfinitive.O deign to visit our forsaken seats. Pope.Yet not Lord Cranstone deigned she greet. Sir W. Scott.Round turned he, as not deigning Those craven ranks to see. Macaulay.
A kind of food, made from the almondlike seeds of the IrvingiaBarteri, much used by natives of the west coast of Africa; -- calledalso dika bread.
Low spirits; a fit of despondency; melancholy. [Colloq.] Berlinblue, Prussian blue.-- Mineral blue. See under Mineral.-- Prussian blue. See under Prussian.
Without; as, senza stromenti, without instruments.
See Throse. [Scot.] Burns.
imp. of Upheave. Chaucer.
Reduced; lowered; restrained; as, to speak with bated breath.Macaulay.
To bend like a bow; to curve. "Embowed arches." [Obs. or R.]Sir W. Scott.With gilded horns embowed like the moon. Spenser.
A saddlecloth; a housing. [Obs.] Dryden.
A small fruit that is pulpy or succulent throughout, havingseeds loosely imbedded in the pulp, as the currant, grape, blueberry.
To drop the bait gently on the surface of the water.To catch a club by dapping with a grasshoper. Walton.
To transfer to another person for a pecuniary equivalent; tomake an object of trade; to dispose of by sale; to sell; as, to vendgoods; to vend vegetables.
The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands ofBourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinesetea.
, a. Etym: [Compar. Showier (; superl. Showiest.]
A chimney cap; a cowl
Cease; stop; stay. "Avast heaving." Totten.
The third person singular of the substantive verb be, in theindicative mood, present tense; as, he is; he is a man. See Be.
To smear; to play the flatterer.His conscience . . . will not daub nor flatter. South.
The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A compositor. [Colloq.]
Weak; insipid; tasteless; commonplace. [R.] "Passages that aresomewhat fade." Jeffrey.His masculine taste gave him a sense of something fade and ludicrous.De Quincey.
A roundlet of tincture sanguine, which is blazoned withoutmention of the tincture.
To make dim; to obscure or darken. Shak.

A malicious publication expressed either in print or inwriting, or by pictures, effigies, or other signs, tending to exposeanother to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule. Such publication isindictable at common law.
