A large war canoe of the Society Islands.
To choose [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Aroint.
See Poop, v. i. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Below; in a lower part. "Aloft, and then alow." Dryden.
A Linnean genus of mollusks having a conical shell. See Cone,n., 4.
One who packs boxes.
To throw by means of a hipe. -- Hip"er (#), n.
Saw. Chaucer.

The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or thenumber of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginningof the year. Annual epact, the excess of the solar year over thelunar year, -- being eleven days.-- Menstrual epact, or Monthly epact, the excess of a calendar monthover a lunar.
To send away. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A suffix expressing more strongly than -ance the idea ofquality or state; as, constancy, buoyancy, infancy.
To lop; to snathe. [Prov. Eng.]

A road way. Via Lactea Etym: [L.] (Anat.), the Milky Way, orGalaxy. See Galaxy, 1.-- Via media Etym: [L.] (Theol.), the middle way; -- a name appliedto their own position by the Anglican high-churchmen, as beingbetween the Roman Catholic Church and what they term extremeProtestantism.
Shrill. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
A Hindoo measure of distance, varying from one and a half totwo English miles. Whitworth.
See 2d Fit.
Is not. See Nis. Chaucer. Spenser.
See Laund.
To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as theindigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete bythe lungs, skin, or kidneys.
To free from a dam, mound, or other obstruction. Dryden.
A hill; a cliff. [Obs.] Spenser.
A working beam.
One who lives by shifts and tricks; one who avoids theperformance of duty or labor.

A body of water, naturally or artificially confined, andusually of less extent than a lake. "Through pond or pool." Milton.Pond hen (Zoöl.), the American coot. See Coot (a).-- Pond lily (Bot.), the water lily. See under Water, and Illust.under Nymphæa.-- Pond snail (Zoöl.), any gastropod living in fresh-water ponds orlakes. The most common kinds are air-breathing snails (Pulmonifera)belonging to Limnæa, Physa, Planorbis, and allied genera. Theoperculated species are pectinibranchs, belonging to Melantho,Valvata, and various other genera.-- Pond spice (Bot.), an American shrub (Tetranthera geniculata) ofthe Laurel family, with small oval leaves, and axillary clusters oflittle yellow flowers. The whole plant is spicy. It grows in pondsand swamps from Virginia to Florida.-- Pond tortoise, Pond turtle (Zoöl.), any freshwater tortoise ofthe family Emydidæ. Numerous species are found in North America.

A small nocturnal and arboreal Australian marsupial (Tarsipesrostratus) about the size of a mouse. It has a long muzzle, a longtongue, and very few teeth, and feeds upon honey and insects. Calledalso noolbenger.
Coarse wool on the legs of sheep. Blount.
Same as Pawl.
A plant common in Europe (Paris quadrifolia); herb Paris;truelove. It has been used as a narcotic.
See Glint.
imp. of Tide, v. i. Chaucer.
An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caughtfor the sake of its roe and for its flesh.

A thin nail, usually small, with a slight projection at the topon one side instead of a head; also, a small wire nail, with a flatcircular head; sometimes, a small, tapering, square-bodied finishingnail, with a countersunk head.
The act of rinsing.
Any individual of the swarthy races of Africa or Asia whichhave adopted the Mohammedan religion. "In Spanish history the termsMoors, Saracens, and Arabs are synonymous." Internat. Cyc.
A large, edible, marine fish (Brosmius brosme), allied to thecod, common on the northern coasts of Europe and America; -- calledalso tusk and torsk.
pl. of Elf.
A suffix used to form diminutives; as, bullock, hillock.

To be gentle, agreeable, or coaxing; to talk fondly; to useendearments; also, to be or become obsequiously courteous orcomplimentary; to fawn. "Honeying and making love." Shak.Rough to common men, But honey at the whisper of a lord. Tennyson.
Union by league; alliance. [Obs.]
A drunken condition; a spree. [Slang]
The number six at dice.
Used in English only in the expression en creux. Thus,engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio, or by sinking orhollowing out the design.
To stop or fasten, as with a wedge, or block; to scotch; as, tochock a wheel or cask.
orderly; easily restrained; -- opposed to Ant: unruly. [Obs.]Gascoigne.
A saint. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekelsof gold and sixty shekels of silver. Ezek. xlv. 12.

The specific signification of in is situation or place withrespect to surrounding, environment, encompassment, etc. It is usedwith verbs signifying being, resting, or moving within limits, orwithin circumstances or conditions of any kind conceived of aslimiting, confining, or investing, either wholly or in part. In itsdifferent applications, it approaches some of the meanings of, andsometimes is interchangeable with, within, into, on, at, of, andamong. It is used: --
A badger.Or with pretense of chasing thence the brock. B. Jonson.
Palm leaves, prepared for being written upon with a stylepointed with steel. [Written also ola.] Balfour (Cyc. of India).
Against; also, towards (in order to meet). [Obs.]Albeit that it is again his kind. Chaucer.

The external covering or coat, as of flesh, fruit, trees, etc.;skin; hide; bark; peel; shell.Thou canst not touch the freedom of my mind With all thy charms,although this corporal rind Thou hast immanacled. Milton.Sweetest nurind. Shak.
To dig or labor with a spade, or as with a spade; to labor as adrudge.Delve may I not: I shame to beg. Wyclif (Luke xvi. 3).
A bullfinch. [Prov. Eng.]

To introduce or escort, as an usher, forerunner, or harbinger;to forerun; -- sometimes followed by in or forth; as, to usher in astranger; to usher forth the guests; to usher a visitor into theroom.The stars that usher evening rose. Milton.The Examiner was ushered into the world by a letter, setting forththe great genius of the author. Addison.
To turn up or to dig out with the snout; as, the swine rootsthe earth.
Delight. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A person who knowingly utters falsehood; one who lies.
A sort of wax used in grafting, etc.
To cut through, as a partition between one working and another.
Displayed; spread out; turned outward; hence, flat; ungainly;as, splay shoulders.Sonwthing splay, something blunt-edged, unhandy, and infelicitous. M.Arnold.
Resembling, or consisting of, snares; entangling; insidious.Spiders in the vault their snary webs have spread. Dryden.
A chain by which a leading horse draws a plow. Knight.
A thorny evergreen shrub (Ulex Europæus), with beautiful yellowflowers, very common upon the plains and hills of Great Britain; --called also gorse, and whin. The dwarf furze is Ulex nanus.

Of or pertaining to the bony or cartilaginous arch whichsupports the tongue. Sometimes applied to the tongue itself. Hyoidarch (Anat.), the arch of cartilaginous or bony segments, whichconnects the base of the tongue with either side of the skull.-- Hyoid bone (Anat.), the bone in the base of the tongue, themiddle part of the hyoid arch.
A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.
To joust. Fairfax.
To allot; to sort; to portion. [R.] To lot on or upon, to countor reckon upon; to expect with pleasure. [Colloq. U. S.]
3d pers. sing. pres. of Ta, to take.

A prefix signifying in or into, used in many English words,chiefly those borrowed from the French. Some English words arewritten indifferently with en- or in-. For ease of pronunciation itis commonly changed to em- before p, b, and m, as in employ, embody,emmew. It is sometimes used to give a causal force, as in enable,enfeeble, to cause to be, or to make, able, or feeble; and sometimesmerely gives an intensive force, as in enchasten. See In-.
A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, orotherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order toseparete the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.
Full of mast; abounding in acorns, etc.
The Barbary ape.
See Plait.
A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to theshield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; aprotection.
Low; mean; boorish; vagabond. "Such pady persons." Digges(1585). "The paddy persons." Motley.
To fight; to scuffle; to box.While the peers cuff to make the rabble sport. Dryden.
To smother; to suffocate; to choke. [Obs.] Holinshed.Palsgrave.
One. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternatelyroasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal fromassociated iron ores, and called coarse metal, fine metal, etc.,according to the grade of fineness. On the exterior it is dark brownor black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
To break in pieces; to crack. [Obs.] "The pot was crased."Chaucer.
To remove a bar or bars from; to unbolt; to open; as, to unbara gate. Heber.
imp. & p. p. of Beget.

A modern transliteration of the Hebrew word translated Jehovahin the Bible; -- used by some critics to discriminate the tribal godof the ancient Hebrews from the Christian Jehovah. Yahweh or Yahwe isthe spelling now generally adopted by scholars.
Same as Yolk.
Low land overflowed, or covered wholly or partially with water,but producing sedge, coarse grasses, or other aquatic plants; boggyland; moor; marsh.'Mid reedy fens wide spread. Wordsworth.
A contorted knot in wood; a crossgrained protuberance; anodule; a boss or projection.
See Verst.
A peculiar larval stage of certain decapod Crustacea,especially of crabs and certain Anomura. [Written also zoæa.]

A suffix used to denote: (a) The nonmetallic, or negative,element or radical in a binary compound; as, oxide, sulphide,chloride. (b) A compound which is an anhydride; as, glycolide,phthalide. (c) Any one of a series of derivatives; as, indogenide,glucoside, etc.

Consisting of flakes or of small, loose masses; lying, orcleaving off, in flakes or layers; flakelike.What showers of mortal hail, what flaky fires! Watts.A flaky weight of winter's purest snows. Wordsworth.
A tuft of hair on the mandibles.

To flow in a small stream, or in drops rapidly succeeding eachother; to trickle. Sir W. Scott.And now and then an ample tear trilled down Her delicate cheek. Shak.Whispered sounds Of waters, trilling from the riven stone. Glover.
Four and one added; one more than four.
Dark; obscure; gloomy. "The murkiest den." Shak.A murky deep lowering o'er our heads. Addison.
The possessive case of the personal pronoun they; as, theirhouses; their country.
The common newt or eft. In America often applied to severalspecies of aquatic salamanders. [Written also evat.]

A missile weapon of offense, slender, pointed, and usuallyfeathered and barbed, to be shot from a bow. Broad arrow. (a) Anarrow with a broad head. (b) A mark placed upon British ordnance andgovernment stores, which bears a rude resemblance to a broadarrowhead.
A narrow lane or alley. [Scot.] Jamieson.The narrow wynds, or alleys, on each side of the street. Bryant.
See Tarn. Coleridge.
imp. & p. p. of Weep.

Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginoussubstances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation ofgums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric withsaccharic acid.
To become untied or loosed.
Worse. [Obs.]They say the world is much warre than it wont. Spenser.
To worship; to glorify; to praise. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
See Foot.
An infant or young child of either sex; a babe.
A slight fit of peevishness or fretfulness. "In a pet shestarted up." Tennyson.
A guest. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A small South American dog, domesticated by the aborigines.
A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing 2.37 gills. W. H. Ward.
A West Indian plant (Indigofera anil), one of the originalsources of indigo; also, the indigo dye.

Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to thegenus Mus and various related genera of the family Muridæ. The commonhouse mouse (Mus musculus) is found in nearly all countries. TheAmerican white-footed, or deer, mouse (Hesperomys leucopus) sometimeslives in houses. See Dormouse, Meadow mouse, under Meadow, andHarvest mouse, under Harvest.
A kind of bandage passing, by successive turns and crosses,from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance toa spike of a barley.

A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of anaromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste. It is valued forits odor and for its medicinal properties. It exuds from the bark ofa shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Balsamodendron Myrrha. The myrrhof the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, andpartly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose. False myrrh.See the Note under Bdellium.
See Fogy.
A cap for retaining anything, as a journal box, in place. Totake keep, to take care; to heed. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The amorphous or homogenous matrix or ground mass, asdistinguished from well-defined crystals; as, the magma of porphyry.
The serum, or watery part, of milk, separated from the morethick or coagulable part, esp. in the process of making cheese. Inthis process, the thick part is called curd, and the thin part whey.
Having color; -- usually in composition; as, bright-hued; many-hued. Chaucer.
A sea fish. See Hake. Ash.

The skin of the squirrel, much used in the fourteenth centuryas fur for garments, and frequently mentioned by writers of thatperiod in describing the costly dresses of kings, nobles, andprelates. It is represented in heraldry by a series of small shieldsplaced close together, and alternately white and blue. Fairholt.No vair or ermine decked his garment. Sir W. Scott.Counter vair (Her.), a fur resembling vair, except in the arrangementof the patches or figures.
To dress; to prink; -used humorously or in contempt. Dryden.
pl. pres. of Wit. Chaucer.
Liquid in which flesh (and sometimes other substances, asbarley or rice) has been boiled; thin or simple soup.I am sure by your unprejudiced discourses that you love broth betterthan soup. Addison.
Father; -- a word sometimes used by children.I was never so bethumped withwords, Since I first called my brother'sfather dad. Shak.
Wet; soaky. [Prov. Eng.]
A fixed star, in Medusa's head, in the constellation Perseus,remarkable for its periodic variation in brightness.
To pay; to satisfy or appease. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
The musk deer. See Musk deer (below).
Any bird of certain genera, as Urinator (formerly Colymbus), orthe allied genus Colymbus, or Podiceps, remarkable for their agilityin diving.
To make hot; to flush. [Poetic]Fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they didcool. Shak.
Half an em, that is, half of the unit of space in measuringprinted matter. See Em.
See Steen. Spenser.
The oval or roundish body laid by domestic poultry and otherbirds, tortoises, etc. It consists of a yolk, usually surrounded bythe "white" or albumen, and inclosed in a shell or strong membrane.
Fermented wort used for making vinegar. Gyle tan (Brewing), alarge vat in which wort ferments.
To hew in pieces. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine,or to impart nourishment. Hoblyn.
One who worships false goods; an idolater; a heathen; one whois neither a Christian, a Mohammedan, nor a Jew.Neither having the accent of Christians, nor the gait of Christian,pagan, nor man. Shak.
A kind of difficult dance; a dance tune, the air of which hastwo brisk and lively, yet dignified, strains in common time, eachplayed twice over. [Written also gavotte.]
Shale or bituminous shale. Kirwan.
To dismiss, let go, or release. [Obs.]
A piece of ground inclosed, and stored with beasts of thechase, which a man may have by prescription, or the king's grant.Mozley & W.

To move of draw (a sail or yard) by means of the clew garnets,clew lines, etc.; esp. to draw up the clews of a square sail to theyard. To clew down (Naut.), to force (a yard) down by hauling on theclew lines.-- To clew up (Naut.), to draw (a sail) up to the yard, as forfurling.
Of or pertaining to the island Scio (Chio or Chios).-- n.

A colored, usually green, expansion growing from the side of astem or rootstock, in which the sap for the use of the plant iselaborated under the influence of light; one of the parts of a plantwhich collectively constitute its foliage.
Knee. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Solely. [Obs.] Spenser.
Like. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A cabin on the after part of the quarterdeck, usually occupiedby the captain. [Written also couch.] [Obs.]The commanders came on board and the council sat in the coach. Pepys.

Of a character which enables the compositor to make largewages; -- said of matter containing blank, cuts, or many leads, etc.;as, a fat take; a fat page. Fat lute, a mixture of pipe clay and oilfor filling joints.
A bandage or apparatus used in cases of hernia, to keep up thereduced parts and hinder further protrusion, and for other purposes.
Any one of several species of small fresh-water ducks of thegenus Anas and the subgenera Querquedula and Nettion. The male ishandsomely colored, and has a bright green or blue speculum on thewings.
pret. of Carve. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A little island.

To cut off the nip or neb of, or to cut off at once with shearsor scissors; to clip off suddenly; to nip; hence, to break off; tosnatch away.Curbed and snipped in my younger years by fear of my parents fromthose vicious excrescences to which that age was subject. Fuller.The captain seldom ordered anything out of the ship's stores . . .but I snipped some of it for my own share. De Foe.
The act of shoving; a forcible push.I rested . . . and then gave the boat another shove. Swift.

A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action ofbromine on fluoresceïn, and named from the fine rose-red which itimparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Itssolution is fluorescent.
A signal, by drum or trumpet, for extinguishing all lights insoldiers' quarters and retiring to bed, -- usually given about aquarter of an hour after tattoo. Wilhelm.
A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21, never existing alone, butregarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compoundsof the paraffin series.
A treenail to fasten the shores.
A student of the first year.
Dismal; gloomy with solitude. "A drear and dying sound."Milton.
A genus of transparent, tubular, free-swimming oceanictunicates found abundantly in all the warmer latitudes. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
Downy; fluffy. [R.]
The European carrion crow.

A tree (Carica Papaya) of tropical America, belonging to theorder Passifloreæ. It has a soft, spongy stem, eighteen or twentyfeet high, crowned with a tuft of large, long-stalked, palmatelylobed leaves. The milky juice of the plant is said to have theproperty of making meat tender. Also, its dull orange-colored, melon-shaped fruit, which is eaten both raw and cooked or pickled.
An iambus or iambic. [R.]
Not of; nor of. [Obs.]
imp. of Sweat. Chaucer.
A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking. Cigar fish (Zoöl.),a fish (Decapterus punctatus), allied to the mackerel, found on thecoast of the Gulf of Mexico.

The whole number, quantity, or amount; the entire thing;everything included or concerned; the aggregate; the whole; totality;everything or every person; as, our all is at stake.Death, as the Psalmist saith, is certain to all. Shak.All that thou seest is mine. Gen. xxxi. 43.
To range or place in a line; to bring into line; to align.Evelyn.

A thickening of the epidermis at some point, esp. on the toees,by friction or pressure. It is usually painful and troublesome.Welkome, gentlemen! Ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns,will have a bout with you. Shak.
A name sometimes given to that dialect of the Celtic which isspoken in the Highlands of Scotland; -- called, by the Highlanders,Gaelic.
A fungus (Ustilago foetida) which affects the ear of cereals,filling the grains with a fetid dust; -- also called pepperbrand.
The top of the head; the head or noll. [Obs.] Spenser.
Woke. Chaucer.

The legal declaration of a person's mind as to the manner inwhich he would have his property or estate disposed of after hisdeath; the written instrument, legally executed, by which a man makesdisposition of his estate, to take effect after his death; testament;devise. See the Note under Testament, 1.
imp. of Run.
A prefix used frequently in composition, signifying well, good,advantageous; -- the opposite of dys-.

A support or supporter; a stay; a prop. [Obs.]If a be to climb trees that are of any great height, there would bestays and appuies set to it. Holland.Point d'appui. Etym: [F., a point of support.] (Mil.) (a) A givenpoint or body, upon which troops are formed, or by which are marchedin line or column. (b) An advantageous defensive support, as acastle, morass, wood, declivity, etc.
See Haulm, straw.

To stop to take a portion of food and drink for refreshment ofone's self or one's beasts, on a journey.Evil news rides post, while good news baits. Milton.My lord's coach conveyed me to Bury, and thence baiting aEvelyn.
Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation; -- formerly, byconfusion, used to designate lactic acid.
A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris. SeeBrassica. [Writen also naphew.]
A support for the spear when couched for the attack. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Having life; -- used only in composition; as, long-lived;short-lived.

The second person singular, indicative mode, present tense, ofthe substantive verb Be; but formed after the analogy of the pluralare, with the ending -t, as in thou shalt, wilt, orig. an ending ofthe second person sing. pret. Cf. Be. Now used only in solemn orpoetical style.
A partially compacted bed of gravel mixed with shells, of theTertiary age.
A prefix used adjectively and adverbially in the sense ofamiss, wrong, ill, wrongly, unsuitably; as, misdeed, mislead,mischief, miscreant.
A tract of land shaped like the letter delta (as, the delta ofthe Ganges, of the Nile, or of the Mississippi.
A tiger. [Obs.]
To bark; to yelp. L'Estrange.
Enjoyment of property; use. Mozley & W.
Any one of several species of large marine gastropods belongingto the genus Yetus, or Cymba; a boat shell.
To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle.
One of the elements which appear at the respective poles when abody is subjected to electro-chemical decomposition. Cf. Anion,Cation.
To manifest sullenness; to sulk. [Colloq.]
One who gazes.
Having to do with shipping; of or pertaining to ships or anavy; consisting of ships; as, naval forces, successes, stores, etc.
A coarse umbelliferous plant (Ligusticum actæifolium) with alarge aromatic root. It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region.Also called Angelico.

Persons added to a jury, commonly from those in or about thecourthouse, to make up any deficiency in the number of jurorsregularly summoned, being like, or such as, the latter. Blount.Blackstone. (b) syntactically sing.
A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europeand in Africa.
Wicked. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A quagmire. [R.] "Crooked or straight, through quags or thornydells." Cowper.

A large, esculent, farinaceous tuber of various climbing plantsof the genus Dioscorea; also, the plants themselves. Mostly nativesof warm climates. The plants have netted-veined, petioled leaves, andpods with three broad wings. The commonest species is D. sativa, butseveral others are cultivated. Chinese yam, a plant (DioscoreaBatatas) with a long and slender tuber, hardier than most of theother species.-- Wild yam. (a) A common plant (Dioscorea villosa) of the EasternUnited States, having a hard and knotty rootstock. (b) Anorchidaceous plant (Gastrodia sesamoides) of Australia and Tasmania.
Changeable; fickle. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To cause to rest by soothing influences; to compose; to calm;to soothe; to quiet. " To lull him soft asleep." Spenser.Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie, To lull the daughters ofnecessity. Milton.
A shaft excavated from below upward.
The external membranous integument of an animal.
Lethean. [Obs.] Marston.

The egg of a louse or other small insect. Nit grass (Bot.), apretty annual European grass (Gastridium lendigerum), with smallspikelets somewhat resembling a nit. It is also found in Californiaand Chili.
A fruit tree (D. zibethinus, the only species known) of theIndian Archipelago. It bears the durian.
To sneak. [Prov. Eng.]
One in whom the property of an estate is vested, subject to theestate of a life renter.I am fiar of the lands; she a life renter. Sir W. Scott.
A pointed instrument used to urge on a beast; hence, anynecessity that urges or stimulates.The daily goad urging him to the daily toil. Macaulay.
To engage in mock combat on horseback, as two knights in thelists; to tilt. [Written also just.]For the whole army to joust and tourney. Holland.
Won. Chaucer.
See Krang.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Tread, for treadeth. Chaucer.
Away. [Obs. or Archaic] Chaucer. To do way, to take away; toremove. [Obs.] "Do way your hands." Chaucer.-- To make way with, to make away with. See under Away. [Archaic]
Early. [Obs.]Rude mechanicals that rare and late Work in the market place.Chapman.

Any one of a great variety of unctuous combustible substances,not miscible with water; as, olive oil, whale oil, rock oil, etc.They are of animal, vegetable, or mineral origin and of variedcomposition, and they are variously used for food, for solvents, foranointing, lubrication, illumination, etc. By extension, anysubstance of an oily consistency; as, oil of vitriol.
A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the EastIndies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
A sandpiper (Terekia cinerea) of the Old World, breeding in thefar north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africaand Australia. It frequents rivers.
Same as Lif.
Washy; weak. [Obs.]Their bodies of so weak and wash a temper. Beau. & Fl.
A sign. See Al segno, and Dal segno.
The past or preterit tense of Arise.
See Paunch.
A bough or branch; a twig. [Obs.]As white as is the blossom upon the ris. Chaucer.
To make sorrowful; to sadden. [Obs.]How it sadded the minister's spirits! H. Peters.
A valley or low place; a tract of low, and usually wet, land; amoor; a fen. [Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S.]
To walk sidewise. [Obs.] L'Estrange.

Out of the common path; aside; -- used in composition, givingthe meaning of something aside, secondary, or incidental, orcollateral matter, a thing private or avoiding notice; as, by-line,by-place, by-play, by-street. It was formerly more freely used incomposition than it is now; as, by-business, by-concernment, by-design, by-interest, etc.

A composition treating of any particular subject; -- usuallyshorter and less methodical than a formal, finished treatise; as, anessay on the life and writings of Homer; an essay on fossils, or oncommerce.
A silk thread formed of two or more threads twisted together,used especially for the weft, or cross threads, of the best qualityof velvets and silk goods.
A basin at the entrance of Roman Catholic churches forcontaining the holy water with which those who enter, dipping theirfingers in it, cross themselves; -- called also holy-water stoup.
A suffix used in medical terms to denote a morbid condition ofsome part, usually some kind of tumor; as in fibroma, glaucoma.
See Ooze. [Obs.]

A gambling game at cardds, in whiich all the other players playagainst the dealer or banker, staking their money upon the order inwhich the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack. Faro bank, thecapital which the proprietor of a farotable ventures in the game;also, the place where a game of faro is played. Hoyle.
The dziggetai.
A prefix meaning against, opposite or opposed to, contrary, orin place of; -- used in composition in many English words. It isoften shortened to ant-; as, antacid, antarctic.
Day. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The last and worst of the four ages of the world; -- consideredto have begun B. C. 3102, and to last 432,000 years.
Silence; hush. [Obs.] Chaucer.
of Do.
A small jug, pitcher, or mug, generally used for ale, shapedsomewhat like a stout man, with a cocked hat forming the brim.
To howl. [Obs.] Wyclif.

A large European scaraboid beetle (Geotrupes stercorarius),which makes a droning noise while flying. The name is also applied toallied American species, as the June bug. Called also dorr,dorbeetle, or dorrbeetle, dorbug, dorrfly, and buzzard clock.
That part of the pistil which contains the seed, and in mostflowering plants develops into the fruit. See Illust. of Flower.

A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the faceof a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the facepale with hunger. Some writers mention two, others three.Both table and provisions vanished guite. With sound of harpies'wings and talons heard. Milton.
See Inlay.
See Cottise.
Sweet.
To clean from lice. "You sat and loused him." Swift.
As much as is taken up between the thumb and two first fingers.[Obs.] Bacon.
To act or perform a second time; to do over again; as, to reacta play; the same scenes were reacted at Rome.

To appear, or to appear to be; to have a show or semblance; topresent an appearance; to look; to strike one's apprehension or fancyas being; to be taken as. "It now seemed probable." Macaulay.Thou picture of what thou seem'st. Shak.All seemed well pleased; all seemed, but were not all. Milton.There is a way which seemeth right unto a man; but the end thereofare the ways of death. Prov. xiv. 12.It seems, it appears; it is understood as true; it is said.A prince of Italy, it seems, entertained his misstress on a greatlake. Addison.
pl. of Foe. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Dev.
Composed of scales lying over each other; as, a scaly bulb;covered with scales; as, a scaly stem. Scaly ant-eater (Zoöl.), thepangolin.
Orblike; having the course of an orb; revolving. [Obs.] "Orbyhours." Chapman.
Deaf. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and isoften rowed by women. Called also tankia. S. W. Williams.
Lower by a semitone; flat; as, E molle, that is, E flat.
imp. of Sing.
Same as Rotche.
A small foxlike animal (Vulpes cama) of South Africa, valuedfor its fur.

To run away, or escape privately, from the place or station towhich one is bound by duty; -- said especially of a woman or a man,either married or unmarried, who runs away with a paramour or asweetheart.Great numbers of them [the women] have eloped from their allegiance.Addison.
Continually. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Fitly; seasonably. Barrow.
To play the duke. [Poetic]Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence. Shak.
Wist not; knew not. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Crooked. [Obs.]
See 4th Crowd.
An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamedbase and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which driesup, forming a blackish crust.
A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere. [Obs.]
See Sourkrout.

A husband; as, baron and feme, husband and wife. [R.] Cowell.Baron of beef, two sirloins not cut asunder at the backbone.-- Barons of the Cinque Ports, formerly members of the House ofCommons, elected by the seven Cinque Ports, two for each port.-- Baron of the exchequer, the judges of the Court of Exchequer, oneof the three ancient courts of England, now abolished.
Cold; very cold; frozen. "Gelid founts." Thompson.
; sing. Iowa. (Ethnol.) A tribe of Indians which formerlyoccupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
To mix; to mingle. [R.]Amongst her tears immixing prayers meek. Spenser.
A wild cat (Felis eyra) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas.It is reddish yellow and about the size of the domestic cat, but witha more slender body and shorter legs.
A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of whichhas been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or alittle short of 10 years. Brande & C.
A bearing worn, not upon the shield, but usually above it, orseparately as an ornament for plate, liveries, and the like. It is arelic of the ancient cognizance. See Cognizance, 4.
A body of Hindoo literature containing aphorisms on grammar,meter, law, and philosophy, and forming a connecting link between theVedic and later Sanscrit literature. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
A shortened form of Papa.
An African anthropoid ape, supposed to be a variety of thechimpanzee.
A burn, or injury to the skin or flesh, by some hot liquid, orby steam.
A loose wench; a disreputable sweetheart. Shak.
A looseness; diarrhea.
The ichneumon.
A hollow water-cooled iron casting in the upper part of thearchway in which the dam stands.
See Cuish.
pl. of Beau.
On land; to the land; ashore. "Cast aland." Sir P. Sidney.
A combination of tones simultaneously performed, producing moreor less perfect harmony, as, the common chord.
To wrap the head of in a hood. [Obs.] Shak.
The small part of a gunstock near the lock, which is grasped bythe hand in taking aim.
To twirl; to turn or wind round; to coil; as, to querl a cord,thread, or rope. [Local, U.S.]
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of theservile classes; a churl.
A large South American serpent (Boa aboma).
One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on theback of the fronds of ferns.
of Arise, for ariseth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A kind of turnip. See Navew.

To apply (one line or surface) to another without slipping; tobring all the parts of (one line or surface) into successive contactwith another, in suck manner that at every instant the parts thathave been in contact are equal.
A simpleton; a dunce; a lout. [Colloq.]
Something used for taking hold or holding; a catch; a loop; abutton. [Obs.] Ex. xxvi. 6.
Easily bent; pliable. Lithy tree (Bot.), a European shrub(Viburnum Lantana); -- so named from its tough and flexible stem.
To go; to walk.
A round hill or point of land; hence, Morro castle, a castle ona hill.
Cast down; crushed by misery; dejected. [Obs.]
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essentialresidue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octylalcohol.
Strife; contention. [Obs.] Shak.
A curve of the third degree. Circular cubic. See underCircular.
The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and thetrunk. See Femur.
A genus of lichens, most of the species of which have long,gray, pendulous, and finely branched fronds. Usnea barbata is thecommon bearded lichen which grows on branches of trees in northernforests.
To ornament with figured work, as the side of a stocking.
A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costumeis worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to thoseof the peacock. [Written also pavane, paven, pavian, and pavin.]
To make a dent upon; to indent.The houses dented with bullets. Macaulay.
A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
To make like a bow; to curve; to arch; to vault; to embow."Imbowed windows." Bacon.
The letter Z; -- called also zee, and formerly izzard. "Zed,thou unnecessary letter!" Shak.
To take possession of by virtue of a warrant or other legalauthority; as, the sheriff seized the debtor's goods.
A kind of baboon; the wanderoo.
See Wray. [Obs.] Chaucer.

One hostile to another; one who hates, and desires or attemptsthe injury of, another; a foe; an adversary; as, an enemy of or to aperson; an enemy to truth, or to falsehood.To all good he enemy was still. Spenser.I say unto you, Love your enemies. Matt. v. 44.The enemy (Mil.), the hostile force. In this sense it is construedwith the verb and pronoun either in the singular or the plural, butmore commonly in the singular; as, we have met the enemy and he isours or they are ours.It was difficult in such a country to track the enemy. It wasimpossible to drive him to bay. Macaulay.
Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast tp supportthe trestletrees.
An evil. See Mala.

A stringed musical instrument formerly in use, of the same formas the violin, but larger, and having six strings, to be struck witha bow, and the neck furnished with frets for stopping the strings.Me softer airs befit, and softer strings Of lute, or viol still, moreapt for mournful things. Milton.

An American thrush (Turdus fuscescens) common in the NorthernUnited States and Canada. It is light tawny brown above. The breastis pale buff, thickly spotted with brown. Called also Wilson'sthrush.Sometimes I hear the veery's clarion. Thoreau.
Fatigued; worn with labor or hardship. [Obs. or Local] Mir. forMag.
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip ofdogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. SeeIllust. of Bloodhound.
To see; to spy. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to theancient corselet.
To pack or stow, as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve.
[See Axial.] [R.]
Characterized by copses. "Copsy villages." "Copsy banks." J.Dyer.
See Poky.
In an ample manner.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet hasceased to cause coagulation. Brande & C.
To dip. [Obs.] Walton.
Reign. [Obs.] Spenser.
Of recent origin or introduction; not ancient; new; hence, outof the ordinary course; unusual; strange; surprising.
An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angelsand saints as the servants of God.
Nose. [Obs.] Piers plowman.
See Piece.

To effect a grasp; to make the motion of grasping; to clutch;to struggle; to strive.As one that grasped And tugged for life and was by strength subdued.Shak.To grasp at, to catch at; to try to seize; as, Alexander grasped atuniversal empire,
One of the large beads in the rosary at which the paternosteris recited. [Obs.] Gower.
A perforated pasteboard or sheet-metal plate for warp threads,making part of the Jacquard apparatus of a loom. See Jacquard.
The fiber by which the petioles of the date palm are boundtogether, from which various kinds of cordage are made.
The European starling. [Prov. Eng.]
The magpie. See Piet.
To pass a rope round, as a cask, gun, etc., preparatory toattaching a hoisting or lowering tackle.
A secluded and narrow valley; a dale; a depression betweenhills.And wooes the widow's daughter of the glen. Spenser.

Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of thefamily Ardeidæ. The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs andtoes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common Europeanheron (Ardea cinerea) is remarkable for its directly ascendingflight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.Wharton.
Dead. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Niter.
At, to, or from a great distance; far away; -- often used withfrom preceding, or off following; as, he was seen from afar; I sawhim afar off.The steep where Fame's proud temple shines afar. Beattie.
A channel of curved section; -- usually applied to one of avertical series of such channels used to decorate columns andpilasters in classical architecture. See Illust. under Base, n.
The fold of membrane loaded with fat, which covers more or lessof the intestines in mammals; the great omentum See Omentum.The caul serves for warming of the lower belly. Ray.
The common American toadfish; -- so called from a markingresembling the Greek letter tau (t). Tau cross. See Illust. 6, ofCross.
Chapped; cracked with cold; affected with chilblains; as kibedheels. Beau. & Fl.
A basket made of rushes, used chiefly for containing figs andraisins.
A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn.Eriodendron anfractuosum), a bombaceous tree of the East and WestIndies.
The hooded merganser. [Local, U.S.]
Having the power of affecting the organs of taste; possessingsavor, or flavor.Camels, to make the water sapid, do raise the mud with their feet.Sir T. Browne.
Any substance in the gaseous, or aëriform, state, the conditionof which is ordinarily that of a liquid or solid.
To smear; to anoint. [Obs.] Shak.
The seventh month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answeringto a part of September with a part of October.
A small owl; especially, the European species (Athene noctua),and the California flammulated owlet (Megascops flammeolus). Owletmoth (Zoöl.), any noctuid moth.

The Hebrew prophet, who was cast overboard as one whoendangered the ship; hence, any person whose presence isunpropitious. Jonah crab (Zoöl.), a large crab (Cancer borealis) ofthe eastern coast of the United States, sometimes found betweentides, but usually in deep water.
The soja, a kind of bean. See Soja.
A bullfinch. Rom. of R.

To acquire knowledge or skill; to make progress in acquiringknowledge or skill; to receive information or instruction; as, thischild learns quickly.Take my yoke upon you and learn of me. Matt. xi. 29.To learn by heart. See By heart, under Heart.-- To learn by rote, to memorize by repetition without exercise ofthe understanding.
The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also abrood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence orresting place perched like an eagle's nest.
A basket; a hammer; a pannier. [Obs.] Halliwell.
A ball which has passed through all the hoops and would go outif it hit the stake but is continued in play; also, the player ofsuch a ball.
Tense.

One of several marked phases or periods in the development andgrowth of many animals and plants; as, the larval stage; pupa stage;zoea stage. Stage box, a box close to the stage in a theater.-- Stage carriage, a stagecoach.-- Stage door, the actor's and workmen's entrance to a theater.-- Stage lights, the lights by which the stage in a theater isilluminated.-- Stage micrometer, a graduated device applied to the stage of amicroscope for measuring the size of an object.-- Stage wagon, a wagon which runs between two places for conveyingpassengers or goods.-- Stage whisper, a loud whisper, as by an actor in a theater,supposed, for dramatic effect, to be unheard by one or more of hisfellow actors, yet audible to the audience; an aside. stage of thegame, [Colloq.] stage n. 10.
To welk, or wither. [Obs.]
The lowest of the three divisions of the Jurassic period; aname given in England and Europe to a series of marine limestonesunderlying the Oölite. See the Chart of Geology.
Such. [Scot.]
To lose. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any plant of the composite genus Tanacetum. The common tansy(T. vulgare) has finely divided leaves, a strong aromatic odor, and avery bitter taste. It is used for medicinal and culinary purposes.
The twelfth month of the Hebrew ecclesiastical year, and thesixth of the civil. It corresponded nearly with March.
Full of dung; filthy; vile; low. Shak.
Having a pile or point; pointed. [Obs.] "Magus threw a spearwell piled." Chapman.
To pierce. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehended.

Lying toward the north; situated at the north, or in a northerndirection from the point of observation or reckoning; proceedingtoward the north, or coming from the north. North following. SeeFollowing, a., 2.-- North pole, that point in the heavens, or on the earth, ninetydegrees from the equator toward the north.-- North preceding. See Following, a., 2.-- North star, the star toward which the north pole of the earthvery nearly points, and which accordingly seems fixed and immovablein the sky. The star a (alpha) of the Little Bear, is our presentnorth star, being distant from the pole about 1º 25', and from yearto year approaching slowly nearer to it. It is called also Cynosura,polestar, and by astronomers, Polaris.
A Japanese coin, worth about one half of a cent.
A general name applied to various insects belonging to theHemiptera; as, the squash bug; the chinch bug, etc.
See Skein. [Obs.]

Any one numerous species of large marine gastropods belongingto Buccinum and allied genera; especially, Buccinum undatum, commonon the coasts both of Europe and North America, and much used as foodin Europe. Whelk tingle, a dog whelk. See under Dog.
A copper coin, used in the Ionian Islands, about one cent invalue.
A boundary. See Mere. [Obs.]
One who rates or estimates.
A sword. [Obs.]
Opening into two or more parts or shoots; forked; furcated."Forky tongues." Pope.
A European bird of the Crow family (Corvus monedula), oftennesting in church towers and ruins; a jackdaw.The loud daw, his throat displaying, draw The whole assembly of hisfellow daws. Waller.
A fragrant kind of green tea. Hyson skin, the light andinferior leaves separated from the hyson by a winnowing machine.M'Culloch.
A unit of cubic measure in the metric system, being a cubicmeter, or kiloliter, and equal to 35.3 cubic feet, or nearly 1
One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tunemusical instruments.
One of the bladders or air vessels of certain algæ, as of thegreat kelp of the Pacific, and common rockweeds (Fuci) of our shores.D. C. Eaton.
The plural of that. See That.
A union of two; duality. [R.] Harris.
A nickname for a policeman; -- from Sir Robert Peel, whoremodeled the police force. See Peeler. [Slang, Eng.] Dickens.
Overgrown with ivy.
Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging toSargus, Pomodasys, and related genera; -- called also sar, andsaragu.
Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situatedin the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great bloodvessels; -- opposed to neural.
A climbing species of Clematis (C. Vitalba).
A body of coal left to sustain an overhanding mass.
Black and blue; grayish blue; of a lead color; discolored, asflesh by contusion. Cowper.There followed no carbuncles, no purple or livid spots, the mass ofthe blood not being tainted. Bacon.

To suffer loss, disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp.as the result of any kind of contest.We 'll . . . hear poor rogues Talk of court news; and we'll talk withthem too, Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out. Shak.

To rest with confidence, as when fully satisfied of theveracity, integrity, or ability of persons, or of the certainty offacts or of evidence; to have confidence; to trust; to depend; --with on, formerly also with in.Go in thy native innocence; rely On what thou hast of virtue. Milton.On some fond breast the parting soul relies. Gray.
Any curiosity or article of virtu.The busy world, which does not hunt poets as collectors hunt forcurios. F. Harrison.
Variant of Huke. [Obs.]
. A combining form from the Greek private, personal, peculiar,distinct.
To checker; to diversify. [R. & Poet.]The painted windows, frecking gloom with glow. Lowell.
See Aret. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A hill. [Obs.]
imp. & p. p. of Hide. See Hidden.
To cause to ooze. Alex. Smith.
Truly. See Parde. [Obs.]Ah, dame! perdy ye have not done me right. Spenser.
To affect by groans.
of Lead. Led captain. An obsequious follower or attendant.[Obs.] Swift.-- Led horse, a sumpter horse, or a spare horse, that is led along.
A mine; a quarry; a pit dug; a ditch. [Written also delft, anddelve.] [Obs.]The delfts would be so flown with waters, that no gins or machinescould . . . keep them dry. Ray.
One who hews.
A flirt. [Obs.] Quarles.
The siamang; -- called also ungka ape.
Any large blackish seaweed.
Misty; gloomy. [Obs.]Light thickens, and the crow Makes wing to the rooky wood. Shak.
The East Indian tapir. See Tapir.

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire,made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burningsome time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood dipped at one end ina substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparationof phosphorus or chlorate of potassium. Match box, a box for holdingmatches.-- Match tub, a tub with a perforated cover for holding slow matchesfor firing cannon, esp. on board ship. The tub contains a littlewater in the bottom, for extinguishing sparks from the lightedmatches.-- Quick match, threads of cotton or cotton wick soaked in asolution of gunpowder mixed with gum arabic and boiling water andafterwards strewed over with mealed powder. It burns at the rate ofone yard in thirteen seconds, and is used as priming for heavymortars, fireworks, etc.-- Slow match, slightly twisted hempen rope soaked in a solution oflimewater and saltpeter or washed in a lye of water and wood ashes.It burns at the rate of four or five inches an hour, and is used forfiring cannon, fireworks, etc.
Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging toTroglodytes and numerous allied of the family Troglodytidæ.
To shut up or inclose, as in a pen. Feltham.
A priming tube connecting the charge chamber with the gallery,or place where the slow match is applied. Knight.
Of or pertaining to a thread or line; characterized by threadsstretched across the field of view; as, a filar microscope; a filarmicrometer.
A kind of quadrangular piece of cloth put on by the Jews whenrepeating prayers in the synagogues. Crabb.
The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principaltotem was the wolf.
See Creel.
See Demy, n.
A quill or reed on which thread or yarn is wound; a bobbin;also, the wound yarn on a weaver's shuttle; also, the reel of afishing rod. [Scot.]

Any one of numerous species of fishes belonging to Salmo,Salvelinus, and allied genera of the family Salmonidæ. They arehighly esteemed as game fishes and for the quality of their flesh.All the species breed in fresh water, but after spawning many of themdescend to the sea if they have an opportunity.
Small coal; also, coal dust; culm. Raymond.
A measure of capacity, equal to half a quart, or four gills, --used in liquid and dry measures. See Quart.
To refuse; to deny. [Obs.] "He shall not nayt ne deny his sin."Chaucer.
of Lie. See lain. Ps. lxviii. 13.
To set in, or furnish with, a haft; as, to haft a dagger.
An effort to vomit. [R.]
To make a mark or cavity on or in, by a blow or by pressure; todent. Donne. Tennyson.
The sign [Obs.]

Lit., skilled mechanical work, such as that required in woodcarving; trade work; hence, a system (usually called the sloydsystem) of manual training in the practical use of the tools andmaterials used in the trades, and of instruction in the making anduse of the plans and specifications connected with trade work. Thesloyd system derives its name from the fact that it was adopted orlargely developed from a similar Swedish system, in which woodcarving was a chief feature. Its purpose is not only to affordpractical skill in some trade, but also to develop the pupilsmentally and physically.
A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It isvalued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing inthe settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
Want of tone; weakness of the system, or of any organ,especially of such as are contractile.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomachby gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany;bloating.
The one and the other; the two; the pair, without exception ofeither.
To simmer. [Obs.] Holland.
In a lax manner.
The Indian antelope (Antilope bezoartica, or cervicapra), notedfor its beauty and swiftness. It has long, spiral, divergent horns.
See Kyrie eleison.

Chalcedony in parallel layers of different shades of color. Itis used for making cameos, the figure being cut in one layer with thenext as a ground. Onyx marble, a banded variety of marble or calciumcarbonate resembling onyx. It is obtained from Mexico.
In accordance with truth; truly. Shak.
A thin, elastic strip of metal, whalebone, wood, or othermaterial, worn in the front of a corset.Her long slit sleeves, stiff busk, puff verdingall, Is all that makesher thus angelical. Marston.

A stone, commonly of a pale to dark green color but sometimeswhitish. It is very hard and compact, capable of fine polish, and isused for ornamental purposes and for implements, esp. in Easterncountries and among many early peoples.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate theiraproach to a place. Farrow.
A small South American rodent (Octodon Cumingii), of the familyOctodontidæ.
A woman who capriciously deceives her lover; a coquette; aflirt. Otway.
Fro. [Old Eng. & Scot.]
High. [Obs.] Chaucer.

The loose outer garment worn by the ancient Romans, consistingof a single broad piece of woolen cloth of a shape approaching asemicircle. It was of undyed wool, except the border of the togaprætexta. Toga prætexta. Etym: [L.], a toga with a broad purpleborder, worn by children of both sexes, by magistrates, and bypersons engaged in sacred rites.-- Toga virilis Etym: [L.], the manly gown; the common toga. Thiswas assumed by Roman boys about the time of completing theirfourteenth year.
Put in dread; afraid. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of thereserve. See Army organization, above.
See Myth. Grote.
One who is loved. [Humorous] "The lover and lovee." Richardson.
A lock or tuft of hair. [Obs.] Dryden.
Gone. Chaucer.
A peculiar whistling sound made by the Australian aborigenes asa call or signal. [Written also cooie.]
A mobcap. Goldsmith.
Same as Mung.
A body of Kaffir warriors; a body of native armed men. [SouthAfrica]
Having an axle; -- used in composition.Merlin's agate-axled car. T. Warton.
See Muræna.
A socket or bezel holding a precious stone; hence, a jewel orornament worn on the person.A precious stone in a rich ouche. Sir T. Elyot.Your brooches, pearls, and ouches. Shak.
Dark; gloomy; murky. Spenser. Mrs. Browning.
See Groan. [Obs.]
To make a low whistling sound; to chirp, as birds. Halliwell.
A liliaceous plant (Calochortus Nuttallii) of Western NorthAmerica, and its edible bulb; -- so called by the Ute Indians and theMormons.

The short, thick first digit of the human hand, differing fromthe other fingers in having but two phalanges; the pollex. SeePollex.Upon his thumb he had of gold a ring. Chaucer.Thumb band, a twist of anything as thick as the thumb. Mortimer.-- Thumb blue, indigo in the form of small balls or lumps, used bywasherwomen to blue linen, and the like.-- Thumb latch, a door latch having a lever formed to be pressed bythe thumb.-- Thumb mark. (a) The mark left by the impression of a thumb, as onthe leaves of a book. Longfellow. (b) The dark spot over each foot infinely bred black and tan terriers.-- Thumb nut, a nut for a screw, having wings to grasp between thethumb and fingers in turning it; also, a nut with a knurled rim forthe same perpose.-- Thumb ring, a ring worn on the thumb. Shak.-- Thumb stall. (a) A kind of thimble or ferrule of iron, orleather, for protecting the thumb in making sails, and in other work.(b) (Mil.) A buckskin cushion worn on the thumb, and used to closethe vent of a cannon while it is sponged, or loaded.-- Under one's thumb, completely under one's power or influence; ina condition of subservience. [Colloq.]
To seize; clutch; snatch; catch; pluck.
See Birt. [Prov. Eng.]
Crazy; mentally unsound. [Written also loony.] [Law, U.S.]
To hurt; to injure; to damage; to wrong.Though yet he never harmed me. Shak.No ground of enmity between us known Why he should mean me ill orseek to harm. Milton.
A round, convex molding. See Illust. of Column.
To melt and run down, as the tallow of a candle; to waste awaywithout feeding the flame. [Written also swale.] Sir W. Scott.
3d pers. sing. pr. of Find, for findeth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Bolty.
A threadlike part of a flower; a stamen.
A quadruped of the genus Canis, esp. the domestic dog (C.familiaris).
Same as Delftware.
A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
To subdue; to daunt. [Obs.]The sight whereof did greatly him adaw. Spenser.
A suffix, indicating that those substances of whose names it isa part are basic, and alkaloidal in their nature.
A Dutch and German measure of liquids, varying in differentcities, being at Amsterdam about 41 wine gallons, at Antwerp 36½, atHamburg 38¼. [Written also Aum and Awm.]

Of or pertaining to a zone; having the form of a zone or zones.Zonal equation (Crystallog.), the mathematical relation which belongsto all the planes of a zone, and expresses their common position withreference to the axes.-- Zonal structure (Crystallog.), a structure characterized by thearrangements of color, inclusions, etc., of a crystal in parallel orconcentric layers, which usually follow the outline of the crystal,and mark the changes that have taken place during its growth.-- Zonal symmetry. (Biol.) See the Note under Symmetry.
A hedge. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Obi.
Exclamation of regret or surprise. [Prov. Eng.] Cowper.
An anchor carried at the bow of a ship.
To taste; to have a relish for. [Obs.]
A slight iregular protuberance which defaces the surface of acasting, caused by the breaking away of a part of the mold.

A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides. The horns areblack, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp. Calledalso rheeboc, and rehboc.
To draw, bend, or straighten, as metal, by blows with the peenof a hammer or sledge.
A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents;the tenth of a dollar. Dime novel, a novel, commonly sensational andtrashy, which is sold for a dime, or ten cents.
Doing. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
Unreasonableness; absurdity. [Obs.]
See Amidst.

Either of two large antelopes (Boöcercus eurycercus of WestAfrica, and B. isaaci of East Africa) of a reddish or chestnut-browncolor with narrow white stripes on the body. Their flesh isespecially esteemed as food.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfinggreen.
To soak. [Obs.] Mortimer.

The title of the supreme ruler in certain Eastern countries,especially Persia. [Written also schah.] Shah Nameh. Etym: [Per.,Book of Kings.] A celebrated historical poem written by Firdousi,being the most ancient in the modern Persian language. Brande & C.

To copy, as a drawing, by rubbing the back of it with red orblack chalk, and then passing a blunt style or needle over the lines,so as to leave a tracing on the paper or other thing against which itis laid or held. [Writting also calque]
The postaxial bone of the forearm, or branchium, correspondingto the fibula of the hind limb. See Radius.
To pelt; to knock about. [Obs.] Holland.
See Eager, and Eagre. [Obs.]

The melted rock ejected by a volcano from its top or fissuredsides. It flows out in streams sometimes miles in length. It alsoissues from fissures in the earth's surface, and forms beds coveringmany square miles, as in the Northwestern United States.
To be formal or affected in dress or manners; -- often with up.[Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Halliwell.
To float; to swim. [Obs.] "Whether I sink or flete." Chaucer.
an obs. form of began, imp. & p. p. of Begin, sometimes used inold poetry.
A kind of triangular spade. [Obs.]
Rugged; rough. [Obs.] "With ruggy, ashy hairs." Chaucer.
A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals oftime can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing thespeed of horses, machinery, etc.
On my life; dearly. [Obs.] "I love that sport alife." Beau. &Fl.

Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus. The garden thyme (Thymusvulgaris) is a warm, pungent aromatic, much used to give a relish toseasoning and soups.Ankle deep in moss and flowery thyme. Cowper.Cat thyme, a labiate plant (Teucrium Marum) of the Mediterraneanreligion. Cats are said to be fond of rolling on it. J. Smith (Dict.Econ. Plants).-- Wild thyme, Thymus Serpyllum, common on banks and hillsides inEurope.I know a bank where the wild thyme blows. Shak.
To cast aside; to put off; to doff. [Obs.]Canst thou so daff me Thou hast killed my child. Shak.
A simpleton. L'Estrange.A pattern and companion fit For all the keeping tonies of the pit.Dryden.
A quire; a book. [Obs.] " The king's quhair." James I. (ofScotland).
A small stage hung over a vessel's side, for workmen to standon in calking, etc.

Relating to, or derived from, a city or citizen; relating toman as a member of society, or to civil affairs. Civic crown (Rom.Antiq.), a crown or garland of oak leaves and acorns, bestowed on asoldier who had saved the life of a citizen in battle.
An Italian coin equivalent in value to the French franc.
A national food of the Hawaiians, made by baking and poundingthe kalo (or taro) root, and reducing it to a thin paste, which isallowed to ferment.
One who saves.

A local and habitual convulsive motion of certain muscles;especially, such a motion of some of the muscles of the face;twitching; velication; -- called also spasmodic tic. Dunglison. Ticdouloureux (. Etym: [F., fr. tic a knack, a twitching + douloureuxpainful.] (Med.) Neuralgia in the face; face ague. See under Face.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.
Dark; murky.He can not see through the mantle murk. J. R. Drake.
To enrich. [Obs.] Gower.
See Poly.
The refuse of cattle taken from a drove. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
See Soosoo.
A low, flat mass of floating ice. Floe rat (Zoöl.), a seal(Phoca foetida).
To utter in a slow, lengthened tone.
Any one of several species of cuckoos of the genus Eudynamys,found in India, the East Indies, and Australia. They deposit theireggs in the nests of other birds.
To release, let fall, or see free, as a weight or compressedspring, as by removing a latch or detent.
Short form for Dura mater.
Sweet. [Obs.] Chaucer. Fairfax.
Mustiness.
A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside ofwhich is a stretched string made to vibrate by singing or humminginto the tube.
A loanin. [Scot.]
The number of simple elements which an abstract conception ornotion includes; the comprehension or content.
To fit; to suit; to adapt. [Obs.] " To apt their places." B.Jonson.That our speech be apted to edification. Jer. Taylor.
A kind of latticework formed of, or covered with, vines,branches of trees, or other plants, for shade; a bower. Sir P.Sidney.
To suck. [Obs.] Chaucer.
imp. of Write. Wrote. Chaucer.
A boatman; an oarsman. [India]
Pertaining to the ileum. [Written also iliac.]
Hellish. Anderson (1573).
A paroxysm of extreme pain or anguish; a sudden and transitoryagony; a throe; as, the pangs of death.

The standard atmospheric pressure used in certain physicalmeasurements calculations; conventionally, that pressure under whichthe barometer stands at 760 millimeters, at a temperature of 0ºCentigrade, at the level of the sea, and in the latitude of Paris.Sir W. Thomson.
A Burman measure of twelve miles.
A person, object, influence, or supernatural being which issupposed to bring bad luck or to cause things to go wrong. [Slang]
The conscious and permanent subject of all psychicalexperiences, whether held to be directly known or the product ofreflective thought; -- opposed to non-ego.
See Aryan.
A kind of stagecoach. "The Derby dilly." J. H. Frere.
Slightly turned or opened; as, the door was standing ajar.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor ofspirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium. T. Gray.
A fertile or green spot in a waste or desert, esp. in a sandydesert.

Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustaceahaving slender legs and long antennæ. They mostly belong to thegenera Pandalus, Palæmon, Palæmonetes, and Peneus, and are much usedas food. The common English prawn in Palæmon serratus.
To lay a tax upon; to assess. [Obs.]
To unite in a small party to promote private views andinterests by intrigue; to intrigue; to plot.Caballing still against it with the great. Dryden.
Same as Silva.
To be turned or inclined from a right line or level; to lieobliquely; to slope.On the side of younder slanting hill. Dodsley.
In a tumid, swelling, blustering manner; haughtily; violently.He brawleth bigly. Robynson (More's Utopia. )
A castrated cock, esp. when fattened; a male chicken gelded toimprove his flesh for the table. Shak.The merry thought of a capon. W. Irving.
To beat; to strike; to chastise. [Obs.]I'll fer him, and firk him, and ferret him. Shak.
A little round hill; a mound; a small elevation of earth; thetop or crown of a hill.On knoll or hillock rears his crest, Lonely and huge, the giant oak.Sir W. Scott.
A pocket. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Certainly; most likely; truly; probably. [Obs. or Archaic]"Ywis," quod he, "it is full dear, I say." Chaucer.She answered me, "I-wisse, all their sport in the park is but ashadow to that pleasure that I find in Plato." Ascham.A right good knight, and true of word ywis. Spenser.
The stone roller. See Stone roller (a), under Stone.

A comprehensive name for all of the pretended arts which claimto produce effects by the assistance of supernatural beings, ordeparted spirits, or by a mastery of secret forces in nature attainedby a study of occult science, including enchantment, conjuration,witchcraft, sorcery, necromancy, incantation, etc.An appearance made by some magic. Chaucer.Celestial magic, a supposed supernatural power which gave to spiritsa kind of dominion over the planets, and to the planets an influenceover men.-- Natural magic, the art of employing the powers of nature toproduce effects apparently supernatural.-- Superstitious, or Geotic, magic, the invocation of devils ordemons, involving the supposition of some tacit or express agreementbetween them and human beings.
Mother; -- word of tenderness and familiarity. [Written alsomama.]Tell tales papa and mamma. Swift.

A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, ornearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.Easel picture, Easel piece, a painting of moderate size such as ismade while resting on an easel, as distinguished from a painting on awall or ceiling.
A layer or seam, or a horizontal stratum between layers; as, abed of coal, iron, etc.

An expression of mirth peculiar to the human species; the soundheard in laughing; laughter. See Laugh, v. i.And the loud laugh that spoke the vacant mind. Goldsmith.That man is a bad man who has not within him the power of a heartylaugh. F. W. Robertson.
Manner of approaching or accosting; address. Chesterfield.
On the way; agoing; as, to be agate; to set the bells agate.[Obs.] Cotgrave.
The exterior or under surface embraced between the branches ofthe lower jaw bone, in birds.

A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the bodycovered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in frontof the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, andarmed bullhead.

A sylvan deity or demigod, represented as part man and partgoat, and characterized by riotous merriment and lasciviousness.Rough Satyrs danced; and Fauns, with cloven heel, From the glad soundwould not be absent long. Milton.
Same as Dorsal, n. [R.]
Catnip.

A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; theproclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by thevery act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Romanemperors; the edicts of the French monarch.It stands as an edict in destiny. Shak.Edict of Nantes (French Hist.), an edict issued by Henry IV. (A. D.1598), giving toleration to Protestants. Its revocation by Louis XIV.(A. D. 1685) was followed by terrible persecutions and theexpatriation of thousands of French Protestants.
A cyma.
Womanhood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The uterus. See Uterus.
Complexion; color; hue; likeness; form. [Archaic]For him which is so bright of blee. Lament. of Mary Magd.That boy has a strong blee of his father. Forby.
A stadium. Donne.
A lion. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A Swedish turnip. See under Turnip.
Pertaining to, or made of, the size of paper called demy; as, ademy book.
The place at Athens where the meetings of the people were heldfor making decrees, etc.
A son; -- used in compound names, to indicate paternity, esp.of the illegitimate sons of kings and princes of the blood; as,Fitzroy, the son of the king; Fitzclarence, the son of the duke ofClarence.
A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linumusitatissimum).
A long bag net distended by hoops, into which fish can passeasily, without being able to return; -- called also fyke net.Cozzens.
To move or act with haste; to proceed with celerity orprecipitation; as, let us hurry. To hurry up, to make haste.[Colloq.]
See Hose. [Archaic]
See Loach.

A detached low mountain, or high rising abruptly from thegeneral level of the surrounding plain; -- applied to peculiarelevations in the Rocky Mountain region.The creek . . . passes by two remarkable buttes of red conglomerate.Ruxton.
Robbery; spoil. [Obs.]
To measure the dimensions of, or to test the accuracy of theform of, as of a part of a gunlock.The vanes nicely gauged on each side. Derham.
Blended; passing into each other by subtle gradations; -- saidof colors or of the surface or material on which the colors are laid.

A clan, tribe, or family, proceeding from a common progenitor;-- used especially of the ancient clans in Ireland.The chief, struck by the illustration, asked at once to be baptized,and all his sept followed his example. S. Lover.
A red coloring matter derived from phenol; -- called also, incommerce, yellow coralin.
Alone [Scot.] His lane, by himself; himself alone.
See Mich. [Obs. or Colloq.]

The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians,and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. Hecorresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usuallyrepresented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.

The most important tribe belonging to the Kaffir race. Theyinhabit a region on the southeast coast of Africa, but formerlyoccupied a much more extensive country. They are noted for theirwarlike disposition, courage, and military skill.
Geniculated; forming an obtuse angle at the joints, like theknee when a little bent; as, kneed grass.
p. p. of Fly; -- often used with the auxiliary verb to be; as,the birds are flown.

The right of bowling again at a full set of pins, after havingknocked all the pins down in less than three bowls. If all the pinsare knocked down in one bowl it is a double spare; in two bowls, asingle spare.
To emit a strong, offensive smell; to send out a disgustingodor.
To haggle about the price of a commodity; to bargain hard.[Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
An inclined plane serving as a communication between differentinterior levels.
Strong malt liquor. [Cant] Prior.
An armed ship having her upper deck cut away, and thus reducedto the next inferior rate, as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.Totten.
A basin. [Obs. or Special form]
TO make foul; to soil; to defile. [Obs.] Milton.
Tint; color; tinge, See Tint. [Obs.]Time shall . . . embrown the teint. Dryden.
Somewhat salt; saltish.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornlende) in the wallsof tin and copper lodes.
To dress or adjust one's self for show; to prank.
A blow; a stroke. [Scot.] H. Miller.
To make sottish; to make dull or stupid; to stupefy; toinfatuate.Fools besotted with their crimes. Hudibras.
See Scent, v. & n. [Obs.] Spenser.
A piece. [Obs.] Dryton.
the horny scale of plate of epidermis at the end of the fingersand toes of man and many apes.His nayles like a briddes claws were. Chaucer.
A tall drinking cup.
The person creating a wakf.
of Last, to endure. Chaucer.
A square of white linen worn at first on the head, but nowabout the neck and shoulders, by priests of the Roman Catholic Churchwhile saying Mass.
See Shearn. [Obs.]
A red Madeira wine, wanting the high aroma of the white sorts,and, when old, resembling tawny port.
Thane. See Thane. E. A. Freeman.

A prefix to verbs, having usually the force of a negative orprivative. It often implies also loss, detriment, or destruction, andsometimes it is intensive, meaning utterly, quite thoroughly, as inforbathe.
Made of hair. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A capping molding. Same as Cymatium.
A vexillum.
See Muzzle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
pl. of Shoe. [Archaic] Chaucer.They shook the snow from hats and shoon. Emerson.
A contraction of Soph ister. [Colloq.]
The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum, or whitepoppy.
Heedful. [Obs.] "Heedy shepherds." Spenser.-- Heed"i*ly, adv. [Obs.] -- Heed"i*ness, n. [Obs.] Spenser.
A prefix in words from the Greek, denoting up, upward,throughout, backward, back, again, anew.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied toother related species. See Bobwhite.
To entice. [Obs.] The Coronation.
Many. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To graft with new feathers, as a wing; to splice a brokenfeather. Hence, Fig.: To repair; to extend; to increase; tostrengthen to equip. [Archaic]Imp out our drooping country's broken wing. Shak.Who lazily imp their wings with other men's plumes. Fuller. Here nofrail Muse shall imp her crippled wing. Holmes.Help, ye tart satirists, to imp my rage With all the scorpions thatshould whip this age. Cleveland.

A soft woolly mass prepared from the young leaves of ArtemisiaChinensis, and used as a cautery by burning it on the skin; hence,any substance used in a like manner, as cotton impregnated withniter, amadou.
See Note under Our.

A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the forepart of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides atanchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying (belayingbitts), for sustaining the windlass (carrick bitts, winch bitts, orwindlass bitts), to hold the pawls of the windlass (pawl bitts) etc.

To increase; to add to; to augment; -- now commonly used without, the notion conveyed being to add to, or piece out by alaborious, inferior, or scanty addition; as, to eke out a scantysupply of one kind with some other. "To eke my pain." Spenser.He eked out by his wits an income of barely fifty pounds. Macaulay.
Same as Sewen.

On or toward the lee, or the side away from the wind; theopposite of aweather. The helm of a ship is alee when pressed closeto the lee side. Hard alee, or Luff alee, an order to put the helm tothe lee side.
A blow. [Obs.] R. of Glouc.
To allege; to assert. [Obs.] Bp. Fisher.

A kind of flower cluster in which sessile flowers are arrangedon an unbranched elongated axis. Spike grass (Bot.), either of twotall perennial American grasses (Uniola paniculata, and U. latifolia)having broad leaves and large flattened spikelets.-- Spike rush. (Bot.) See under Rush.-- Spike shell (Zoöl.), any pteropod of the genus Styliola having aslender conical shell.-- Spike team, three horses, or a horse and a yoke of oxen,harnessed together, a horse leading the oxen or the span. [U.S.]
Having, or abounding with, mites.
A mound or small hill.
Sesame. [Sometimes written til.] Teel oil, sesame oil.
nearer. [Obs.] See Nerre.
Cows. "A herd of fifty or sixty kine." Milton.
To subject to fine or amercement; to mulct; to amerce. [Obs.]
Same as Borrel.
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures(usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
A small eyebolt ragged or barbed at the point.

A saxicoline singing bird (Kittacincla macroura) of India,noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement itimitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy.Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rumpwhite, the under parts chestnut.
Having ample room; spacious; large; as, a roomy mansion; aroomy deck. Dryden.
To raise; to set up; to stir up. [Obs.]
One who plays on a lute.
India. [Poetical] Shak. Milton.
A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel, -- always ofa green color.
The spotted deer (Cervus axis or Axis maculata) of India, whereit is called hog deer and parrah (Moorish name).
A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort; agibe.Quips, and cranks, and wanton wiles. Milton.He was full of joke and jest, But all his merry quips are o'er.Tennyson.
One more than nine; twice five.With twice ten sail I crossed the Phrygian Sea. Dryden.
See Parr.
A made-up story; stuff; nonsense; humbug; -- often anexclamation of contempt.
Attended with symptoms of some degree of severity, and comingspeedily to a crisis; -- opposed to chronic; as, an acute disease.Acute angle (Geom.), an angle less than a right angle.
Millet.
See lst Not. [Obs.] Chaucer.
On the sea; at sea; toward the sea.
Lying or remaining in a place; hence, resident; as, legerambassador.
A tumor consisting of muscular tissue.
The hide of a young or small beef creature, or leather madefrom it; kipskin. Kip leather. See Kipskin.
The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it isgiven in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount onforeign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.
To impose a fine upon; to fine.
To happen. [Obs.] Hewyt.
A coarse woolen stuff with a long nap; -- usually dyed in plaincolors.A new black baize waistcoat lined with silk. Pepys.
See Jig, 6.
Of or pertaining to matter; material; corporeal; as, hylicinfluences.
Like a drone; sluggish; lazy.
To sport or make diversion in a mask or disguise; to mask.With mumming and with masking all around. Spenser.

Of a dull brownish yellow, or drab color; -- applied to cloth,originally to a stout brownish cotton cloth, used in making uniformsin the Anglo-Indian army. In the United States service the summeruniform of cotton is officially designated khaki; the winter uniformof wool, olive drab.
Of or pertaining to a pyre. [R.]
To move hastily; to scour. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Nigh. [Archaic]
Same as Emir.

Any plant or species of the genus Papaver, herbs with showypolypetalous flowers and a milky juice. From one species (Papaversomniferum) opium is obtained, though all the species contain it tosome extent; also, a flower of the plant. See Illust. of Capsule.California poppy (Bot.), any yellow-flowered plant of the genusEschscholtzia.-- Corn poppy. See under Corn.-- Horn, or Horned, poppy. See under Horn.-- Poppy bee (Zoöl.), a leaf-cutting bee (Anthocopa papaveris) whichuses pieces cut from poppy petals for the lining of its cells; --called also upholsterer bee.-- Prickly poppy (Bot.), Argemone Mexicana, a yellow-flowered plantof the Poppy family, but as prickly as a thistle.-- Poppy seed, the seed the opium poppy (P. somniferum).-- Spatling poppy (Bot.), a species of Silene (S. inflata). SeeCatchfly.
To attend the levee or levees of.He levees all the great. Young.
See Tucum.

A slight or temporary structure built to shade or sheltersomething; a structure usually open in front; an outbuilding; a hut;as, a wagon shed; a wood shed.The first Aletes born in lowly shed. Fairfax.Sheds of reeds which summer's heat repel. Sandys.
A bird; the flicker.

To create or constitute; as, to raise a use that is, to createit. Burrill. To raise a blockade (Mil.), to remove or break up ablockade, either by withdrawing the ships or forces employed inenforcing it, or by driving them away or dispersing them.-- To raise a check, note, bill of exchange, etc., to increasefraudulently its nominal value by changing the writing, figures, orprinting in which the sum payable is specified.-- To raise a siege, to relinquish an attempt to take a place bybesieging it, or to cause the attempt to be relinquished.-- To raise steam, to produce steam of a required pressure.-- To raise the wind, to procure ready money by some temporaryexpedient. [Colloq.] -- To raise Cain, or To raise the devil, tocause a great disturbance; to make great trouble. [Slang]
To be lifted, or to admit of being lifted, from the imposingstone without dropping any of the type; -- said of a form.
See Coddle.
Down; fur. [Obs. or Eng.] J. Dyer.
See 1st Pink.
A husband; a master of a family. [Obs.]
A native nurse for children; also, a lady's maid. [India]

A suffix, denoting that the element indicated enters intocertain compounds with its highest valence, or with a valencerelatively higher than in compounds where the name of the elementends in -ous; as, ferric, sulphuric. It is also used in the generalsense of pertaining to; as, hydric, sodic, calcic.
A part; a fragment; a portion. [Obs.]
Feathery or wool-like down; filament of a feather. Shak.No feather, or dowle of a feather. De Quincey.
A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly ifassociated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bonesof the nose.
A short sleep; a doze; a siesta. Cowper.
The old plural of Eye.And eke with fatness swollen were his een. Spenser.
An omnibus. [Colloq.]
Money; tribute; compensation; ransom.[Obs.]
Having awns; bearded.
To move away; to go off. [Prov. Eng. or Local, U. S.]
