The interval between any tone and the tone represented on thetenth degree of the staff above it, as between one of the scale andthree of the octave above; the octave of the third.
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around avertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railwaytrack.
One of a class of strongly basic substances derived fromammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by a basic atomor radical.
To stave in; to bilge. [Obs.] Holland.
A genus of ruminant quadrupeds, including the wild and domesticcattle, distinguished by a stout body, hollow horns, and a large foldof skin hanging from the neck.
Shaky, or tremulous; quaking.
The deepsea fishing for cod, ling, and tusk, off the ShetlandIsles.
Meal (esp. Indian meal) boiled in water; hasty pudding; supawn.[U.S.]
A cuirass or breastplate. [Obs.] Spenser.
Swoon. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A temporary mark or boundary, as a bough of a tree set up inmarking out or dividing anything, as tithes, swaths to be mowed incommon ground, etc.; -- called also wicker. [Prov. Eng.]
See Catechu.
To transmit or send, esp. to a distance, as money in payment ofa demand, account, draft, etc.; as, he remitted the amount by mail.
An adjective suffix signifying relating or belonging to, of thenature of, tending to; as affirmative, active, conclusive,corrective, diminutive.
Barley, especially the hardy four-rowed kind."Bear interchanges in local use, now with barley, now with bigg." NewEnglish Dict.
the original third pers. sing. pres. of Go. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Thorough. [Reformed spelling.]
Any part of a curved line.
of Hote.
p. p. of Wax. Chaucer.
Lying in heaps. Gay.
See Pavan.

A division of time characterized by the prevalence of similarconditions of the earth; commonly a minor division or part of aperiod.The long geological epoch which stored up the vast coal measures. J.C. Shairp.

A state of quiet or tranquillity; freedom from disturbance oragitation; calm; repose; specifically:(a) Exemption from, or cessation of, war with public enemies.(b) Public quiet, order, and contentment in obedience to law.(c) Exemption from, or subjection of, agitating passions;tranquillity of mind or conscience.(d) Reconciliation; agreement after variance; harmony; concord. "Theeternal love and pees." Chaucer.

The space left by excavation between pillars. See Post andstall, under Post. Stall reader, one who reads books at a stall wherethey are exposed for sale.Cries the stall reader, "Bless us! what a word onA titlepage is this!" Milton.

To spread, or turn from the swath, and scatter for drying, asnew-mowed grass; -- chiefly used in the past participle.The smell of grain or tedded grass. Milton.The tedded hay and corn sheaved in one field. Coleridge.
pl. of Louse.
A spider; perhaps from its shape; it being round like a head.
Much; very; as, molto adagio, very slow.
To flay. [Obs.]He will be fleaced first And horse collars made of's skin. J.Fletcher.

A rod at the end of a heddle.(j) (Mach.) A solid or hollow cylinder or bar, having one or morejournals on which it rests and revolves, and intended to carry one ormore wheels or other revolving parts and to transmit power or motion;as, the shaft of a steam engine. See Illust. of Countershaft.
A pictorial suggestion on a coat of arms of the name of theperson to whom it belongs. See Canting arms, under Canting.
A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewelfor personal adornment, or like.
Dreaded. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Moldiness. [R.]
p. p. & a. from Rive.
Pertaining to the goddess Isis; as, Isiac mysteries.
Hand. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A king. To play rex, to play the king; to domineer. [Obs.]

A plant of the genus Allium (A. Porrum), having broadly linearsucculent leaves rising from a loose oblong cylindrical bulb. Theflavor is stronger than that of the common onion. Wild leek , inAmerica, a plant (Allium tricoccum) with a cluster of ovoid bulbs andlarge oblong elliptical leaves.
To make a guess or random judgment; to conjecture; -- with at,about, etcThis is the place, as well as I may guess. Milton.

To find fault or rail with rude clamor; to brawl; to utterharsh, rude, boisterous rebuke; to chide sharply or coarsely; --often with at; as, to scold at a servant.Pardon me, lords, 't is the first time ever I was forced to scold.Shak.
A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.
A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to thedance.
The catch in a gunlock by which the hammer is held cocked orhalf cocked. Sear spring, the spring which causes the sear to catchin the notches by which the hammer is held.
A genus of polypetalous herbaceous plants, including all kindsof violets.
Of or pertaining to veins; venous; as, venal blood. [R.]
Well rounded or filled out; full; fleshy; fat; as, a plumpbaby; plump cheeks. Shak.The god of wine did his plump clusters bring. T. Carew.
The panel for the name, between the bands of the back of abook.

A line inclosing or forming the extremity of a piece of ground,or field of combat; hence, in the plural (lists), the ground or fieldinclosed for a race or combat. Chaucer.In measured lists to toss the weighty lance. Pope.To enter the lists, to accept a challenge, or engage in contest.
One who utters gibes. B. Jonson.
To form a scum; to become covered with scum. Also usedfiguratively.Life, and the interest of life, have stagnated and scummed over. A.K. H. Boyd.
A bench. [North of Eng. & Scot.]
A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is offur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment,hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
of Senge, to singe. Chaucer.
A filament of a stamen. [Obs.]
A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deitieswere inclosed.
The stalk or stem of grain and grasses (including the bamboo),jointed and usually hollow.
Like a lath; long and slender.A lathy horse, all legs and length. R. Browning.
The Muse who presided over history.
The abdomen; the uterus; the womb. [Obs.]
Realm. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Ordure; dung. [Obs.] Burton.
To foretell; to divine. [Scot.]
Same as Brier.
Ordeal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or isoctavalent.
A piece of lively dance music, in two strains which arerepeated; also, the dance.
See Crowd, a violin.
To persuade by gentle, insinuating courtesy, flattering, orfondling; to wheedle; to soothe.
A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe,now Lambeth. Pennant.
The pilgrimage to Mecca, performed by Mohammedans.
In collision; entangled. Totten. To run afoul of, to runagainst or come into collision with, especially so as to becomeentangled or to cause injury.
p. p. of Be; -- used for been. [Obs.] Spenser.

A slender outgrowth from the chitinous cuticle of insects,spiders, crustaceans, and other invertebrates. Such hairs are totallyunlike those of vertebrates in structure, composition, and mode ofgrowth.
Woad. [Obs.]
See Ect-.
To lay. [Obs.]
An abbreviation of hypochonaria; -- usually in plural.[Colloq.]Heaven send thou hast not got the hyps. Swift.
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin,including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the placewhere the business of any public department is transcated.
An Asiatic leguminous herb (Glycine Soja) the seeds of whichare used in preparing the sauce called soy.
A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
A South American striped frog (Pseudis paradoxa), remarkablefor having a tadpole larger than the adult, and hence called alsoparadoxical frog.

To change or modify in any way for the better; as,(a) by simply removing what is erroneous, corrupt, superfluous,faulty, and the like;(b) by supplying deficiencies;(c) by substituting something else in the place of what is removed;to rectify.Mar not the thing that can not be amended. Shak.An instant emergency, granting no possibility for revision, oropening for amended thought. De Quincey.We shall cheer her sorrows, and amend her blood, by wedding her to aNorman. Sir W. Scott.To amend a bill, to make some change in the details or provisions ofa bill or measure while on its passage, professedly for itsimprovement.
Twofold; double. [R.] "Binal revenge, all this." Ford.
Smallclothes. [Colloq.] Hood. Dickens.
To vex; to annoy; to startle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Same as Liter.

An oarlike swimming organ of various invertebrates. Oar cock(Zoöl), the water rail. [Prov. Eng.] -- Spoon oar, an oar having theblade so curved as to afford a better hold upon the water in rowing.-- To boat the oars, to cease rowing, and lay the oars in the boat.-- To feather the oars. See under Feather., v. t.-- To lie on the oars, to cease pulling, raising the oars out ofwater, but not boating them; to cease from work of any kind; to beidle; to rest.-- To muffle the oars, to put something round that part which restsin the rowlock, to prevent noise in rowing.-- To put in one's oar, to give aid or advice; -- commonly used of aperson who obtrudes aid or counsel not invited.-- To ship the oars, to place them in the rowlocks.-- To toss the oars, To peak the oars, to lift them from therowlocks and hold them perpendicularly, the handle resting on thebottom of the boat.-- To trail oars, to allow them to trail in the water alongside ofthe boat.-- To unship the oars, to take them out of the rowlocks.
A fragment of any solid substance; a thick piece. See Chunk.[Colloq.] Lowell.
To have efficiency as an epispastic; to act as a sinapism; --said of a blister, poultice, etc.
Vast; immense. [R.]I can call spirits from the vasty deep. Shak.

A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part ofa vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, iscarried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it isled to a furnace. [Written also trompe, and trombe.]
In the game of craps, a first throw of the dice in which thetotal is two, three, or twelve, in which case the caster loses.
A small coaster vessel, usually sloop-rigged, used in conveyingpassengers and goods from place to place, or as a tender to largervessels in port.The hoy went to London every week. Cowper.
In Russia, a published proclamation or imperial order, havingthe force of law.

Pertaining to, or containing, aroma; fragrant; spicy; strong-scented; odoriferous; as, aromatic balsam. Aromatic compound (Chem.),one of a large class of organic substances, as the oils of bitteralmonds, wintergreen, and turpentine, the balsams, camphors, etc.,many of which have an aromatic odor. They include many of the mostimportant of the carbon compounds and may all be derived from thebenzene group, C6H6. The term is extended also to many of theirderivatives.-- Aromatic vinegar. See under Vinegar.
A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.[Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Any one attached to a Mohammedan mosque, esp. a student of thehigher branches of theology in a mosque school. [Written alsosophta.]
See under Hunt. [Obs.] Chaucer.

The most common and most useful metallic element, being ofalmost universal occurrence, usually in the form of an oxide (ashematite, magnetite, etc.), or a hydrous oxide (as limonite, turgite,etc.). It is reduced on an enormous scale in three principal forms;viz., cast iron, steel, and wrought iron. Iron usually appears darkbrown, from oxidation or impurity, but when pure, or an freshsurface, is a gray or white metal. It is easily oxidized (rusted) bymoisture, and is attacked by many corrosive agents. Symbol Fe (LatinFerrum). Atomic weight 55.9. Specific gravity, pure iron, 7.86; castiron, 7.1. In magnetic properties, it is superior to all othersubstances.
An instrument formerly used which somewhat resembled theviolin, having three strings, and being played with a bow. [Writtenalso rebeck.] Milton.He turn'd his rebec to a mournful note. Drayton.
A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus,Ochroma, etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is usedfor strings and cordage.
An annoyer. [Obs.] Tusser.
A weevil; a worm that breeds in malt, biscuit, etc. [Obs.]Tusser., n. Etym: [F., fr. bouder to pout, be sulky.]
Tight; nimble. [Obs.]Of a good stirring strain too, she goes tith. Beau. & Fl.

A key or thing touched to produce a tone. Tasto solo, singletouch; -- in old music, a direction denoting that the notes in thebass over or under which it is written should be performed alone, orwith no other chords than unisons and octaves.
Singular; wonderful; extraordinary. [Obs.] -- n.
An arrow poison, made from an apocynaceous plant (Strophanthushispidus) of the Gaboon country; -- called also onaye.
To pour, as steel, from a melting pot; to fill, as a mold, withmolten metal.
Viscous; glutinous; of the nature of, or like, glue.
Of or pertaining to song; lyric; tuneful.
To hasten; to go in haste; -- also often with the reciprocalpronoun. [Rare, except in poetry] "My husband hies him home." Shak.The youth, returning to his mistress, hies. Dryden.
See Lotus.
Vile. [Obs.] "That vild race." Spenser.-- Vild"ly, adv. [Obs.] Spenser.
To gibe; to sneer; to break a scornful jest; to utter severesarcasms.Men of all sorts take a pride to gird at me. Shak.
The gorilla.
A female deer or antelope; specifically, the female of thefallow deer, of which the male is called a buck. Also applied to thefemale of other animals, as the rabbit. See the Note under Buck.
Beyond. [North of Eng.]
A sort of moving machine employed in the old pageants. [Obs.]B. Jonson.
imp. & p. p. of Spy.
First; chief.
To gather. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any species of the genus Manis, or family Manidæ.
One who poles.
Gone. Chaucer.
To cool. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A mill. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To wither; to dry. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit.It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, andmountain ash.

A vein. Vena cava; pl. Venæ cavæ. Etym: [L., literally, hollowvein.] (Anat.) Any one of the great systemic veins connected directlywith the heart.-- Vena contracta. Etym: [L., literally, contractedvein.] (Hydraulics) The contracted portion of a liquid jet at andnear the orifice from which it issues.-- Vena portæ; pl. VenÆ portæ. Etym: [L., literally, vein of theentrance.] (Anat.) The portal vein of the liver. See under Portal.
A prefix, from the Latin re and ad combined, coming to usthrough the French and Italian. See Re-, and Ad-.
Consisting of sod; covered with sod; turfy. Cotgrave.
See Else. [Obs.]
A cavern. [Obs.] Shak.
Same as Mono-.
An isolated or circumscribed formation, particularly where thestrata dip inward, on all sides, toward a center; -- especiallyapplied to the coal formations, called coal basins or coal fields.
A promontory; a cape; a headland. Hakluyt.

Resembling, or characterized by, buff. Buffy coat, thecoagulated plasma of blood when the red corpuscles have so settledout that the coagulum appears nearly colorless. This is common indiseased conditions where the corpuscles run together more rapidlyand in denser masses than usual. Huxley.
Sexual connection with a woman without her consent. See Age ofconsent, under Consent, n. statutory rape.
To give attention or heed; to obey; as, the dog minds well.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent (Siphneus aspalax) resembling themole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
A native or inhabitant of Exeter, in England.
A very venomous snake of India (Bungarus coeruleus), allied tothe cobra. Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often withnarrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
A genus of grasses, including a great number of species, as thekinds called meadow grass, Kentucky blue grass, June grass, and speargrass (which see).
p. p. of Spread. Chaucer.
Unsteady; dizzy; tottery. [Obs.or Prov. Eng.] Sir W. Scott.For yet his noule [head] was totty of the must. Spenser.
Expressing, or consisting of, the number two; belonging to two;as, the dual number of nouns, etc. , in Greek.Here you have one half of our dual truth. Tyndall.
See Grail., a dish.
Turbid; as, roily water.
A birch tree. [Prov. Eng.] "The silver birk." Tennyson.
imp. & p. p. of Ring. Chaucer.
Taken. Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to a king; kingly; royal; as, regal authority,pomp, or sway. "The regal title." Shak.He made a scorn of his regal oath. Milton.
A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries inEurope; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
The floor of a coal mine. Raymond. Thill coupling, a device forconnecting the thill of a vehicle to the axle.
A molding, the section of which is the form of the letter S,with the convex part above; cyma reversa. See Illust. under Cyma.
He (or she ) goes out, or retires from view; as, exit Macbeth.
The capelin.

Of or pertaining to a royal line of England, descended fromOwen Tudor of Wales, who married the widowed queen of Henry V. Thefirst reigning Tudor was Henry VII.; the last, Elizabeth. Tudor style(Arch.), the latest development of Gothic architecture in England,under the Tudors, characterized by flat four-centered arches, shallowmoldings, and a profusion of paneling on the walls.

Lying toward the west; situated at the west, or in a westerndirection from the point of observation or reckoning; proceedingtoward the west, or coming from the west; as, a west course is onetoward the west; an east and west line; a west wind blows from thewest.This shall be your west border. Num. xxxiv. 6.West end, the fashionable part of London, commencing from the east,at Charing Cross.
A large conical brick structure around which the firing kilnsare grouped. Knight.
To eat gluttonously or to satiety.Like three horses that have broken fence, And glutted all night longbreast-deep in corn. Tennyson.
A name sometimes given to the raven.
Same as Chief.
A small wooden vessel; a pail. [Scot.] Jamieson.
To sigh.
a sweet, demulcent, acidulous, or mucilaginous mixture, used asa vehicle. Milton.Honey in woods, juleps in brooks. H. Vaughan.

To drop from a high place upon sharp stakes or hooks, as theTurks dropped malefactors, by way of punishment.Ganching, which is to let fall from on high upon hooks, and there tohang until they die. Sandys.
A lofty West African tree (Khaya Senegalensis), related to themahogany, which it resembles in the quality of the wood. The bark isused as a febrifuge.
Pertaining to, abounding with, or resembling, tin. "The tinnystrand." Drayton.
See Doily.
See Visor.
An open box car used on railroads. Compare Lorry.
A claw. [Obs.]
An indefinite expanse. [R.]The gray vague of unsympathizing sea. Lowell.
See Sunfish (b).
A toll for passage over another person's grounds. [Written alsopeage and pedage.]  Burke.
To hasten; to hurry. [Archaic]I 'll haste the writer. Shak.They were troubled and hasted away. Ps. xlviii. 5.
Full of whirlpools or gulfs. Chapman.
To put into a cask.
The moon. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To shut; to close. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Pain; grief; distress; anguish. [Written also dolour.] [Poetic]Of death and dolor telling sad tidings. Spenser.
Quick of perception; alert; sharp. [Scot.] Jamieson.
A license of reprisals. See Marque.
A prefix signifying half, and sometimes partly or imperfectly;as, semiannual, half yearly; semitransparent, imperfectlytransparent.
A combining form signifying impressed form; stamp; print; type;typical form; representative; as in stereotype phototype, ferrotype,monotype.
To make ruddy. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
See Slav.
See Ascus.
A nævus. [Obs.] Dryden.
A climbing plant (Humulus Lupulus), having a long, twining,annual stalk. It is cultivated for its fruit (hops).

An exclamation denoting surprise, joy, or grief. Both asuttered and as written, it expresses a great variety of emotions,determined by the tone or the context. When repeated, ha, ha, it isan expression of laughter, satisfaction, or triumph, sometimes ofderisive laughter; or sometimes it is equivalent to "Well, it is so."Ha-has, and inarticulate hootings of satirical rebuke. Carlyle.
obs. imp. of Grind. Chaucer.
Long and flexible, like a wand. [Prov. Eng.] Brockett.
A prefix, from Gr. de`ka, signifying ten; specifically (MetricSystem), a prefix signifying the weight or measure that is ten timesthe principal unit.
Sound. [Obs.] aucer.
Same as Jereed.
Having a taste or flavorl savory; sapid. [Obs.] Cockeram.
An ancient name of a gum.
Any raptorial bird of the subfamily Milvinæ, of which manyspecies are known. They have long wings, adapted for soaring, andusually a forked tail.
Specifically, the throes or travail of childbirth.She bowed herself and travailed, for her pains came upon her. 1 Sam.iv. 19.
The posterior opening of the alimentary canal, through whichthe excrements are expelled.
To cause to burst forth; to eject; as, to erupt lava. Huxley.
One of intermediate order between angels and men.
A pole or beam used in Scottish games for tossing as a trial ofstrength.
A large ornamental letter used, esp. by the early printers, atthe commencement of the chapters and other divisions of a book.Brande & C.
Dice. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One of the radiating sticks of a fan. The outermost are largerand longer, and are called panaches. Knight.
An abnormal sound of several kinds, heard on auscultation.
To con (a ship). [Obs.]
To be tangent to. See Tangent, a.
See Utas. [Obs.]
A seal; a signature. Dryden.Of talismans and sigils knew the power. Pope.
See Oast.
To strike; to crush; to smash; to dash in pieces. [Obs.] P.Plowman. "I'll pash him o'er the face." Shak.
An arch, or ceiling, of boards, placed over the men's heads ina mine.
Food. [Obs.] See Cates.
A kind of domestic cattle reared in Asia for its flesh andmilk. It is supposed to be a hybrid between the zebu and the yak.
Small; tiny. [Obs.]
Nearer. [Obs.] [Written also neer, ner.] Chaucer. Never theneer, never the nearer; no nearer. [Obs.]
To run out or forth; to extend. [Obs.] Harvey.
A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varyingconsiderably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625pounds.
To void the excrement, as a bird; to mute. [Obs.]
A moving picture or a moving picture show; -- commonly used inpl. [Slang or Colloq.]
Any one of numerous species of small passerine birds native oftropical America. See Banana quit, under Banana, and Guitguit.
The brains. [Scot.]
A suffix indicating something drawn or written, a drawing,writing; -- as, monogram, telegram, chronogram.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neckand throat, and extending to the shoulders.
A person having myopy; a myops.
,v.t. To make naked. [Obs.] Chaucer.Come, be ready, nake your swords. Old Play.
The five lines and the spaces on which music is written; --formerly called stave.
A nickname given to a person of Spanish (or, by extension,Portuguese or Italian) descent. [U. S.]

To raise; to lift; to elevate; esp., to raise or lift to adesired elevation, by means of tackle, as a sail, a flag, a heavypackage or weight.They land my goods, and hoist my flying sails. Pope.Hoisting him into his father's throne. South.Hoisting engine, a steam engine for operating a hoist.
One who muses.
To move swiftly; -- usually with indefinite it.Straight flies as chek, and clips it down the wind. Dryden.
To puff. [Prov. Eng. A Local, U. S.] Halliwel.
The second digit, that next pollex, in the manus, or hand; theforefinger; index finger.
A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; --mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account.
One who gathers eggs; an eggler.
An expression equivalent to What did you say Sir Eh [Obs.]Shak.

To prevent by fear; hence, to hinder or prevent from action byfear of consequences, or difficulty, risk, etc. Addison.Potent enemies tempt and deter us from our duty. Tillotson.My own face deters me from my glass. Prior.
Relaxation. [Obs.] Feltham.
To shape (the brim) into a curve.
Abbreviation of pyrogallic acid. [Colloq.]
To cry, as a young child; to squall. [Written also meawl.]Shak.

A heavy iron lever having an oscillating motion on a centralaxis, one end of which is connected with the piston rod from which itreceives motion, and the other with the crank of the wheel shaft; --called also working beam or walking beam.
See 1st Char.
A title of honor in Turkey and in some other parts of the East;a bey.

Made, as a vowel, with a less tense, and more open and relaxed,condition of the mouth organs; -- opposed to primary as used by Mr.Bell, and to narrow as used by Mr. Sweet. The effect, as explained byMr. Bell, is due to the relaxation or tension of the pharynx; asexplained by Mr. Sweet and others, it is due to the action of thetongue. The wide of e (eve) is î (îll); of a (ate) is ê (ênd), etc.See Guide to Pronunciation, § 13-15.
A puppet. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Disregard or violation of law. [R.] Glanvill.
To praise. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Russians.
To assert as true; to declare. [R.]Had they [the ancients] dreamt this, they would have truthed itheaven. Ford.
Any passage having the entrance represented as wider than theexit, so as to give the appearance of length.
Tiles laid at the eaves of a house. Knight.
Went. See Yode.All as he bade fulfilled was indeed This ilke servant anon right outyede. Chaucer.
of Kneel.
A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudicea third.
To make a slight, sharp noise (or a succession of such noises),as by gentle striking; to tick.The varnished clock that clicked behind the door. Goldsmith.
Totty. [Obs.]My head is totty of my swink to-night. Chaucer.

To have adequate or sufficient courage for any purpose; to bebold or venturesome; not to be afraid; to venture.I dare do all that may become a man; Who dares do more is none. Shak.Why then did not the ministers use their new law Bacause they durstnot, because they could not. Macaulay.Who dared to sully her sweet love with suspicion. Thackeray.The tie of party was stronger than the tie of blood, because apartisan was more ready to dare without asking why. Jowett (Thu
A kind of head covering; a caul. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having flat sides or surfaces; as, a sixpaned nut.
Same as Obi.-- a.
To determine an issue of fact, and to declare such adetermination to a court; as, the jury find for the plaintiff.Burrill.
A cliff. [Obs.]That gainst the craggy clifts did loudly roar. Spenser.
A fon. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who eyes another. Gayton.
To mew; to molt. [Obs.] Quarles.
See Clamp.
See Tænia.
To beat with a mall; to beat with something heavy; to bruise;to maul.
Poison; venom; corrupt matter from a sore. [Obs.] Holland.
A squirrel's nest. Cowper.
Having the place of articulation on the soft palate; guttural;as, the velar consonants, such as k and hard q.
Having a glazed appearance; -- said of the fractured surface ofsome kinds of pin iron.
Variant of Engine. [Obs.] Chaucer.
imp. & p. p. of Sting.
A king. [obs.]
One who hires.
See Siren. [R.]
A combining form fr. Gr. o'y^ron, urine.
A workman's name for the graphite which forms incidentally iniron smelting.
Same as Pood.
See Pansy. [Obs.] Dryden.

One of the old musical forms, before the time of the morecompact sonata, consisting of a string or series of pieces all in thesame key, mostly in various dance rhythms, with sometimes anelaborate prelude. Some composers of the present day affect the suiteform.
Of or pertaining to the Incas.

Of thee, or belonging to thee; the more common form of thine,possessive case of thou; -- used always attributively, and chiefly inthe solemn or grave style, and in poetry. Thine is used in thepredicate; as, the knife is thine. See Thine.Our father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdomcome. Thy will be done. Matt. vi. 9,10.These are thy glorious works, Parent of good. Milton.
Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that theymay be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam. [Written also lagan.]Blackstone.
Of or pertaining to the aspen, or resembling it; made of aspenwood.Nor aspen leaves confess the gentlest breeze. Gay.
Power; force; energy; spirit; activity; vigor. [Colloq.]
A youth woman; a girl; a sweetheart.
A New Zealand forest tree (Metrosideros robusta), also, itshard dark red wood, used by the Maoris for paddles and war clubs.

Danger; risk; hazard; jeopardy; exposure of person or propertyto injury, loss, or destruction.In perils of waters, in perils of robbers. 2 Cor. xi. 26.Adventure hard With peril great achieved. Milton.At, or On, one's peril, with risk or danger to one; at the hazard of."On thy soul's peril." Shak.
, an old method of printing that (AS. æt, edhæt) the "y" takingthe place of the old letter "Þ"). Cf. Ye, the.
A guillemot.
A wry face or mouth; a mow. [Obs.]
Baryta.
A long strip of wood, curved upwards in front, used on the footfor sliding.
The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristicof certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as,tolyl carbinol.
A prime mover; a machine by means of which a source of power,as steam, moving water, electricity, etc., is made available fordoing mechanical work.
One who, or that which, mixes.
See 1st Lar.
Of forbidding or fear-inspiring aspect; fierce; stern; surly;cruel; frightful; horrible.Whose grim aspect sets every joint a-shaking. Shak.The ridges of grim war. Milton.
Same as Pewit.
A rabbit. See Cony.
Dry. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Attar.
To cause a smart in. "A goad that . . . smarts the flesh." T.Adams.
See Jougs. [Scot.]
To go or move with one side foremost; to move sidewise; as, tosidle through a crowd or narrow opening. Swift.He . . . then sidled close to the astonished girl. Sir W. Scott.
The yew. [Obs.] Dryden.
A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
Infested with moths; moth-eaten. "An old mothy saddle." Shak.
A stag; the male of the red deer. See the Note under Buck.Goodliest of all the forest, hart and hind. Milton.
Same as Rani.
With ease and dexterity. [Low]
An exclamation expressing, by different intonations, triumph,mixed with derision or irony, or simple surprise.

A large net, one edge of which is provided with sinkers, andthe other with floats. It hangs vertically in the water, and when itsends are brought together or drawn ashore incloses the fish. Seineboat, a boat specially constructed to carry and pay out a seine.
Old; ancient; as, the olden time. "A minstrel of the oldenstamp." J. C. Shairp.
To slay. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To make foul of filthy; to dirty. Swift.
To have part; to receive a portion; to partake, enjoy, orsuffer with others.A right of inheritance gave every one a title to share in the goodsof his father. Locke.
To pull roughly or hastily; to plunder; to spoil; to tear.[Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
Having a nap or pile; downy; shaggy. Holland.
Dark blue or bluish gray; lead-colored. [Scot.]
See Krang.
See Meathe. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To the inside of; within. It is used in a variety ofapplications.
The difference between the approximate result and the trueresult; -- used particularly in the rule of double position.
A small tortricid moth whose larva sews together the edges of aleaf by means of silk; as, the apple-leaf sewer (Phoxopterisnubeculana)

A swiveling carriage, consisting of a frame with one or morepairs of wheels and the necessary boxes, springs, etc., to carry andguide one end of a locomotive or a car; -- sometimes called bogie inEngland. Trucks usually have four or six wheels.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
Same as Ha.
A snare; a gin. [Obs.]Like a bird that hasteth to his grin. Remedy of Love.
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]

To turn the head of a vessel toward the wind; to sail nearerthe wind; to turn the tiller so as to make the vessel sail nearer thewind. To luff round, or To luff alee, to make the extreme of thismovement, for the purpose of throwing the ship's head into the wind.

The sixth month of the year, containing thirty days.And what is so rare as a day in June Then, if ever, come perfectdays. Lowell.June beetle, June bug (Zoöl.), any one of several species of largebrown beetles of the genus Lachnosterna and related genera; -- socalled because they begin to fly, in the northern United States,about the first of June. The larvæ of the June beetles live underground, and feed upon the roots of grasses and other plants. Calledalso May bug or May beetle.-- June grass (Bot.), a New England name for Kentucky blue grass.See Blue glass, and Illustration in Appendix.
The one of the five senses by which certain properties ofbodies (called their taste, savor, flavor) are ascertained by contactwith the organs of taste.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column ora vase.
An apparent right; as where the defendant in trespass gave tothe plaintiff an appearance of title, by stating his title specially,thus removing the cause from the jury to the court. Blackstone.
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240feet in length by 120 in breadth.
Rare; uncommon; unusual. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
A corruption of God's; -- formerly used in oaths andejaculatory phrases. "Ods bodikin." "Ods pity." Shak.

A thick, circular disk of wood, to which the cartridge bag andprojectile are attached, in fixed ammunition for cannon; also, apiece of soft metal attached to a projectile to take the groove ofthe rifling.
imp. of Speak.
See Noils.

A large vein of auriferous quartz; -- so called in Australia.Hence, any body of rock yielding valuable ore. Reef builder (Zoöl.),any stony coral which contributes material to the formation of coralreefs.-- Reef heron (Zoöl.), any heron of the genus Demigretta; as, theblue reef heron (D.jugularis) of Australia.

To present an answer, by allegation of fact, to the declarationof a plaintiff; to deny the plaintiff's declaration and demand, or toallege facts which show that ought not to recover in the suit; in aless strict sense, to make an allegation of fact in a cause; to carryon the allegations of the respective parties in a cause; to carry ona suit or plea. Blackstone. Burrill. Stephen.
To make a hissing sound; as, a flatiron hot enough to siss whentouched with a wet finger. [Colloq. U. S.; Local, Eng.]
A weaver's reed; a sley.
Guile. [Obs.] Chaucer.
of Do.
The soft naked sheath at the base of the beak of birds of prey,parrots, and some other birds. See Beak.
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop,are used instead of dice.
The shaft of a column, or trunk of pilaster. Gwilt.
A sharp sound, as of a bell; a tinkling.
To put off dress; to take off the hat.
The back part of the neck; the scruff. [Prov. Eng.] Ld. Lytton.
To ascend or creep upward by twining about a support, or byattaching itself by tendrills, rootlets, etc., to a support orupright surface.
To make dizzy or giddy; to give the vertigo to; to confuse.If the jangling of thy bells had not dizzied thy understanding. SirW. Scott.
Of or pertaining to an urn; effected by an urn or urns. "Urnalinterments." Sir T. Browne.
A tribe of Indians, which, together with the Foxes, formerlyoccupied the region about Green Bay, Wisconsin. [Written also Sauks.]
Of or pertaining to the region of the cheek bone, or to themalar bone; jugal.
, abbreviation of Amuck. To run a muck. See Amuck.
Legally qualified; possessed of legal competence; as, able toinherit or devise property.
One who names, or calls by name.

To make the noise of, or one like that of, a sheep; to cry likea sheep or calf.Then suddenly was heard along the main, To low the ox, to bleat thewoolly train. PopeThe ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas, will never answer acalf when he bleats. Shak.

A perennial suffrutescent plant (Ruta graveolens), having astrong, heavy odor and a bitter taste; herb of grace. It is used inmedicine.Then purged with euphrasy and rue The visual nerve, for he had muchto see. Milton.They [the exorcists] are to try the devil by holy water, incense,sulphur, rue, which from thence, as we suppose, came to be calledherb of grace. Jer. Taylor.
See Node.
A person easily deceived, tricked, or imposed on; a mean dupe;a gull.I have learned that . . . I am not the first cully whom she haspassed upon for a countess. Addison.
A thin, soft kind of muslin.
To shake with short, abrupt risings and fallings, as a carriagemoving on rough ground; as, the coach jolts.
To take or drink tea. [Colloq.]
A piece of ground taken out of any regular ground plot orfloor, so as to make a court, yard, etc.; -- sometimes written quink.Gwilt.

Active; lively; brisk; smart; -- often applied toconvalescents; as, she is quite peart to-day. [O. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.]There was a tricksy girl, I wot, albeit clad in gray, As peart asbird, as straight as bolt, as fresh as flowers in May. Warner (1592).
See Solus.
A kind of dandy; especially, one characterized by anultrafashionable style of dress and other affectations. [Recent]The social dude who affects English dress and English drawl. TheAmerican.
Death.[Obs.] Shak.
Near; hard by; along; past. [Obs.]To tell her if her child went ought forby. Chaucer.To the intent that ships may pass along forby all the sides of thecity without let. Robynson (More's Utopia).
A turf. [Obs.] Swift.
To drudge; to toil laboriously. [Obs.] "To drugge and draw."Chaucer.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.

To overlap (each other); -- said of bones or fracturedfragments. To ride a hobby, to have some favorite occupation orsubject of talk.-- To ride and tie, to take turn with another in labor and rest; --from the expedient adopted by two persons with one horse, one of whomrides the animal a certain distance, and then ties him for the use ofthe other, who is coming up on foot. Fielding.-- To ride down. (a) To ride over; to trample down in riding; tooverthrow by riding against; as, to ride down an enemy. (b) (Naut.)To bear down, as on a halyard when hoisting a sail.-- To ride out (Naut.), to keep safe afloat during (a storm) whileriding at anchor or when hove to on the open sea; as, to ride out thegale. to ride the lightning, (Colloq.) to be executed byelectrocution in an electric chair.

One of a series of ornaments, in the form of a frustum of acone, attached to the lower part of the triglyphs, and also to thelower faces of the mutules, in the Doric order; -- called alsocampana, and drop. Gutta serena Etym: [L., lit. serene or clear drop](Med.), amaurosis.-- Guttæ band (Arch.), the listel or band from which the guttæ hang.
A heavy, stupid fellow; a blockhead; a numskull; an ignoramus;a dunce; a dullard.This Puck seems but a dreaming dolt. Drayton.
Ho there; stop; attend; hence, a loud cry or a call to attractattention; a halloo.And every day, for food or play, Came to the mariner's hollo.Coleridge.
A fluke of an anchor.
The first month of the jewish ecclesiastical year, formerlyanswering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of theChristian calendar. See Abib.

Utmost; highest endeavor or state; most nearly perfect thing,or being, or action; as, to do one's best; to the best of ourability. At best, in the utmost degree or extent applicable to thecase; under the most favorable circumstances; as, life is at bestvery short.-- For best, finally. [Obs.] "Those constitutions . . . are nowestablished for best, and not to be mended." Milton.-- To get the best of, to gain an advantage over, whether fairly orunfairly.-- To make the best of. (a) To improve to the utmost; to use ordispose of to the greatest advantage. "Let there be freedom to carrytheir commodities where they can make the best of them." Bacon. (b)To reduce to the least possible inconvenience; as, to make the bestof ill fortune or a bad bargain.
, v. t. Etym: [Cf. OIcel. berja to strike.] To pierce. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like. Shak.
To deceive; to cheat; to mislead; to trick; to defraud.The rulgar, gulled into rebellion, armed. Dryden.I'm not gulling him for the emperor's service. Coleridge.
To wean. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
One who ogles. Addison.

To collect into a mass or heap; to gather a great quantity of;to accumulate; as, to amass a treasure or a fortune; to amass wordsor phrases.The life Homer has been written by amassing all the traditions andhints the writers could meet with. Pope.
Abounding with husks; consisting of husks. Dryden.
A kind of mollusk, a whelk. [Prov. Eng.]
The female of the red deer, of which the male is the stag.
To call, as a hen her chickens. Dryden.
imp. & p. p. of Get. See Get.
imp. of Wring. Wrung. Chaucer.
Resembling, or covered with a substance resembling, rust;affected with rust; rubiginous.
The stroke in beating time.
A gap. [Obs.] Colgrave.
Same as Laplander. Cf. Lapps.
Any thick lump, mass, or cake; especially, a large regularlyshaped or molded mass, as of bread, sugar, or cake. Bacon. Loafsugar, refined sugar that has been formed into a conical loaf in amold.
A yarn measure of six hundred yards or of a spindle. SeeSpindle.

A thing; personal property. Chose in action, a thing of whichone has not possession or actual enjoyment, but only a right to it,or a right to demand it by action at law, and which does not exist atthe time in specie; a personal right to a thing not reduced topossession, but recoverable by suit at law; as a right to recovermoney due on a contract, or damages for a tort, which can not beenforced against a reluctant party without suit.-- Chose in possession, a thing in possession, as distinguished froma thing in action.-- Chose local, a thing annexed to a place, as a mill.-- Chose transitory, a thing which is movable. Cowell. Blount.
To moisten with dew, or as with dew. "Falling tears his facebedew." Dryden.
Judgment; justice; sentence. [Obs.]Up [on] pain of hanging and high juise. Chaucer.
See Coca.
Made or consisting of oaks or of the wood of oaks. "In oakenbower." Milton.Oaken timber, wherewith to build ships. Bacon.
The land belonging, or yielding revenue, to a parish church orecclesiastical benefice.
A genus of fishes. See Saury.
To drink in great draughts; to swallow greedily.Well-dressed people, of both sexes, . . . devouring sliced beef, andswilling pork, and punch, and cider. Smollett.
A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of SouthAmerica.
imp. & p. p. of Rap, to snatch away.
Same as Tatou.
A European species of lavender (Lavandula spica), whichproduces a volatile oil. See Spike.

The bottom of the body of a plow; -- called also slade; also,the bottom of a furrow.(b) (Far.) The horny substance under a horse's foot, which protectsthe more tender parts.(c) (Fort.) The bottom of an embrasure.(d) (Naut.) A piece of timber attached to the lower part of therudder, to make it even with the false keel. Totten.(e) (Mining) The seat or bottom of a mine; -- applied to horizontalveins or lodes. Sole leather, thick, strong, used for making thesoles of boots and shoes, and for other purposes.
A tocsin. [Obs.] Halliwell.
To protect from the intrusion of the uninitiated; as, to tile aMasonic lodge.
Mad; insane; possessed; rabid; furious; frantic. [Obs.][Written also wode.]Our hoste gan to swear as [if] he were wood. Chaucer.
A circle; hence, a diadem. [Obs.] Shak.

The front of an army; the first line or leading column; also,the front line or foremost division of a fleet, either in sailing orin battle.Standards and gonfalons, twixt van and rear, Stream in the air.Milton.
A rope; also, a measure equal to a rod. [Scot.]
A diarrhea or flux. [Obs.] Holland.
Counterfeit money. [Slang] To shove the queer, to putcounterfeit money in circulation. [Slang]
To turn about a fixed point, usually the center or axis, as aspar or piece of timber; to turn; -- used also of any heavy body.
A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on thedestruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed toHomer.
See Fidget. [R.] Swift.
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.[R.] Boyle.
A small shield, especially one of an approximately ellipticform, or crescent-shaped.
To scratch. [Obs.] Burton.
A stiff, long saw, guided at the ends but not stretched in agate. Muley axle (Railroad), a car axle without collars at the outerends of the journals. Forney.
of Leap. [Obs.]And, laughing, lope into a tree. Spenser.
A square bar of wood or iron, used to support the topmast,being passed through a hole or mortise at its heel, and resting onthe trestle trees.
See 5th Scald.
See Sirocco. [Poetic] Emerson.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of itsspecies or kind; especially, a diminutive human being.
sing. of Mores.
A composition for two performers, whether vocal orinstrumental.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now,commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corneris marked.
A French mastiff.
A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England inmarking sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
To make a pompons display; to conduct. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Any animal which is unusually small, as compared with others ofits kind; -- applied particulary to domestic animals.
The Amish Mennonites.
A frantic revel; drunken revelry. See Orgies
A light, brisk musical movement.Hot and hasty, like a Scotch jib. Shak.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the orderPlagiostomi, found in all seas.
See Pillau.
An opaque, compact variety of barite, or heavy spar. [Alsowritten cauk.]
Any marine annelid of the genus Hyalinæcia, especially H.tubicola of Europe, which inhabits a transparent movable tuberesembling a quill in color and texture.
imp. & p.p. of Curse.
Wholly; entirely; absolutely; quite; as, stark mind. Shak.Held him strangled in his arms till he was stark dead. Fuller.Stark naked, wholly naked; quite bare.Strip your sword stark naked. Shak.

A prefix from Latin de down, from, away; as in debark, decline,decease, deduct, decamp. In words from the French it is equivalent toLatin dis- apart, away; or sometimes to de. Cf. Dis-. It is negativeand opposite in derange, deform, destroy, etc. It is intensive indeprave, despoil, declare, desolate, etc.
Sliced cabbage served as a salad, cooked or uncooked.
A tackle with ropes which are not parallel.
See Coil. [Obs.]
Great anxiety accompanied by painful constriction at the upperpart of the belly, often with palpitation and oppression.
See Whang. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
An ornamental tuft of feathers.
To quaver. [Obs.] See Quob.
A broken gait of a horse, between an amble and a gallop; --commonly called a Canterbury gallop.
A suffix sometimes marking the agent for action; as, merchant,covenant, servant, pleasant, etc. Cf. -ent.
See 1st Mot. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To assail with contemptuous cries or shouts; to follow withderisive shouts.Partridge and his clan may hoot me for a cheat. Swift.

To bring to ruin; to cause to fall to pieces and decay; to maketo perish; to bring to destruction; to bring to poverty orbankruptcy; to impair seriously; to damage essentially; to overthrow.this mortal house I'll ruin. Shak.By thee raised, I ruin all my foes. Milton.The eyes of other people are the eyes that ruin us. Franklin.By the fireside there are old men seated, Seeling ruined cities inthe ashes. Longfellow.
A professional tramp; one who spends his life traveling fromplace to place, esp. by stealing rides on trains, and begging for aliving. [U. S.] -- Ho"bo*ism (#), n.
To have an opinion; to judge; to think; to suppose. South.
A South American freah-water fish (Myleies pacu), of the familyCharacinidæ. It is highly esteemed as food.
In a glow; glowing; as, cheeks aglow; the landscape all aglow.
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for onesecond, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; --proposed by J.D.Everett, an English physicist.
A Turret. [Obs.]
Pshaw! pish! nonsense! -- an expression of scorn, dislike, orcontempt.
An iron attachment on one end of a mast or boom, with a ring,through which another mast or boom is rigged out and secured; awythe. R. H. Dana, Jr.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animalor vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils. Graham.
The mane of an animal.
The orang-outang.
Although. [Reformed spelling] Alt"horn`, n. Etym: [Alt + horn.](Mus.)
See Grilse.
A leguminous plant of the genus Medicago. The black medic isthe Medicago lupulina; the purple medic, or lucern, is M. sativa.
See Gyrus.
Hoar. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Goods found of which the owner is not known; originally, suchgoods as a pursued thief threw away to prevent being apprehended,which belonged to the king unless the owner made pursuit of thefelon, took him, and brought him to justice. Blackstone.
Axle grease. See Gome. [Prov. Eng.]
To stand, depend, hang, or turn, as on a hinge; to dependchiefly for a result or decision or for force and validity; --usually with on or upon; as, the argument hinges on this point. I.Taylor
A loch or lake; -- so spelt in Ireland.
Used to the way; broken. [R.]A horse that is not well wayed; he starts at every bird that fliesout the hedge. Selden.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one ofthe second class.
An abbreviation of Congius.
Not any; not one; none.Let there be no strife ... between me and thee. Gen. xiii. 8.That goodness is no name, and happiness no dream. Byron.
Whole. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A plant of the genus Ziziphus (Z. lotus); -- so called by theArabs of Barbary, who use its berries for food. See Lotus (b).
See Greet, to weep.
Dearth; scarcity. [Obs.] Spenser.
A variant of Height.
To sound. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Disease, especially of a contagious kind. Lues venerea,syphilis; -- called also simply lues.
The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast. [Obs.]A most tempestuous blore. Chapman.
An American fish; the lafayette or spot.
An official expounder of Mohammedan law.
Hasty; reckless; rash. [Obs.] Chaucer.-- Ra"kel*ness, n. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To pour water on; to soak in, or mix with, water. [Obs. orProv. Eng.] Grose.My fowls, which well enough, I, as before, found feeding at theirtrough Their yoted wheat. Chapman.
To be leveled with the ground; to fall; to suffer overthrow.[Obs.]
A measure of distance, varying from four to ten miles, butusually about five. [India] [Written also yojana.]
To drive or urge forward or on; to press on; to incite toaction or motion in any way.The surge impelled me on a craggy coast. Pope.
A river flood; an overflow or inundation. Burns.Gareth in a showerful spring Stared at the spate. Tennyson.
To utter or tell unnecessarily, or in a thoughtless manner; topublish (secrets or trifles) without reserve or discretion. Udall.And yonder a vile physician blabbing The case of his patient.Tennyson.
To thwack. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The mink; -- called also minx otter. [Obs.]
To please; -- chiefly used impersonally. [Obs.] " Sith itlyketh you." Chaucer.
Washed. Chaucer.
Wild; noisy; boisterous.
To bite; to gnaw. [Written also roin.] [Obs.] Spenser.
A Spanish dollar; also, an Argentine, Chilian, Colombian, etc.,coin, equal to from 75 cents to a dollar; also, a pound weight.
Account; reckoning; computation. [Obs.] Shak.
Not; never. [Obs.]He never yet no villany ne said. Chaucer.
Ere; before. [Obs.] Sylvester.

A heavy iron tool, curved and sometimes pointed at both ends,wielded by means of a wooden handle inserted in the middle, -- usedby quarrymen, roadmakers, etc.; also, a pointed hammer used fordressing millstones.
A hybrid animal; specifically, one generated between an ass anda mare, sometimes a horse and a she-ass. See Hinny.
A genus of palms from which sago is obtained.
imp. & p. p. of Flee.

The capital city of Peru, in South America. Lima bean. (Bot.)(a) A variety of climbing or pole bean (Phaseolus lunatus), which hasvery large flattish seeds. (b) The seed of this plant, much used forfood.-- Lima wood (Bot.), the beautiful dark wood of the South Americantree Cæsalpinia echinata.

The hinder part or buttocks of certain quadrupeds, especiallyof a horse; hence, the place behind the saddle.So light to the croup the fair lady he swung, So light to the saddlebefore her he sprung. Sir W. Scott.
See Cross, n. [Obs.]
In a dripping state; as, leaves all adrip. D. G. Mitchell.

imp. of Cleave. Cleft. Spenser. Clove hitch (Naut.) See underHitch.-- Clove hook (Naut.), an iron two-part hook, with jaws overlapping,used in bending chain sheets to the clews of sails; -- called alsoclip hook. Knight.
Good. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., acompound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with amonamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms ofhydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; --frequently used as a combining form; as, succinimide.
Hair. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See 2d Reis.

A tree of the genus Ulmus, of several species, much used as ashade tree, particularly in America. The English elm is Ulmuscampestris; the common American or white elm is U. Americana; theslippery or red elm, U. fulva. Elm beetle (Zoöl.), one of severalspecies of beetles (esp. Galeruca calmariensis), which feed on theleaves of the elm.-- Elm borer (Zoöl.), one of several species of beetles of which thelarvæ bore into the wood or under the bark of the elm (esp. Saperdatridentata).-- Elm butterfly (Zoöl.), one of several species of butterflies,which, in the caterpillar state, feed on the leaves of the elm (esp.Vanessa antiopa and Grapta comma). See Comma butterfly, under Comma.-- Elm moth (Zoöl.), one of numerous species of moths of which thelarvæ destroy the leaves of the elm (esp. Eugonia subsignaria, calledelm spanworm).-- Elm sawfly (Zoöl.), a large sawfly (Cimbex Americana). The larva,which is white with a black dorsal stripe, feeds on the leaves of theelm.
See Mo. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, inconsequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.

Any young insect from the time that it hatches from the egguntil it becomes a pupa, or chrysalis. During this time it usuallymolts several times, and may change its form or color each time. Thelarvæ of many insects are much like the adults in form and habits,but have no trace of wings, the rudimentary wings appearing only inthe pupa stage. In other groups of insects the larvæ are totallyunlike the parents in structure and habits, and are calledcaterpillars, grubs, maggots, etc.
A dove. [Scot.]
Air. [Obs.] Chaucer.
imp. of Tread.On burnished hooves his war-horse trode. Tennyson.
The edible berries of the Zizyphys Lotus, a tree of NorthernAfrica, and Southwestern Europe. [Written also nubk.] See Lotus (b),and Sadr.
A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.[Colloq.] C. Kingsley.
A wall-like mass of mineral matter, usually an intrusion ofigneous rocks, filling up rents or fissures in the original strata.
That part of a roofing slate, shingle, tile, or metal plate,which is exposed to the weather.
To be dizzy; to have an unsteady or reeling sensation; as, thehead swims.

A large Asiatic antelope (Budorcas taxicolor) native of thehigher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head andneck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat.Called also budorcas.

A member of the conservative party, as opposed to theprogressive party which was formerly called the Whig, and is nowcalled the Liberal, party; an earnest supporter of exsisting royaland ecclesiastical authority.
grog. [Obs.] Sir W. Scott.
In a general sense, from, or out from; proceeding from;belonging to; relating to; concerning; -- used in a variety ofapplications; as:
Sparing; parsimonious. [Obs.]
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
See Slant. [Obs.]
Been. Chaucer.
Something infixed. [R.] Welsford.
The inward part of a building; the interior. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To strike off an impression or impressions of, from type, orfrom stereotype, electrotype, or engraved plates, or the like; in awider sense, to do the typesetting, presswork, etc., of (a book orother publication); as, to print books, newspapers, pictures; toprint an edition of a book.
To indicate by signs, as future events; to be the omen of; toportend to presage; to foreshow.A raven that bodes nothing but mischief. Goldsmith.Good onset bodes good end. Spenser.

A beginner in learning; one who is in the rudiments of anybranch of study; a person imperfectly acquainted with a subject; anovice. [Written also tiro.]The management of tyros of eighteen Is difficult. Cowper.
To check; to sneap; to sneb. [Obs.]Him would he snib sharply for the nones. Chaucer.
A pit. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A small, handsome, long-tailed West American monkey(Cercopithecus mona). The body is dark olive, with a spot of white onthe haunches.
The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out. [Eng.]
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barleymeal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians. [writtenalso quas.]
The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most importantof the exercises of the Pentathlon.
To supply with food. [Obs.] Baret.
A name given to various species of arctic sea birds of thefamily Alcidæ. The great auk, now extinct, is Alca (or Plautus)impennis. The razor-billed auk is A. torda. See Puffin, Guillemot,and Murre.
In an able manner; with great ability; as, ably done, planned,said.
Any insect in that stage of its metamorphosis which usuallyimmediately precedes the adult, or imago, stage.

To affect with pain or uneasiness, either physical or mental;to trouble; to be the matter with; -- used to express some uneasinessor affection, whose cause is unknown; as, what ails the man I knownot what ails him.What aileth thee, Hagar Gen. xxi. 17.
The ramie or grass-cloth plant. See Grass-cloth plant, underGrass.
Luxury. [Obs.] Shenstone. Édition de luxe (. Etym: [F.](Printing) A sumptuous edition as regards paper, illustrations,binding, etc.
To guide; to govern. [Obs.]Discreet enough his country for to gye. Chaucer.
See 2d Tike.
Soot. [Obs.] Spenser.
To fasten together by dowels; to furnish with dowels; as, acooper dowels pieces for the head of a cask.
To make drunk. [Obs.] Wood.
See Homelyn.
To make a jarring noise, as in running; as, the engine pounds.
A name given to four of the twelve astrological "houses."[Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Sacs.
Amice, a hood or cape. See 2d Amice.
A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.As false as dicers' oaths. Shak.
A boy's game played with large marbles.

Preceding in the order of time; former; antecedent; anterior;previous; as, a prior discovery; prior obligation; -- usedelliptically in cases like the following: he lived alone [in thetime] prior to his marriage.
Of a dark brown color, with a little red in its composition;also, made of, or done in, sepia.
See Matte. Knight.
To work to windward; to beat.
A wading bird of the genus Grus, and allied genera, of variousspecies, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
See Quit. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A white fluid secreted by the mammary glands of female mammalsfor the nourishment of their young, consisting of minute globules offat suspended in a solution of casein, albumin, milk sugar, andinorganic salts. "White as morne milk." Chaucer.
A large African antelope (Alcelaphus Lichtensteini), allied tothe hartbeest, but having shorter and flatter horns, and lacking ablack patch on the face.
A suffix or combining form meaning like, resembling, in theform of; as in anthropoid, asteroid, spheroid.
3d sing. pres. of Abide. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Like pile or wool.
A form of decay in fruit which is overripe.
See Spoom. [Obs.]We might have spooned before the wind as well as they. Pepys.
The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which allMohammedans must pray. [Written also kaaba.]
A house or mansion. [Sp. Amer. & Phil. Islands]
Bearing a press of canvas without careening much; as, a stiffvessel; -- opposed to crank. Totten.
A division of a perianth. [R.]
Sherry. See Sherry.
The fossil resin of the kauri tree of New Zealand.
To sparkle. [Obs.] Spenser.
A West African gazelle (Gazella redunca).
A wicker fish basket.
Started; leaped.They privily be stirt into a well. Chaucer.
The act of trekking; a drawing or a traveling; a journey; amigration. [Chiefly South Africa]
As if dead; lifeless; spiritless; dejected; depressed. Shak.
Mean; not extreme.
The East Indian name of a virulent poison extracted fromAconitum ferox or other species of aconite: also, the plant itself.
A colorless gaseous substance (O
A Chinese musical instrument, consisting of resonant stones ormetal plates, arranged according to their tones in a frame of wood,and struck with a hammer.
In a gushing state. Hawthorne.
An arrow, having a rotary motion, formerly used with thecrossbow. Cf. Vireton. Gower.
To make new. [Obs.] Skelton.
Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges. [Obs.Eng.]
See Sty, a boil. [R.] De quincey.
Solace. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A shelter. Same as Beild. [Scot.]
The second month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year,corresponding to our May.
An awl. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A lodge; a habitation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Cymry.
A pustule; a whelk. Wiseman.
To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt.Lo! where the stripling, wrapt in wonder, roves. Beattie.
imp. & p. p. of Say.
To lie in warmth; to be exposed to genial heat.Basks in the glare, and stems the tepid wave. Goldsmith.
A shekel. [Obs.]The holy mother brought five sicles and a pair of turtledoves toredeem the Lamb of God. Jer. Taylor.
A shade for the face, projecting from the bonnet. [Colloq.Eng.] C. Kingsley.
Foam rising upon beer, or other malt liquors, when fermenting,and used as leaven in making bread and in brewing; yeast. Shak.
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; Hence, a lady's flatworkbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba. C. Bronté.
To set in order, as a jury, for the trial of a cause; that is,to call them man by man. Blackstone. To array a panel, to set forthin order the men that are impaneled. Cowell. Tomlins.
To move as an eddy, or as in an eddy; to move in a circle.Eddying round and round they sink. Wordsworth.

A gaseous prodact, formed in coal mines, old wells, pints, etc.Choke damp, a damp consisting principally of carboniCarbonic acid,under Carbonic.-- Damp sheet, a curtain in a mine gallery to direct air currentsand prevent accumulation of gas.-- Fire damp, a damp consisting chiefly of light carburetedhydrogen; -- so called from its tendence to explode when mixed withatmospheric air and brought into contact with flame.
See Set, n., 2 (e) and 3.
An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in thecountries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; --called also carob tree.
A small salmon; a grilse; a sewin. [Prov. Eng.]
A hillock; a small kop. [South Africa]

A pointed instrument for piercing small holes, as in leather orwood; used by shoemakers, saddlers, cabinetmakers, etc. The blade isdifferently shaped and pointed for different uses, as in the bradawl, saddler's awl, shoemaker's awl, etc.
A fresh-water herbivorous fish (Cyprinus carpio.). Severalother species of Cyprinus, Catla, and Carassius are called carp. SeeCruclan carp.
An addition to, or a paraphrase of, some part of the Latinservice in the vernacular; -- common in English before theReformation.
Same as Hamele.
Over again; another time; in a new form; afresh; as, to armanew; to create anew. Dryden.
A wand. See Verge. [Obs.]

Freodom from motion, agitation, or disturbance; a cessation orabeence of that which causes motion or disturbance, as of winds orwaves; tranquility; stilness; quiet; serenity.The wind ceased, and there was a great calm. Mark. iv. 39.A calm before a storm is commonly a peace of a man's own making.South.
The European cormorant.
Apt to balk; as, a balky horse.
Paid; pleased. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
Crooked; lame; as, a game leg. [Colloq.]
A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of thehumerus.
A regular solid body, with six equal square sides.

A bundle of fibers, or a loosely twisted or braided cord, tape,or tube, usually made of soft spun cotton threads, which by capillaryattraction draws up a steady supply of the oil in lamps, the meltedtallow or wax in candles, or other material used for illumination, insmall successive portions, to be burned.But true it is, that when the oil is spent The light goes out, andwick is thrown away. Spenser.
A bladder growing on the root of the tongue of a horse, againstthe windpipe, and stopping the breath.
A substance regarded as an element, contained in the atmosphereand remarkable for its chemical inertness. Rayleigh and Ramsay.
To frighten; to worry. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] T. Brown.
Hence, figuratively: The interior part of anything; as, thebowels of the earth.His soldiers . . . cried out amain, And rushed into the bowels of thebattle. Shak.
A prefix signifying within. See Ento-.
An exclamation of grief. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
To put off by trickery; to cheat. [Obs.]I have been fubbed off, and fubbed off, and fabbed off, from this dayto that day. Shak.
To jeer; to show contempt. Sir W. Scott.
A mixture of soot and other ingredients, used by Egyptian andother Eastern women to darken the edges of the eyelids.
An arctic fish (Gadus luscus), allied to the cod; -- calledalso pout and whiting pout.
Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobeor lobes.
A roommate, especially in a college or university; an old andintimate friend.
A European fresh-water cyprinoid fish of the genus Abramis,little valued as food. Several species are known.
A variant of Dan, a title of honor. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who, or that which, ties.
A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.

Small roundish masses of ice precipitated from the clouds,where they are formed by the congelation of vapor. The separatemasses or grains are called hailstones.Thunder mixed with hail, Hail mixed with fire, must rend the Egyptiansky. Milton.

To pass gradually from a sound, prosperous, or perfect state,to one of imperfection, adversity, or dissolution; to waste away; todecline; to fail; to become weak, corrupt, or disintegrated; to rot;to perish; as, a tree decays; fortunes decay; hopes decay.Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, Where wealthaccumulates and men decay. Goldsmith.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Say. [Archaic]
The suslik. [Written also zisel.]
The tumultuous disturbance of the public peace by an unlawfulassembly of three or more persons in the execution of some privateobject. To run riot, to act wantonly or without restraint.
Same as Spurt.
Of or pertaining to a web or webs; like a web; filled orcovered with webs.Bats on their webby wings in darkness move. Crabbe.

Very large; enormous; immense; excessive; -- used esp. ofmaterial bulk, but often of qualities, extent, etc.; as, a huge ox; ahuge space; a huge difference. "The huge confusion." Chapman. "A hugefilly." Jer. Taylor.-- Huge"ly, adv.-- Huge"ness, n.Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea. Shak.
See Amends. [Obs.] Shak.
Within; in; in or into the interior; toward the innerapartment. [Scot.]
An edge or point; also, a beginning. [ Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Chaucer. Ord and end, the beginning and end. Cf. Odds and ends, underOdds. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Chaucer. Halliwell.
A peculiar flavor or taint; as, a musty tack. [Obs. or Colloq.]Drayton.
A noun suffix with a diminutive force; as in baronet, pocket,facet, floweret, latchet.
A shoot or sprout from the ground. Gray.

Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimesused in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates ofthe alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkalinesulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (.
A suffix signifying dominion, jurisdiction; as, bishopric, thedistrict over which a bishop exercises authority.
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion ofcoagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
A genus of Carnivora including the common bears.

A little mass or weight of lead, or the like, attached to aline, and used by builders, etc., to indicate a vertical direction; aplummet; a plumb bob. See Plumb line, below. Plumb bob. See Bob, 4.-- Plumb joint, in sheet-metal work, a lap joint, fastened bysolder.-- Plumb level. See under Level.-- Plumb line. (a) The cord by which a plumb bob is suspended; aplummet. (b) A line directed to the center of gravity of the earth.-- Plumb rule, a narrow board with a plumb line, used by buildersand carpenters.
See Sunfish, 1.

That part of a mine from which the mineral has been partiallyor wholly removed; the waste left in old workings; -- called also gob. To work the goaf or gob, to remove the pillars of mineral matterpreviously left to support the roof, and replace them with props.Ure.

A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere,including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces.These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces,in this and other respects differing from the firs.
Spongy; soft; fat and puffy. [Scot.]
To vex; to tease; to trouble. [Scot.]
A kind of large knife resembling a machete. [Phil. Islands]
To make an effort to vomit; to strain, as in vomiting. [Writtenalso reach.]Beloved Julia, hear me still beseeching! (Here he grew inarticulatewith retching.) Byron.
A weight of British India. The standard tola is equal to 180grains.
A lunar distance.
A narrow glen; a ravine; a dell. [Old Eng. & Scotch] Shak.

A quadruped of the genus Sus, and allied genera of Suidæ; esp.,the domesticated varieties of S. scrofa, kept for their fat and meat,called, respectively, lard and pork; swine; porker; specifically, acastrated boar; a barrow.
of Know.
To destroy. [Obs.] Tusser.
A rocking or balanced stone. Gwill.
To smile in an affected or conceited manner; to smile withaffected complaisance; to simper.

A genus of plants found in central Europe and about theMediterranean, having flowers on a spadix inclosed in a spathe. Thecuckoopint of the English is an example.Our common arums the lords and ladies of village children. Lubbock.

An inlet from the Gulf of Mexico, from a lake, or from a largeriver, sometimes sluggish, sometimes without perceptible movementexcept from tide and wind. [Southern U. S.]A dark slender thread of a bayou moves loiteringly northeastward intoa swamp of huge cypresses. G. W. Cable.

To vex by bringing to notice, or reminding of, a fault, defect,misfortune, or the like; to revile; to reproach; to upbraid; totaunt; as, he twitted his friend of falsehood.This these scoffers twitted the Christian with. Tillotson.Æsop minds men of their errors, without twitting them for what isamiss. L'Estrange.
To diminish in strength; to abate; to subside. "When the rageallays." Shak.

A plant of the genus Viola (V. tricolor) and its blossom,originally purple and yellow. Cultivated varieties have very largeflowers of a great diversity of colors. Called also heart's-ease,love-in-idleness, and many other quaint names.
See Beak. [Obs.] Spenser.
A hole in the ground, or hiding place, for concealing andpreserving provisions which it is inconvenient to carry. Kane.
A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacketplated with mail. [Spelled also hacqueton.] [Obs.] Halliwell. Sir W.Scott.
See Bots.
To shut with violence; to slam; as, to slot a door. [Obs. orProv. Eng.]
The act of fainting, or the state of one who has fainted; aswoon. [R.] See Fainting, n.The saint, Who propped the Virgin in her faint. Sir W. Scott.
A tower. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A fragment; -- now used only in composition, as in potsherd.See Shard.The thigh . . . which all in sherds it drove. Chapman.
A donkey. [Cant] Thackeray.
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil.It has an unpleasant garlic odor.

The cheek; the jaw. [Written also jole, choule, chowle, andgeoule.] Cheek by jowl, with the cheeks close together; side by side;in close proximity. "I will go with three cheek by jole." Shak. "Sits cheek by jowl." Dryden.
To splice together the ends of slivers of wool, for subsequentdrawing. Planked shad, shad split open, fastened to a plank, androasted before a wood fire.
An exclamation expressive of sorrow. [Archaic. or Poet.] Shak.
of Dress.
One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragus, or Oryx,nasomaculatus).

Of or pertaining to the Isle of Man, or its inhabitants; as,the Manx language. Manx cat (Zoöl.), a breed of domestic cats havinga rudimentary tail, containing only about three vertebrae.-- Manx shearwater (Zoöl.), an oceanic bird (Puffinus anglorum, orP. puffinus), called also Manx petrel, Manx puffin. It was formerlyabundant in the Isle of Man.
To take a blot; as, this paper blots easily.
That has lost freshness, color, or brightness; grown dim. "Hisfaded cheek." Milton.Where the faded moon Made a dim silver twilight. Keats.
To make ready; to prepare; to dress. [Obs.]We will all bowne ourselves for the banquet. Sir W. Scott.
To furnish with pews. [R.] Ash.
Relating to wheels or to rotary motion; rotary. [R.]
The issue in a writ of right.
Anything that is very puzzling or difficult to explain. Dr.Sheridan.The perpetual crux of New Testament chronologists. Strauss.
A genus of African antelopes which includes the gemsbok, theleucoryx, the bisa antelope (O. beisa), and the beatrix antelope (O.beatrix) of Arabia.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbowto wrist. [Obs.]
The urus.

A cap. Specifically: (a) A close-fitting cap covering the sidesof the head, like a small hood without a cape. (b) An officialheaddress, such as that worn by certain judges in England. [Writtingalso quoif.]From point and saucy ermine down To the plain coif and russet gown.H. Brocke.The judges, . . . althout they are not of the first magnitude, norneed be of the degree of the coif, yet are they considerable. Bacon.
An old form of Elf.
Zonate.
A kind of wig; false hair.
An exclamation expressing contempt or disgust; bah !

To compose fables; hence, to write or speak fiction ; to writeor utter what is not true. "He Fables not." Shak.Vain now the tales which fabling poets tell. Prior.He fables, yet speaks truth. M. Arnold.
of Kythe. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A species of Macropiper (M. methysticum), the long pepper, fromthe root of which an intoxicating beverage is made by thePolynesians, by a process of mastication; also, the beverage itself.[Written also kawa, kava, and ava.]
Formed into a row, or rows; having a row, or rows; as, atwelve-rowed ear of corn.
To put in an urn, as the ashes of the dead; hence, to bury; tointomb.The sepulcher Wherein we saw thee quietly inurned. Shak.
Go away; begone; away; -- chiefly used in driving off a cat.
A rhymer; a versifier.

A nobleman of England ranking below a marquis, and above aviscount. The rank of an earl corresponds to that of a count (comte)in France, and graf in Germany. Hence the wife of an earl is stillcalled countess. See Count.

A passage or hall of communication, especially when largeenough to serve also as a waiting room. It differs from anantechamber in that a lobby communicates between several rooms, anantechamber to one only; but this distinction is not carefullypreserved.
To make a gash, or long, deep incision in; -- applied chieflyto incisions in flesh.Grievously gashed or gored to death. Hayward.
It is silent; -- a direction for a vocal or instrumental partto be silent during a whole movement.

An official diviner who foretold events by the singing,chattering, flight, and feeding of birds, or by signs or omensderived from celestial phenomena, certain appearances of quadrupeds,or unusual occurrences.

A patriarch of Biblical history, in the time of the Deluge.Noah's ark. (a) (Zoöl.) A marine bivalve shell (Arca Noæ), whichsomewhat resembles an ark, or ship, in form. (b) A child's toy,consisting of an ark-shaped box containing many different woodenanimals.
To regulate the sounds of, as musical strings, by pressing themagainst the finger board with the finger, or by shortening in any waythe vibrating part.
A supernatural being, often represented as of diminutive size,but sometimes as a giant, and fabled to inhabit caves, hills, andlike places; a witch. Troll flower. (Bot.) Same as Globeflower (a).

Articles, especially of food, accumulated for some specificobject; supplies, as of provisions, arms, ammunition, and the like;as, the stores of an army, of a ship, of a family.His swine, his horse, his stoor, and his poultry. Chaucer.In store, in a state of accumulation; in keeping; hence, in a stateof readiness. "I have better news in store for thee." Shak.-- Store clothes, clothing purchased at a shop or store; -- indistinction from that which is home-made. [Colloq. U.S.] -- Storepay, payment for goods or work in articles from a shop or store,instead of money. [U.S.] -- To set store by, to value greatly; tohave a high appreciation of.-- To tell no store of, to make no account of; to consider of noimportance.
An internal muscle arising from the lumbar vertebræ andinserted into the femur. In man there are usually two on each side,and the larger one, or great psoas, forms a part of the iliopsoas.
One who makes a vow. Bale.

A common baptismal name for a man. The name of one of theapostles, Peter boat, a fishing boat, sharp at both ends, originallyof the Baltic Sea, but now common in certain English rivers.-- Peter Funk, the auctioneer in a mock auction. [Cant, U.S.] --Peter pence, or Peter's pence. (a) An annual tax or tribute, formerlypaid by the English people to the pope, being a penny for everyhouse, payable on Lammas or St.Peter's day; -- called also Rome scot,and hearth money. (b) In modern times, a voluntary contribution madeby Roman Catholics to the private purse of the pope.-- Peter's fish (Zoöl.), a haddock; -- so called because the blackspots, one on each side, behind the gills, are traditionally said tohave been caused by the fingers of St. Peter, when he caught the fishto pay the tribute. The name is applied, also, to other fishes havingsimilar spots.
See Show.
imp. of Upgive. Chaucer.
Same as lst Gore.
A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by theTurks. See Rhusma.
Same as Haft, n. [Obs.] Waller.
Three, at cards, dice, or dominoes; a card, die, or domino ofthree spots or pips.Seven is my chance and thine is cinq and trey. Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the cod (Gadus); -- applied toan acid obtained from cod-liver oil, viz., gadic acid.
A little teat; a nipple. [Familiar]

A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering forthe back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps orbrooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of thesame stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plainlinen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. Thebreastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.Exodus xxviii. 6-12.
That part of a garment which is turned back; specifically, thelap, or fold, of the front of a coat in continuation of collar.[Written also lappel and lapelle.]
To whirl round, or revolve, with a whizzing noise; to fly ormore quickly with a buzzing or whizzing sound; to whiz.The partridge bursts away on whirring wings. Beattie.

The metal casing and flange fitted about a pipe where it passesthrough a roof. Boot catcher, the person at an inn whose business itwas to pull off boots and clean them. [Obs.] Swift.-- Boot closer, one who, or that which, sews the uppers of boots.-- Boot crimp, a frame or device used by bootmakers for drawing andshaping the body of a boot.-- Boot hook, a hook with a handle, used for pulling on boots.-- Boots and saddles (Cavalry Tactics), the trumpet call which isthe first signal for mounted drill.-- Sly boots. See Slyboots, in the Vocabulary.
To leap or jump about in a sprightly manner; to cut capers; toskip; to spring; to prance; to dance.He capers, he dances, he has eyes of youth. Shak.
To roll; to spout; to boil up. [Obs.] Holland.
A shield or target. [Obs. or Poetic] "A buckler on a targe."Chaucer.
imp. & p. p. of Tread.
To peen.
Animal fat; lard.
To release from confinement or restraint. Keats.
A shock of grain. [Prev.Eng.]
A small sailing vessel, commonly rigged as a sloop, usedchiefly in the coasting and fishing trade.
